headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, and welcome to Skyworks Solutions' First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Steve Ferranti, Vice President of Investor Relations for Skywork
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, and welcome to Skyworks Solutions' First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Steve Ferranti, Vice President of Investor Relations for Skyworks. Mr. Ferranti, please go ahead.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks first fiscal quarter 2016 conference call. Joining me today are Dave Aldrich, Don Palette and Liam Griffin. Dave will begin today's call with the business overview, followed by Don's fina
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks first fiscal quarter 2016 conference call. Joining me today are Dave Aldrich, Don Palette and Liam Griffin. Dave will begin today's call with the business overview, followed by Don's financial review and outlook. We will then open the lines for your questions.
Please note that our comments today will include statements relating to future results that are forward-looking as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially and adversely from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, those noted in our earnings release and those detailed from time to time in our SEC filings.
I would also like to remind everyone that the results and guidance we will discuss today are from our non-GAAP income statement, consistent with the format we've used in the past. Please refer to our press release within the Investor Relations section of our company website for a complete reconciliation to GAAP. With that, I will turn the call over to Dave for his comments in the quarter.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and welcome, everyone. We had a solid first quarter performance with revenue profitability and earnings ahead of expectations in spite of the challenging macro environment. As specifically during the quarter, we delivered revenue of $927 mi
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and welcome, everyone. We had a solid first quarter performance with revenue profitability and earnings ahead of expectations in spite of the challenging macro environment. As specifically during the quarter, we delivered revenue of $927 million, that's up 15% year-over-year. We produced operating income of $367 million, that's up 30% year-over-year, translating into a 39.6% operating margin. And we posted $1.60 in earnings per share that's up 27% versus the prior year. We also generated more than $345 million in operating cash flow and ended the quarter with just over $1.2 billion in cash on hand and with no debt. This was another well-executed quarter for the Skyworks team. Our content gain, our diversification and our disciplined approach -- disciplined operational focus were key factors in achieving this Q1 results. And as we look ahead, we continue to see tangible opportunities to capitalize on a number of high-level growth trends across the technology landscape. These include growing consumption of wireless data within consumer and enterprise applications, advancements and cloud-based services, the proliferation of connectivity within the emerging markets, and increasing adoption of the Internet of Things. These macro themes are irrefutable and they're far-reaching creating expanding uses of our technology and higher addressable content opportunities with each new product generation. 
Leveraging our industry-leading integration capabilities, we positioned Skyworks to capitalize on these profitable market tailwinds. Now despite these positive long-term drivers, this here the March quarter, which is normally a seasonally soft period, has been impacted by above-normal forecast reductions and inventory adjustments of one of our top customers. This dynamic has been well-documented across the supply chain over the last few weeks. After closely analyzing the market environment, we have adopted and appropriately conservative outlook for our Q2 revenue guidance. However, through strong gross margin performance and a disciplined focus on cost, the overall impact to EPS is relatively small and our guidance represents high single-digit earnings growth on the year-over-year basis. Don will provide more specific later in the call. 
It is worth emphasizing that we're well positioned for a strong second half of calendar '16 based on clear visibility into design wins across our flagship smartphone customers. And from this vantage point, we are highly confident in our prospects for gaining dollar content with an upcoming generation, putting us on track to continue delivering above-market revenue growth with expanding profit margins and earnings leverage. Before providing a more detailed view of the market, I'll turn it over now to Don for a more in-depth review of the financial results.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. Thanks for joining us, everyone. Revenue for the first quarter was $926.8 million, in line with our guidance and up 15% versus the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $476.1 million or 51.4% of revenue, ahead of guidance and up 470 basis poin
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. Thanks for joining us, everyone. Revenue for the first quarter was $926.8 million, in line with our guidance and up 15% versus the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $476.1 million or 51.4% of revenue, ahead of guidance and up 470 basis points from the quarter of fiscal 2015. Operating expenses were $109.5 million consisting of R&D expenses $71.9 million and SG&A expense of $37.6 million. We generated $366.6 million of operating income, up 30% from the year-ago quarter, translating into a 39.6% operating margin. Our cash tax rate was 15% resulting in net income of $311.2 million or $1.60 of diluted earnings per share as compared with diluted EPS of $1.26 in the year-ago quarter. That equates to a 27% year-over-year earnings growth. 
Turning to our first quarter balance sheet and cash flow statement, we invested $79.5 million in capital expenditures with depreciation of $51.5 million. We generated $345 million in cash flow from operations, which includes the $88.5 million termination fee from PMCCR and exited the quarter with over $1.2 billion in cash on hand and no debt. 
Moving to product mix. For the first quarter of fiscal 2016, power amplifiers represented 16% of revenue; integrated mobile systems was 64% and broad markets was 20%. We saw a healthy growth in both integrated mobile systems in broad markets. In fact, IMS was up a full 16 points versus a year ago as a percentage of our mix. Power amplifier products continued to decline as a percentage of our revenue as the market shifts toward higher value integrated solutions. 
Now for our second quarter business outlook. We expect second quarter revenue to be approximately $775 million. We suggest modeling gross margin in the range of 50.5% to 51% with operating expenses flat to Q1 at approximately $109.5 million. It's worth noting that the midpoint of our gross margin guidance range implies over a 400-basis-point improvement versus the prior year. Our strong gross margin outlook in the phase of current market dynamics highlights the benefits of our higher value integrated systems, along with our scale and flexible manufacturing operations. Looking ahead, we see continued optimally for margin improvement as we leverage our recent capital investment and ramp our customer integrated solutions and precision analogue products. For modeling purposes, we recommend using a 60% incremental gross margin off of the second quarter baseline. We are targeting a goal of at least 53% gross margin for the company and have a number of initiatives in place to accelerate our progress toward achieving this goal. Below the line, we anticipate $500,000 in interest and other expenses and a cash tax rate around 15%. We project our tax rate to remain at these levels for the remainder of our 2016 fiscal year. We expect share count to be around 194.5 million shares resulting in second quarter EPS of $1.24, and that's up 8% versus last year. 
Finally, we recently entered into an agreement to divest Tech, a small subsidiary of our to Kia Sarah for roughly $42 million. Transtech produce a ceramic substrates and materials for a number of broad market applications and had become a noncritical -- have become noncritical to our corporate strategy. We expect the transaction to close sometime in early April. For modeling purpose, we recommend assuming around $40 million per quarter of revenue impact starting in the June quarter with no impact to EPS. This transaction helps to improve the financial returns of our business while sharpening focus on our core strategy. Our Q2 margin and EPS guidance highlights the robustness of our business model within the context of a challenging market conditions. For the second half of calendar 2016, we see momentum building off of this baseline. Many of the drivers supporting this are already in place, giving us a high level of confidence to extend our track record of best-in-class financial results. And we remain on track toward our midterm goal of $8 in annualized EPS. And with that, I'll turn the call back over to David.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don. Before closing and taking your questions, I wanted to take a moment to reiterate a few market realities that will continue to fuel our growth for the coming years. First, demand for wireless data continues to skyrocket, with no end in sigh
componenttext: Thank you, Don. Before closing and taking your questions, I wanted to take a moment to reiterate a few market realities that will continue to fuel our growth for the coming years. First, demand for wireless data continues to skyrocket, with no end in sight driven by the adoption of streaming media and cloud-based services across consumer and enterprise applications. Now these services are in their infancy and consume a tremendous amount of bandwidth, drastically increasing demands our network and on devices. Secondly, growing data consumption requires dramatically higher levels of analogue performance at the semiconductor level. To Improve throughput, our customers are facing mounting technical challenges, including navigating spectrum limitations, improving signal reality -- reliability and mitigating interference, all while extending battery life. The end result is greater addressable content per device and TAM growth well in excess of the semiconductor sector. Third, as the technology integration leader, we are consolidating market share and our visibility to new content wins an future architectures is very strong. The solutions we're developing for future generations are tremendously complex, and they require best-in-class core technologies, advance integration capabilities and deep system-level expertise. Skyworks is uniquely positioned in all these regards to address these opportunities. This focuses -- this fosters closer engagement with customers and higher value solutions across the board, with a narrowing field of capable competitors. And fourth, the Internet of Things is real, and it's happening today, facilitating entirely new growth avenues for us and enhancing our diversification. At his year's Consumer Electronics Show, there is a showcase of groundbreaking new devices leveraging the power of wireless connectivity. Much of the excitement made at CES this year was around innovations in the connected car, in the automated home, wearable technologies and entirely new categories like drones, utilizing enabling technologies like GPS, Wi-Fi, ZigBee, Bluetooth and others. And we participated at Skyworks in all of these markets to our suite of connectivity solutions. And lastly, we've successfully redefined our business model, combining a strategic focus on higher value-added integrated solutions with unrivaled scale with advanced manufacturing capabilities and deep operational know-how. The end result is that you are consistently delivering among the best financial return in the semiconductor sector in a variety of market conditions. As just one measure of this, our return on invested capital for 2015 was 33% and over the last 2 years, we've averaged 30%. In closing, looking past the near-term volatility, wv created a unique and a robust business model fueled by the proliferation of connectivity and combining above market top-line growth, healthy cash flow and the financial returns of a best-in-class diversified company. That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, lets open the lines for questions, please.

And if you guys expect to outgrow the market, where do you have the most leverage there to take share?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think the market for smartphones, for example, is going to grow in the mid-single digits. And if -- however, if you look at the complexity, analogue and RF complexity driven by increasing band counts by higher adoption rates of AC carrier aggrega
componenttext: Well, we think the market for smartphones, for example, is going to grow in the mid-single digits. And if -- however, if you look at the complexity, analogue and RF complexity driven by increasing band counts by higher adoption rates of AC carrier aggregation and other complex switching algorithms looking to improve the signal integrity on the receive side, 2D RX technologies, high-performance, low-noise amplifiers, we think the market growth rate would be at least double that for our classic products. And of course, we look to a broadening array of vertical markets and IoT to continue to round out the business and become more diversified with higher margins.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rick, great question. Well, China is certainly a growth driver for Skyworks. We're in the early innings of a 4G upgrade cycle. And just in the last quarter, December quarter, we're up about 20% year-over-year across China. And there's been some chop
componenttext: Sure, Rick, great question. Well, China is certainly a growth driver for Skyworks. We're in the early innings of a 4G upgrade cycle. And just in the last quarter, December quarter, we're up about 20% year-over-year across China. And there's been some choppiness in the interim volatility and we understand that well, we've been in this market for quite a while. We are encouraged by the content growth and the move towards the systems illusions that we speak of. We're starting to see that with the larger Tier 1s in China and also the white-box players, and we're continuing to go beyond just the trend that receive solutions to start to move into things like Wi-Fi and GPS and power management, so that's all positive. And as we see this move to 5 more clearly, that's incremental content. So we are seeing that move up, it's really in line with the China subscribers wanting more and more functionality and more capability and that place right into our strength, so we're very positive about that expect China to be a long-term growth rate for us.

componenttext: What we do need to a high-performance filter technology, and we're refining that we're able to do very high-frequency, very tight frequency spacing with our temperature-compensated. So we also have to partners and a lot of IP this given at the capability to enter a strategic band configurations using a bulk device, coupled with the But the you mentioned carrier aggregation, but what we're really seeing is we can get the performance, for example, on the transmit path or any carrier aggregation system to go if we can drive the right topology and the right device performance, we can find that it's a little bit less dependent than 1 or many things about the actual filter technology and process that it is about the whole leaked budget, that is from the transceiver to the antenna and back. And so we're getting, I mean, some of the power-added efficiency numbers and the current consumption reductionin we're getting out of these newest generation SkyOne, skylight, PAD architectures, it really frankly unheard of in the space, and it's not all about the filters. It's much more about the device performance and the way we architect it.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then how does the TDK Qualcomm JV impacts your relationship or arrangement in outsourcing parts of TDK?
componenttext: Okay. And then how does the TDK Qualcomm JV impacts your relationship or arrangement in outsourcing parts of TDK?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we buy soft filters from TDK. We have a long-term supply agreement, that deal's not going to close for a while we're very lucky that we have a big footprint now in filters, and so we can build our own sauce and our own TC sauce. We'll see how that p
componenttext: Well, we buy soft filters from TDK. We have a long-term supply agreement, that deal's not going to close for a while we're very lucky that we have a big footprint now in filters, and so we can build our own sauce and our own TC sauce. We'll see how that plays out ad-libbing it has anything material impact on supply at all and in fact, it's been on our road map particularly when you look at RF technology, which is a lot of filters, lot of passes. It's always been in on our roadmap for margins, frankly, for margin as well as performance to pull that technology more and more in-house. So we can pull it in if we have to, and it really will be to played out over time, but I would worry about it from a supply constraint.

componenttext: David, on the same points. Just getting glimpse your capacity in Panasonic, own salt then you guys over motor to see, but it's outset you go back fairly in capacity and then Qualcomm has been making a lot of this JV, but can you just refresh our memory before JV announced. When you're seeing Qualcomm the cup competitions for any of the RF and in any of the major players they're doing all 360 for like 3 years now. And so I just want to get a kind of snapshot before we lose our minds on the JV and what was going on the Qualcomm before then. And then Don, the 6% incremental gross margins, what's the primary driver that you're going to need to get there? What's driving that and the 53% [ph] target margin, the primary driver there, is it a higher mix of integrated products or is it just throughput? headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So with respect to the first half of the question, I think you're absolutely right. The TDK and Qualcomm have been working closely together in building designs for a long time. We've competed very successfully against those designs, there hasn't been a lo
componenttext: So with respect to the first half of the question, I think you're absolutely right. The TDK and Qualcomm have been working closely together in building designs for a long time. We've competed very successfully against those designs, there hasn't been a lot of traction in the sweet spot of what we do. There've been other RF 360 components of that system, in which we don't compete with and that success. But these decades of and I performance and driving switch technologies and multi-chip margin technology and getting to put our own high-performance filters has really given us a system-level performance that has not been easy for competition to replicate. We know TDK very well. We've used them in the past, they're mostly saw they've got some limited capabilities involved but remember, I think, as your question alluded to, our customers awarding business based purely performance, and on configurability and what it does at the system level. And we have a clear advantage of the system level over anybody. We've not seen the combination of Qualcomm TDK to be any meaningful threat over the last 3 years.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the margins. The modeling, we suggested the 60% and the target is 53% and a 51% for this quarter. We're obviously feel good about, we're well on our way. We've had some nice gains and consecutive quarters, and it's really a lot of things. You're ri
componenttext: And on the margins. The modeling, we suggested the 60% and the target is 53% and a 51% for this quarter. We're obviously feel good about, we're well on our way. We've had some nice gains and consecutive quarters, and it's really a lot of things. You're right, one of the things is the overall suite of new products we released because it's more integration more value for the customer, we're just seeing better margins on that. So that's mix, but it's not mix, it's real value-added integrated solutions, and that's really helping. And it's the things we do on CapEx, it's the things we do on driving productivity improvements through the fab, through the assembly test, operation makes it. We've driven filter cost down dramatically so we're executing as we have for a long time pretty well across all fronts and they're all contributing to the margin story. As far as capacity, we're in really good shape. We've got square footage on a new leased facility in Mexicali. So it's short money for equipment. We can expand that very, very quickly that pays back quickly. Dave already talked about quadrupling the filter capacity as far as square footage and Japan, so with equipment again, we can do that very quickly. And we've got our outsource partners for a wafer. So we're a really good shape to be able to expand capacity when it's required.

componenttext: Just 2 quick ones if I could. You've covered china pretty well. I'm wondering if you could just talk a little bit about what you're seeing or what your customers are saying about some of the other emerging markets right now? And then back to Qualcomm, obviously, they haven't -- as you talked about, they haven't had a lot of success. They are talking about now a little bit more aggressively about Marson, and so from a competitive landscape, do you think that can change anything. And, I guess, for topic, anything else from anyone in the CMOS camp?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Maybe I'll do the second half first for the other emerging markets. Tim, it really is the case that there hasn't been a single successful new PA company in many, many years, the PA device technology. And the merchant gas foundries are, I would estim
componenttext: Sure. Maybe I'll do the second half first for the other emerging markets. Tim, it really is the case that there hasn't been a single successful new PA company in many, many years, the PA device technology. And the merchant gas foundries are, I would estimate at least 5 years behind what Skyworks is able to do today state-of-the-art at the device level. And it's been through decades of experience. So I think that the merchant gas market, merchant gas capability fails in comparison to the stellar device performance that companies like Skyworks and we specifically are getting. So I'm not too worried about any new gas and trend, and I'm definitely not worried about seeing CMOS technology being able to accomplish the kind of current consumption, the kind of transmit requirements that we're seeing across our markets today. Every single time there is an advanced in a different technology or with a different competitor, what we're finding is that the next generation system has increased the bar so high that it doesn't matter, that improvement isn't anywhere near capable of delivering the system-level performance that our customer's requiring. We are designing our platforms now that in 2018. And those platforms, I tell you, it is the best of the best that we'll go to complete successfully and we think we've got a unique capability there.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then following up on the emerging markets, and then what we do see there is certainly our global brand participate across the emerging markets, but more frequently, we see some of the China players drive a great deal of their exports through markets l
componenttext: And then following up on the emerging markets, and then what we do see there is certainly our global brand participate across the emerging markets, but more frequently, we see some of the China players drive a great deal of their exports through markets like India, Middle East, Latin America. Of those, the India market is actually been consuming probably at the highest level again buying product typically manufactured by our China OEMs, and we play into that channel. And there's definitely a lot of room to grow in that geography.

componenttext: And just on the broad market segment, clearly a number of driver of that business segment, but maybe you could highlight for us 1 or 2 applications that you think can contribute the most from dollar revenue growth perspective as you look out over the next few quarters?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. The broad markets business has been doing quite well, up about 12% year-over-year in Q1, and we'll continue to be at team's level or higher growth rate into the calendar year. So, I mean, we're seeing is really a wide variety of applications i
componenttext: Sure, sure. The broad markets business has been doing quite well, up about 12% year-over-year in Q1, and we'll continue to be at team's level or higher growth rate into the calendar year. So, I mean, we're seeing is really a wide variety of applications in the broad portfolio. We've got some great IoT programs that go into a set-top box and streaming media, in many cases $10 to $12 per box Wi-Fi switching, ZigBee technology. There's Connected Home opportunity now that's really playing, got some great content there. And one of the markets that we're is excited about now, it's early innings, but we are seeing some uptake in automotive. We're starting to see high-end LTE telematics applications. We've got design wins in vehicle-to-vehicle communication. We've got customers like GM, like Volkswagen, Continental, so that's a market that we think we'll do very well for several years and the opportunity there for us is outstanding. So that's a little color on where we are, but broad is has been growing quite well and quite steady.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, thanks for the question, Greg. Despite the backdrop right now, when you look at the model for us is absolutely intact. componenttext: And then a follow-up just on gross margin, Don. componenttext: That's a fair question, but you got to remember that those are averages to assume over period. There are events that happen quarter-to-quarter that can move those. And what happened in those quarters are a multiple things we were seeing some benefit from the filter assets and driving cost down, we had new product launches, all of those things can create a short-term step function that moves you in a different spots. That sustaining 75% just that off the charts. 60 is very, very good. So modeling 60, you'll see get a very, very good answer.

componenttext: Great. And then as far as filters just for us as, I think, you talked last call about 2017 getting there, how necessary is that? And as we push into a higher frequency stuff later years, is it -- is it the right technology where we have to see some other technology emerge in filter to handle that?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question. Clearly, for today, we're doing low-band and now mid-band. We're well above 2 gigahertz with great performance using temperature-compensated devices. I think, technology, what it will do for us in that '17 timeframe will open up the
componenttext: It's a great question. Clearly, for today, we're doing low-band and now mid-band. We're well above 2 gigahertz with great performance using temperature-compensated devices. I think, technology, what it will do for us in that '17 timeframe will open up the high band, the very highest band in some of these back configurations. I think, that'll be very good for us. We'll be able to have the enviable trade-off between using saw temperature-compensated in bulk devices in using the right application for the function because if you look across the world today, you know most world phones, most smartphones don't use broad technologies. They have a different configuration or a different band line-up that doesn't require it. But for those customers who are looking for sort of a low mid-high, very high-performance, truly a world phone, what quality will do will open up high band for us, in which we don't participate, market we don't participate in today. So to increase our TAM and we'll get there by '17.

componenttext: Maybe just following up on that for Williams as well. With your filtered capacity, capacity, is there a way to quantify some of the dollar content increases that you're able to attack today that may weren't able to get into a couple of years ago knowing that so much of the RF content increases is coming on the filter side?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that the increase over the last couple of years until the next couple of years on the RF side and smartphones are global, it's probably equally weighted between filter-enabled devices, receive and transmit, and other functionality that we
componenttext: Yes, I would say that the increase over the last couple of years until the next couple of years on the RF side and smartphones are global, it's probably equally weighted between filter-enabled devices, receive and transmit, and other functionality that we talked about, which is voltage regulation, power management, receive technology and higher performance Wi-Fi and the like. So I'm going to just go and brush and tell you roughly equal growth within mobile coming about the filter label solutions and coming about through other system level locks that we didn't previously address.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to add to that, I think, one of the real unique characteristics of what we do here and we talked about in this call is our ability to integrate. So it isn't just taking filter and taking the amplifier or integrating it. There's a lot of unique Skywork
componenttext: And to add to that, I think, one of the real unique characteristics of what we do here and we talked about in this call is our ability to integrate. So it isn't just taking filter and taking the amplifier or integrating it. There's a lot of unique Skyworks DNA that develops these engines. They're highly customizable, each based upon partner, each OEM, we configured to their needs, we look at their current budget, we look at what they need to do in terms of bands, we look at the filter technology wanted to deploy and all that comes together, and it's worth the TC capabilities that we have today are unbelievable, they're world-class, world manufacturer. In this last calendar year, we manufactured about 1.5 billion TC [indiscernible], all of which were consumed by our integrated system. So we're very bullish on that concept and we'll continue to use the best technologies to win.

componenttext: Yes, I think, what we've done in the past, we're always looking for -- if you think about our power management acquisition that we did to AATI or PsyD or the Panasonic filter capability, they all did 2 things for us. They gave us a much bigger target and more relevance to the system performance level for our both customers, so they also opened up new target markets that gave us opportunities within in IOT. So we would continue to look at that, whether it's cloud-based computing, whether it's machine-to-machine, whether it's being able to do more at the kind of IOT sensor, MCU RF module capability, we see those as being attractive, surgical, strategic, accretive deals.

componenttext: Just wanted to get into the broad markets a little bit, 20% of the revenue, around $185 million came from IOT broad markets. componenttext: Sure. Yes, the broad market business is actually quite diversified. I would say the strongest elements are around kind of the streaming media, the Wi-Fi integration, Connected Home, we have just a large roster of design wins in that part of the space. And we're also seeing and if you look at some tear down to these boxes you're seeing a 3 by 3 streams, which will triple content, and so you've got $10 to $12 per box we're in markets like DirecTV, Technicolor, some of the Netgear routers those are just examples. So that's a real strong area and there's a lot of upgrades to go here in the U.S. and in developing market, so we like that. Connected Home, I mentioned, some of these appliance opportunities, customers like Nest, and lots of names like that. Automotive, relatively new, we have not only the traditional IOT applications like Wi-Fi and Bluetooth, but you have a telematics play. And then others space that has been a bit quiet, but we do think will turn is one the infrastructure. Your great deal of content for companies like Nokia, Siemens, Ericsson, Huawei, and we do see that getting a little stronger will probably back half of 2016, a little bit soft so far, but it's another market where we have some solid designs.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, and welcome to Skyworks Solutions' First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Steve Ferranti, Vice President of Investor Relations for Skywork
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, and welcome to Skyworks Solutions' First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Steve Ferranti, Vice President of Investor Relations for Skyworks. Mr. Ferranti, please go ahead.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks first fiscal quarter 2016 conference call. Joining me today are Dave Aldrich, Don Palette and Liam Griffin. Dave will begin today's call with the business overview, followed by Don's fina
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks first fiscal quarter 2016 conference call. Joining me today are Dave Aldrich, Don Palette and Liam Griffin. Dave will begin today's call with the business overview, followed by Don's financial review and outlook. We will then open the lines for your questions.
Please note that our comments today will include statements relating to future results that are forward-looking as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially and adversely from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, those noted in our earnings release and those detailed from time to time in our SEC filings.
I would also like to remind everyone that the results and guidance we will discuss today are from our non-GAAP income statement, consistent with the format we've used in the past. Please refer to our press release within the Investor Relations section of our company website for a complete reconciliation to GAAP. With that, I will turn the call over to Dave for his comments on the quarter.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and welcome, everyone. We had a solid first quarter performance with revenue profitability and earnings ahead of expectations in spite of the challenging macro environment. Specifically during the quarter, we delivered revenue of $927 milli
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and welcome, everyone. We had a solid first quarter performance with revenue profitability and earnings ahead of expectations in spite of the challenging macro environment. Specifically during the quarter, we delivered revenue of $927 million, that's up 15% year-over-year. We produced operating income of $367 million, that's up 30% year-over-year, translating into a 39.6% operating margin. And we posted $1.60 in earnings per share that's up 27% versus the prior year. We also generated more than $345 million in operating cash flow and ended the quarter with just over $1.2 billion in cash on hand and with no debt. This was another well-executed quarter from the Skyworks team. Our content gain, our diversification and our disciplined approach -- disciplined operational focus were key factors in achieving this Q1 results. And as we look ahead, we continue to see tangible opportunities to capitalize on a number of high-level growth trends across the technology landscape. These include growing consumption of wireless data within consumer and enterprise applications, advancements and cloud-based services, the proliferation of connectivity within the emerging markets, and increasing adoption of the Internet of Things. These macro themes are irrefutable and they're far-reaching, creating expanding uses of our technology and higher addressable content opportunities with each new product generation.
Leveraging our industry-leading integration capabilities, we positioned Skyworks to capitalize on these profitable market tailwinds. Now despite these positive long-term drivers, this year the March quarter, which is normally a seasonally soft period, has been impacted by above-normal forecast reductions and inventory adjustments at one of our top customers. This dynamic has been well-documented across the supply chain over the last few weeks. After closely analyzing the market environment, we have adopted and appropriately conservative outlook for our Q2 revenue guidance. However, through strong gross margin performance and a disciplined focus on cost, the overall impact to EPS is relatively small and our guidance represent high single digit earnings growth on a year-over-year basis. Don will provide more specific later in the call. 
It is worth emphasizing that we're well positioned for a strong second half of calendar '16, based on clear visibility into design wins across our flagship smartphone customers. And from this vantage point, we are highly confident in our prospects for gaining dollar content with an upcoming generation, putting us on track to continue delivering above-market revenue growth with expanding profit margins and earnings leverage. Before providing a more detailed view of the market, I'll turn it over now to Don for a more in-depth review of the financial results.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. Thanks for joining us, everyone. Revenue for the first quarter was $926.8 million, in line with our guidance and up 15% versus the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $476.1 million or 51.4% of revenue, ahead of guidance and up 470 basis poin
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. Thanks for joining us, everyone. Revenue for the first quarter was $926.8 million, in line with our guidance and up 15% versus the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $476.1 million or 51.4% of revenue, ahead of guidance and up 470 basis points from the quarter of fiscal 2015. Operating expenses were $109.5 million consisting of R&D expenses $71.9 million and SG&A expense of $37.6 million. We generated $366.6 million of operating income, up 30% from the year-ago quarter, translating into a 39.6% operating margin. Our cash tax rate was 15% resulting in net income of $311.2 million or $1.60 of diluted earnings per share as compared with diluted EPS of $1.26 in the year-ago quarter. That equates to a 27% year-over-year earnings growth.
Turning to our first quarter balance sheet and cash flow statement, we invested $79.5 million in capital expenditures with depreciation of $51.5 million. We generated $345 million in cash flow from operations, which includes the $88.5 million termination fee from PMCCR, and exited the quarter with over $1.2 billion in cash on hand and no debt.
Moving to product mix. For the first quarter of fiscal 2016, power amplifiers represented 16% of revenue; integrated mobile systems was 64% and broad markets was 20%. We saw a healthy growth in both integrated mobile systems in broad markets. In fact, IMS was up a full 16 points versus a year ago as a percentage of our mix. Power amplifier products continued to decline as a percentage of our revenue as the market shifts toward higher-value integrated solutions.
Now for our second quarter business outlook. We expect second quarter revenue to be approximately $775 million. We suggest modeling gross margin in the range of 50.5% to 51% with operating expenses flat to Q1 at approximately $109.5 million. It's worth noting that the midpoint of our gross margin guidance range implies over a 400-basis-point improvement versus the prior year. Our strong gross margin outlook in the phase of current market dynamics highlight the benefits of our higher-value integrated systems, along with our scale and flexible manufacturing operations. Looking ahead, we see continued optimally for margin improvement as we leverage our recent capital investments and ramp our custom integrated solutions and precision analogue products. For modeling purposes, we recommend using a 60% incremental gross margin off of the second quarter baseline. We are targeting a goal of at least 53% gross margin for the company and have a number of initiatives in place to accelerate our progress toward achieving this goal. Below the line, we anticipate $500,000 in interest and other expenses and a cash tax rate around 15%. We project our tax rate to remain at these levels for the remainder of our 2016 fiscal year. We expect share count to be around 194.5 million shares resulting in second quarter EPS of $1.24, and that's up 8% versus last year.
Finally, we recently entered into an agreement to divest Trans-Tech, a small subsidiary of ours, to Kyocera for roughly $42 million. Trans-Tech produces ceramic substrates and materials for a number of broad market applications and had become a noncritical -- have become noncritical to our corporate strategy. We expect the transaction to close sometime in early April. For modeling purpose, we recommend assuming around $40 million per quarter of revenue impact starting in the June quarter with no impact to EPS. This transaction helps to improve the financial returns of our business while sharpening focus on our core strategy. Our Q2 margin and EPS guidance highlights the robustness of our business model within the context of a challenging market conditions. For the second half of calendar 2016, we see momentum building off of this baseline. Many of the drivers supporting this are already in place, giving us a high level of confidence to extend our track record of best-in-class financial results. And we remain on track toward our midterm goal of $8 in annualized EPS. And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Dave.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don. Before closing and taking your questions, I wanted to take a moment to reiterate a few market realities that will continue to fuel our growth in the coming years. First, demand for wireless data continues to skyrocket, with no end in sight
componenttext:
Thank you, Don. Before closing and taking your questions, I wanted to take a moment to reiterate a few market realities that will continue to fuel our growth in the coming years. First, demand for wireless data continues to skyrocket, with no end in sight, driven by the adoption of streaming media and cloud-based services across consumer and enterprise applications. Now these services are in their infancy and consume a tremendous amount of bandwidth, drastically increasing demands on network and on devices. Secondly, growing data consumption requires dramatically higher levels of analogue performance at the semiconductor level. To improve throughput, our customers are facing mounting technical challenges, including navigating spectrum limitations, improving signal reality -- reliability and mitigating interference, all while extending battery life. The end result is greater addressable content per device and TAM growth well in excess of the semiconductor sector. Third, as a technology integration leader, we are consolidating market share and our visibility to new content wins and future architectures is very strong. The solutions we're developing for future generations are tremendously complex, and they require best-in-class core technologies, advanced integration capabilities and deep system-level expertise. Skyworks is uniquely positioned in all these regards to address these opportunities. This focuses -- this fosters closer engagement with customers and higher-value solutions across the board, with a narrowing field of capable competitors. And fourth, the Internet of Things is real, and it's happening today, facilitating entirely new growth avenues for us and enhancing our diversification. At this year's Consumer Electronics Show, there was a showcase of groundbreaking new devices leveraging the power of wireless connectivity. Much of the excitement at CES this year was around innovations in the connected car, in the automated home, wearable technologies and entirely new categories like drones, utilizing enabling technologies like GPS, Wi-Fi, ZigBee, Bluetooth and others. And we participated at Skyworks in all of these markets to our suite of connectivity solutions. And lastly, we've successfully redefined our business model, combining a strategic focus on higher value-added integrated solutions with unrivaled scale with advanced manufacturing capabilities and deep operational knowhow. The end result is that we are consistently delivering among the best financial returns in the semiconductor sector in a variety of market conditions. As just one measure of this, our return on invested capital for 2015 was 33% and over the last 2 years, we've averaged 30%.
In closing, looking past the near-term volatility, we've created a unique and a robust business model fueled by the proliferation of connectivity and combining above-market top-line growth, healthy cash flow and the financial returns of a best-in-class diversified analogue company.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, lets open the lines for questions, please.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Rick Schafer with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Rick Schafer with Oppenheimer.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to give my congratulations for reacting so quickly to that change on the top line there, preserving EPS. My first question is just really what are your expectations, I guess, for the overall RF content growth for the overall market over the next
componenttext: Just want to give my congratulations for reacting so quickly to that change on the top line there, preserving EPS. My first question is just really what are your expectations, I guess, for the overall RF content growth for the overall market over the next couple of years? And if you guys expect to outgrow the market, where do you have the most leverage there to take share?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think the market for smartphones, for example, is going to grow in the mid-single digits. And if -- however, if you look at the complexity, analogue and RF complexity driven by increasing band counts by higher adoption rates of AC carrier aggrega
componenttext: Well, we think the market for smartphones, for example, is going to grow in the mid-single digits. And if -- however, if you look at the complexity, analogue and RF complexity driven by increasing band counts by higher adoption rates of AC carrier aggregation and other complex switching algorithms looking to improve the signal integrity on the receive side, 2D RX technologies, high-performance, low-noise amplifiers, we think the market growth rate would be at least double that for our classic products. And of course, we look to a broadening array of vertical markets and IoT to continue to round out the business and become more diversified with higher margins.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then a follow-up to that. Can you discuss content trends that you're seeing with the China -- Chinese handset OEMs and maybe put in context how that growth there compares with what you're seeing with -- from the Tier 1 guys, maybe in Korea, Nort
componenttext: Okay, and then a follow-up to that. Can you discuss content trends that you're seeing with the China -- Chinese handset OEMs and maybe put in context how that growth there compares with what you're seeing with -- from the Tier 1 guys, maybe in Korea, North America wherever? And maybe part of that answer I'm curious, what your expected -- what do you expect to see in terms of the impact from the move to 5 mode -- the 5-mode rollout in China?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rick, great question. Well, China is certainly a growth driver for Skyworks. So we're in the early innings of a 4G upgrade cycle. And just in the last quarter, December quarter, we're up about 20% year-over-year across China. And there's been some c
componenttext: Sure, Rick, great question. Well, China is certainly a growth driver for Skyworks. So we're in the early innings of a 4G upgrade cycle. And just in the last quarter, December quarter, we're up about 20% year-over-year across China. And there's been some choppiness and interim volatility and we understand that well, we've been in this market for quite a while. We are encouraged by the content growth and the move towards the systems illusions that we speak of. We're starting to see that with the larger Tier 1s in China and also the white-box players, and we're continuing to go beyond just the trend that receive solutions to start to move into things like Wi-Fi and GPS and power management, so that's all positive. And as we see this move to 5 more clearly, that's incremental content. So we are seeing that move up, it's really in line with the China subscribers wanting more and more functionality and more capability and that plays right into our strength. So we're very positive about that and expect China to be a long-term grower for us.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Dave, beyond the sort of well-advertised slowdown or inventory adjustment at your largest customer, what has been the trends at your Korean and your Chinese customers? I think they're all trying to assess whether this was a 1-quarter problem for your industry? Or whether there are any other longer-term impacts. If you could give us some insights into that, I think, that will be very useful for investors?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as Liam commented a moment ago, Vivek, the China TAM story and the upgrade to 4G has been very positive for the company. And in fact, I think, we were something like 20% year-over-year growth in our China revenue in the December quarter. An
componenttext: Well, I think, as Liam commented a moment ago, Vivek, the China TAM story and the upgrade to 4G has been very positive for the company. And in fact, I think, we were something like 20% year-over-year growth in our China revenue in the December quarter. And that's content, that share, that's being lined out with the right set of baseband and SoC partners. And if you look at our customer Samsung, our second largest customer, we've seen very high attach rate now with a more complex solutions, on the Galaxy 7 on them, and the emerging 16 platforms. And the fact of matter is our China customers and Samsung, they're all adopting virtually across the board a more complex system, RF system, that's highly integrated for size, for current consumption and just to merely handle the complexity and get these designs can, these SKUs out into the market on time. And that's been very, very good for us, very bad for the discrete companies. Very, very good for us.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then one more sort of near-term question. If you could discuss sort of the puts and takes for the June quarter because your largest customer still has some seasonal headwinds during that quarter, I think, you also mentioned divestiture. I beli
componenttext: Got it. And then one more sort of near-term question. If you could discuss sort of the puts and takes for the June quarter because your largest customer still has some seasonal headwinds during that quarter, I think, you also mentioned divestiture. I believe, Don, you mentioned that it could have $14 million impacts. So if you could just run us through the puts and takes to how to think conceptually about the June quarter?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's obviously -- we're monitoring the demand environment in China and elsewhere very closely. And the ramp timing of large programs which are participating in increasing content. Generally, June is up somewhat from March. That's our current expecta
componenttext: Well, it's obviously -- we're monitoring the demand environment in China and elsewhere very closely. And the ramp timing of large programs which are participating in increasing content. Generally, June is up somewhat from March. That's our current expectation, although it's little early. However, the visibility in new designs and in new platforms, both in terms of flagship but also some of our IOT platforms, gives us a very keen sense that the second half of calendar '16 will be very strong and the growth rate will be very high. After we work through obviously, as you said, the well-publicized issue and inventory burn with a large customer. Maybe, Don, you could comment on the TTI transaction?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Vivek, so the way to think about it is when we're doing our models, you look at the business as it is today and assign appropriate growth rates throughout the fiscal period. And then off of that, you would just deduct $14 million a quarter for the J
componenttext: Sure. Vivek, so the way to think about it is when we're doing our models, you look at the business as it is today and assign appropriate growth rates throughout the fiscal period. And then off of that, you would just deduct $14 million a quarter for the June and September quarter and beyond as you're starting at that point. And there's no earnings impact with that $14 million. So it's a much lower margin business for us, and then that's offset by their OpEx. So there's no earnings associated with that.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the China side. We did -- while we did [indiscernible] top customers, it did seem the Chinese handset OEMs rebounded pretty nicely in the December quarter and ramping into Chinese New Year, so I'm just wondering if that's affected you
componenttext: Just following up on the China side. We did -- while we did [indiscernible] top customers, it did seem the Chinese handset OEMs rebounded pretty nicely in the December quarter and ramping into Chinese New Year, so I'm just wondering if that's affected your customer mix. If you could give us an update on how big China is as a percent. And do you expect that to grow into the March quarter, and then also we've heard a lot about India last night from your partner competitor, I'm curious what your exposure is out there and the outlook?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Mike. With respect to China as we've spoken, it's a very diverse set of customers. It's not just mobile, we do a great deal of business in IoT markets, Wi-Fi and even infrastructure, But we are seeing within China names like Huawei really accel
componenttext: Yes, sure, Mike. With respect to China as we've spoken, it's a very diverse set of customers. It's not just mobile, we do a great deal of business in IoT markets, Wi-Fi and even infrastructure, But we are seeing within China names like Huawei really accelerate, Xiaomi to some degree and some of the other lightbox players and if you take the China Mobile businesses as well as our broad market and China is about 20% of our revenue at Skyworks. So we do see them coming up this quarter, again, in March sequentially, so they're going to be one of the drivers for us in the March quarter. And again, throughout the year as we mentioned before, it was just a tremendous opportunity with the 2G and 3G customers and subscribers moving up into 4G. So we're encouraged by that but you're going to see some improvement in China in the March quarter following a strong December.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then for Don, if I could spin the OpEx, your job on the gross margin, but how should we think about puts and takes for OpEx going forward after -- into this next calendar year? And then also just any thoughts on cash. Obviously, it's -- given th
componenttext: Okay, and then for Don, if I could spin the OpEx, your job on the gross margin, but how should we think about puts and takes for OpEx going forward after -- into this next calendar year? And then also just any thoughts on cash. Obviously, it's -- given the macro environment uncertainty, was your plan really to get more aggressive on the buyback or would you still be looking at some fairly large acquisitions?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the OpEx side, we said in the prepared remarks that we see $109.5 million kind of level for the next several fiscal quarters. After that, modeling up a couple of million a quarter, as we've talked 2 to 3, as we've talked about before I think is safe. B
componenttext: On the OpEx side, we said in the prepared remarks that we see $109.5 million kind of level for the next several fiscal quarters. After that, modeling up a couple of million a quarter, as we've talked 2 to 3, as we've talked about before I think is safe. But as far as the cash, yes, we continue to generate very strong cash of the earnings. We have at 40% target a free cash flow that we wanted to distribute to the shareholders through dividends buybacks. We didn't do any buyback this quarter, I mean, we also balanced it about what's going on in potentially M&A activity what we're looking at and those things. And bottom line is at 40% we'll continue to do. So stay tuned.
