headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we spent $80 million in the first fiscal quarter. We would expect that to come down closer to more like -- we don't really guide it, but more like the depreciation level, appreciation generally in the high 40s to 50 kind of a level. So it is coming d
componenttext: Yes, we spent $80 million in the first fiscal quarter. We would expect that to come down closer to more like -- we don't really guide it, but more like the depreciation level, appreciation generally in the high 40s to 50 kind of a level. So it is coming down in some of that. When we're spending capital to direct results of the volumes that we're looking at, sort of the backdrop right now, that number is going to be able to come down a little bit. The use of cash as we said, we like the 40% targeted for our shareholders and that will be through dividend and buybacks. We'll continue to focus on doing that.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Blayne with respect to filters in the last few quarters as we've discussed on each call, we've dramatically increased our footprint in Japan and again processing in Singapore. We are probably roughly quadrupled the capability from a facility standpoin
componenttext: And Blayne with respect to filters in the last few quarters as we've discussed on each call, we've dramatically increased our footprint in Japan and again processing in Singapore. We are probably roughly quadrupled the capability from a facility standpoint. We're hiring, we're getting very good performance at the RF levels as well as yields, and so we continue to see advantages in using really the highest performance temperature-compensated service device in the world, and we are starting to see more bands at higher frequencies that are capable of using PCs. So obviously, we could see real performance and cost advantage, both on the transmit and the receive side. So I think you should look for us to continue to line out modules, SkyOne, and other types of products of power amplified duplexers more and more of our internal devices as well as our receive DRX with temperature-compensated SAW for better receive performance.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up, as you look out this year, you talked about content gains, your large smartphone customers. Can you maybe just talk about where -- what types of products you're seeing the best traction for content gain? That will be helpful.
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up, as you look out this year, you talked about content gains, your large smartphone customers. Can you maybe just talk about where -- what types of products you're seeing the best traction for content gain? That will be helpful.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Blayne. With regard to large flagship programs, in general, what you're seeing as Dave articulated, more and more adoption of our SkyOne still to rich multiple bands -- multiple power amplifier band switching integrated in a trasmit section. Coupled
componenttext: Sure, Blayne. With regard to large flagship programs, in general, what you're seeing as Dave articulated, more and more adoption of our SkyOne still to rich multiple bands -- multiple power amplifier band switching integrated in a trasmit section. Coupled with that, we're doing really good work on the receive chain with these DRX solutions and look at LNA against switching, against filtering integrating in with single engine. And then to augment that, we're really seeing great traction in our 11ac portfolio, often in MIMO, [indiscernible] 2 for smartphone. Now we're seeing power management devices and Bluetooth connectivity, et cetera. So we're really rounding out this analogue content around very rich filter-integrated system. So that's what you will see in the flagship phones and we're starting to see our value to your customers even move up in that area.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Harsh Kumar with Stephens.
componenttext: We'll go next to Harsh Kumar with Stephens.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on your content in the Chinese handset guys versus the Tier 1 and what opportunity do you see as the Chinese handset guys try to move up and match sort of what the Tier 1 guys are up?
componenttext: Question on your content in the Chinese handset guys versus the Tier 1 and what opportunity do you see as the Chinese handset guys try to move up and match sort of what the Tier 1 guys are up?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, that the upgrade cycle in China is the largest content gain in the history of the company, because the volumes are so very high and the embedded base there of 2G and 3G has relatively low content for us. And now as the world is adopting these mor
componenttext: I think, that the upgrade cycle in China is the largest content gain in the history of the company, because the volumes are so very high and the embedded base there of 2G and 3G has relatively low content for us. And now as the world is adopting these more integrated system solutions for all the sort of well-publicized, performance-size cost just a reality of how do you deal with the complexity when you're a customer with other things to worry about in the RF portion. So we continue to see a great deal of content gain and frankly, share consolidation, and it is turning into a big scale advantage to have the breadth of content as well as the cost structure around high volume. So I think you'll continue to see that.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up, a couple of companies such as Avago and others talk about content growing above 15%. I know you guys are somewhere in there. Most of you guys talk about greater than 10%. I'm curious what's the latest greatest standpoint is with r
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, a couple of companies such as Avago and others talk about content growing above 15%. I know you guys are somewhere in there. Most of you guys talk about greater than 10%. I'm curious what's the latest greatest standpoint is with respect to how you guys see content growth for smartphones?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would echo what you've stated. I think the content's growth is every bit of kind of a low mid-teens and could be high. We have to decouple. The true content growth is driven by complexity, which everybody talks about. There's more bands, there's more hi
componenttext: I would echo what you've stated. I think the content's growth is every bit of kind of a low mid-teens and could be high. We have to decouple. The true content growth is driven by complexity, which everybody talks about. There's more bands, there's more high-frequency bands, there's more complexity around delivering, as Liam mentioned, MIMO-based solutions on the receive side. Powered voltage is becoming an increasing issue. Of course, you remember we did an acquisition that gives us some unique IP around driving more refined voltage through the transmit path. And that's real advantage in our system solutions that can be replicated by an RF-only company. So we continue to see that as a real differential advantage for Skyworks.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Atif Malik with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll go next to Atif Malik with Citigroup.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations in strong execution. Dave, can you just talk about your strategy on filters. Do you need above solution for carrier aggregation opportunity which is kicking off this year, and then I will follow up?
componenttext: Congratulations in strong execution. Dave, can you just talk about your strategy on filters. Do you need above solution for carrier aggregation opportunity which is kicking off this year, and then I will follow up?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we do need a high-performance filter technology. And we're refining that we're able to do very high-frequency, very tight frequency spacing with our temperature-compensated SAW. We also have [indiscernible] filter partners and a lot of IP that's givi
componenttext: What we do need a high-performance filter technology. And we're refining that we're able to do very high-frequency, very tight frequency spacing with our temperature-compensated SAW. We also have [indiscernible] filter partners and a lot of IP that's giving us the capability to enter in strategic band configurations using a bulk device, coupled with a temperature-compensated -- coupled with a SAW. But you know -- I mentioned carrier aggregation, but what we're really seeing is we can get the performance, for example, on the transmit path or any carrier aggregation system. If we can drive the right topology and the right device performance, we find that it's a little bit less dependent than one normally thinks about the actual filter technology and process that it is about the whole linked budget, that is from the transceiver to the antenna and back. And so we're getting, I mean, some of the power-added efficiency numbers and the current consumption reduction we're getting out of these newest generation SkyOne, skylight, PAD architectures, it really frankly unheard of in the space. And it's not all about the filters, it's much more about the device performance and the way we architect it.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then how does the TDK Qualcomm JV impacts your relationship or arrangement in outsourcing parts of TDK?
componenttext: Okay. And then how does the TDK Qualcomm JV impacts your relationship or arrangement in outsourcing parts of TDK?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we buy soft filters from TDK. We have a long-term supply agreement. That deal is not going to close for a while. We're very lucky that we have a big footprint now in filters, and so we can build our own SAWs and our own TCs. We'll see how that plays
componenttext: Well, we buy soft filters from TDK. We have a long-term supply agreement. That deal is not going to close for a while. We're very lucky that we have a big footprint now in filters, and so we can build our own SAWs and our own TCs. We'll see how that plays out. But I don't think it has any material impact on supply at all and in fact, it's been on our road map, particularly when you look at the RF technology, which has a lot of filters, lot of passes. It's always been on our roadmap for margins, frankly, for margin as well as performance to pull that technology more and more in-house. So we can pull in if we have to, and it really will be -- will play out over time, but I wouldn't worry about it from a supply constraint.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Edward Snyder with Charter Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Edward Snyder with Charter Equity Research.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are kind of on the same point. You're just getting glimpse of your capacity in Panasonic. They used to build their own SAW, then you guys converted the motor to TC, but it sounds like you can go back fairly easy if you had the capacity and then Qualcom
componenttext: We are kind of on the same point. You're just getting glimpse of your capacity in Panasonic. They used to build their own SAW, then you guys converted the motor to TC, but it sounds like you can go back fairly easy if you had the capacity and then Qualcomm has been making a lot of this JV, but can you just refresh our memory before the JV was announced? When you're seeing Qualcomm in the competitions for any of the RF and any of the major players. They're not even doing all 360 for like 3 years now. And so I just want to get a kind of snapshot before we lose our minds on the JV and what was going on with Qualcomm and before then. And then Don, the 6% incremental gross margins, what's the primary driver that you're going to need to get there? What's driving that? In the 53% target margin, the primary driver there, is it a higher mix of integrated products or is it just throughput? And then if you could maybe give us an update on the gas capacity? And most importantly your packaging assembly test capacity in Mexico?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a long question, Ed. Thank you.
componenttext: That's a long question, Ed. Thank you.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, that's -- yes. So with respect to the first half of the question, I think you're absolutely right. The TDK and Qualcomm have been working closely together in fielding designs for a long time. We've competed very successfully against those designs, so
componenttext: Ed, that's -- yes. So with respect to the first half of the question, I think you're absolutely right. The TDK and Qualcomm have been working closely together in fielding designs for a long time. We've competed very successfully against those designs, so there hasn't been a lot of traction in the sweet spot of what we do. There've been other RF360 components of that system in which we don't compete, where they've had success. But these decades of gallium arsenide performance and driving switch technologies and multi-chip module technology and getting to put our own high-performance filters has really given us a system-level performance that has not been easy for competition to replicate. We know TDK very well. We've used them in the past. They mostly saw they've got some limited capability involved, but remember, I think, as your question alluded to, our customers are awarding business based purely on performance and on configurability and what this -- it does at the system level. And we have a clear advantage of the system level over anybody. We've not seen the combination of Qualcomm, TDK to be any meaningful threat over the last 3 years.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the margins, Ed, yes, the modeling, we suggested the 60% and the target's 53% and at 51% for this quarter. We obviously feel good about we're well on our way. We've had some nice gains on consecutive quarters, and it's really a lot of things. You'r
componenttext: And on the margins, Ed, yes, the modeling, we suggested the 60% and the target's 53% and at 51% for this quarter. We obviously feel good about we're well on our way. We've had some nice gains on consecutive quarters, and it's really a lot of things. You're right. One of the things is the overall suite of new products we released because there's more integration, more value for the customer. We're just seeing better margins on that. So that's -- you could -- that's mix, but it's not mix. It's real -- it's more value-add integrated solutions, and that's really helping. And it's the things we do on CapEx. It's the things we do on driving productivity improvements through the fab, through the assembly and test operation in Mexicali. We've driven filter cost down dramatically. So we're executing as we have for a long time pretty well across all fronts, and they're all contributing to the margin story. As far as capacity, we're in really good shape. We've got square footage on a new leased facility in Mexicali. So it's short money for equipment. We can expand that very, very quickly. That pays back quickly. Dave already talked about quadrupling the filter capacity as far as square footage in Japan, so with equipment, again, we can do that very quickly. And we've got our outsource partners for a wafer. So we're in a really good shape to be able to expand capacity when it's required.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tim Long with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tim Long with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones if I could. You covered china pretty well. I'm wondering if you could just talk a little bit about what you're seeing or what your customers are saying about some of the other emerging markets right now. And then back to Qualcomm. Obviou
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones if I could. You covered china pretty well. I'm wondering if you could just talk a little bit about what you're seeing or what your customers are saying about some of the other emerging markets right now. And then back to Qualcomm. Obviously, they haven't -- as you talked about, they haven't had a lot of success. They are talking about now a little bit more aggressively about gallium arsenide. So from a competitive landscape, do you think that can change anything? And I guess, while we're on that topic, anything else from anyone in the CMOS camp?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Maybe I'll do the second half first, and Liam, you can comment on the other emerging markets. Tim, it really is the case that there hasn't been a single successful new PA company in many, many years, the PA device technology. And the merchant gas fo
componenttext: Sure. Maybe I'll do the second half first, and Liam, you can comment on the other emerging markets. Tim, it really is the case that there hasn't been a single successful new PA company in many, many years, the PA device technology. And the merchant gas foundries are, I would estimate, at least 5 years behind what Skyworks is able to do today, state of the art, at the device level, and it's been through decades of experience. So I think that the merchant gas market, merchant gas capability pales in comparison to the stellar device performance that companies like Skyworks and we specifically are getting. So I'm not too worried about any new gas entrant, and I'm definitely not worried about CMOS technology being able to accomplish the kind of current consumption, the kind of transmit requirements that we're seeing across our markets today. Every single time there is an advance in a different technology or with a different competitor, what we're finding is that the next-generation system has increased the bar so high that it doesn't matter that improvement isn't anywhere near capable of delivering a system-level performance that our customer's requiring. We're designing platforms now that are 2018, and those platforms, boy, I tell you, it is the best of the best. And we're going to compete successfully, and we think we've got a unique capability there.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And following up on the emerging markets into what we do see there is certainly our larger global brands participate across the emerging markets, but more frequently, we see some of the China players drive a great deal of their exports through market
componenttext: Yes. And following up on the emerging markets into what we do see there is certainly our larger global brands participate across the emerging markets, but more frequently, we see some of the China players drive a great deal of their exports through markets like India, Middle East, Latin America. Of those, the India market has actually been consuming probably at the highest level, again, buying product typically manufactured by our China OEMs. So we play it through that channel. And there's definitely a lot of room to grow in that geography.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gabriela Borges with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gabriela Borges with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just one on the near-term environment if I could. You mentioned the above-normal inventory reductions, but I'd love to get your thoughts on where you think we are with that inventory correction and whether inventory is getting more back in line with
componenttext: Maybe just one on the near-term environment if I could. You mentioned the above-normal inventory reductions, but I'd love to get your thoughts on where you think we are with that inventory correction and whether inventory is getting more back in line with end of model [ph] sell-through?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- clearly, there's been a disruption in the December and March time frame as a very large flagship phone model had to see the numbers come down, and we're working through that. And I think that, from my standpoint, any inventory correction i
componenttext: I think it's -- clearly, there's been a disruption in the December and March time frame as a very large flagship phone model had to see the numbers come down, and we're working through that. And I think that, from my standpoint, any inventory correction in the system should be gone in the June quarter, and we ought to be off to the races in the second half of the year.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on the broad market segment, clearly a number of drivers of that business segment, but maybe you could highlight for us 1 or 2 applications that you think can contribute the most from a dollar revenue growth perspective as we look out over t
componenttext: And then just on the broad market segment, clearly a number of drivers of that business segment, but maybe you could highlight for us 1 or 2 applications that you think can contribute the most from a dollar revenue growth perspective as we look out over the next few quarters.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure, yes. The broad markets business has been doing quite well, up about 12% year-over-year in Q1, and we'll continue to be at team's level or higher growth rate into the calendar year. So I mean, what we're seeing is really a wide variety of appli
componenttext: Sure, sure, yes. The broad markets business has been doing quite well, up about 12% year-over-year in Q1, and we'll continue to be at team's level or higher growth rate into the calendar year. So I mean, what we're seeing is really a wide variety of applications in the broad portfolio. We've got some great IoT programs that go into set-top box and streaming media, in many cases $10 to $12 per box WiFi switching, ZigBee technology. There's a connected home opportunity now that's really playing out, got some great content there. And one of the markets that we're excited about now, it's early innings, but we are seeing some uptake in automotive. We're starting to see high-end LTE telematics applications. We've got design wins in vehicle-to-vehicle communication. We've got customers like GM, like Volkswagen, Continental. So that's a market that we think we'll do very well for several years, and the opportunity there for us is outstanding. So that's a little color on where we are but broad, has been growing quite well and quite steady.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We now have a question from Craig Ellis with B. Riley.
componenttext: We now have a question from Craig Ellis with B. Riley.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with one that relates to the longer-term financial targets. In the quarter, you were a hair's distance from your operating margin target, and it looks like you're making very good progress towards the gross margin target. How should in fact jus
componenttext: I'll start with one that relates to the longer-term financial targets. In the quarter, you were a hair's distance from your operating margin target, and it looks like you're making very good progress towards the gross margin target. How should in fact just investors think about the time frame to the revenue target and the earnings per share target, guys?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, thanks for the question, Craig. The -- what's -- despite the backdrop right now, I mean, when you look at the -- the model for us is absolutely intact. I mean, when you look at the drivers we're making, continue to make progress on the gross
componenttext: Yes. I mean, thanks for the question, Craig. The -- what's -- despite the backdrop right now, I mean, when you look at the -- the model for us is absolutely intact. I mean, when you look at the drivers we're making, continue to make progress on the gross margin front. Volume will have some impact on that in the short term, but we're continuing to drive that. We know disciplined OpEx investments, we know how to measure those to manage that very effectively. So when you roll out all that together, once we get through this pause that we're seeing right now and given the back half of the year and beyond, we see an opportunity to get there in a couple of years. And by the way, we're not at -- what we deliver, we're not at the OpEx target because the model will be in the low 40s. We're not quite there yet. So we got room to run.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good stuff. And then a follow-up just on gross margins, Don. If I look at the last 3 quarters, which represents the bulk of calendar '15, the incrementals were 75% on average, which is amongst the best in semis. And I understand that the 60% increme
componenttext: Okay. Good stuff. And then a follow-up just on gross margins, Don. If I look at the last 3 quarters, which represents the bulk of calendar '15, the incrementals were 75% on average, which is amongst the best in semis. And I understand that the 60% incremental target is a nice uptick from where the company had been. But what would cause -- given the initiatives that you have in play and the business divestiture, which is low margin, what would cause a regression back to 60% rather than staying at the levels the business has recently been at?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a fair question, but you got to remember that those are averages to assume over a period. There are events that happen quarter-to-quarter that can move those. And what happened in those quarters, there were multiple things. We were seeing some bene
componenttext: That's a fair question, but you got to remember that those are averages to assume over a period. There are events that happen quarter-to-quarter that can move those. And what happened in those quarters, there were multiple things. We were seeing some benefit from the filter asset and driving cost down. We had new product launches. All of those things can create a short-term step-function that moves you in a different spot. That sustaining 75% is just -- that's off the charts. 60% is very, very good. So modeling 60%, you'll see you get a very, very good answer.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question now from Anthony Stoss with Craig-Hallum.
componenttext: We have a question now from Anthony Stoss with Craig-Hallum.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you talked about China being up, your biggest customer being down in March. Can you talk about Samsung? And also, Don, if you wouldn't mind taking us through kind of what CapEx was in the quarter and what we should expect in 2016.
componenttext: So you talked about China being up, your biggest customer being down in March. Can you talk about Samsung? And also, Don, if you wouldn't mind taking us through kind of what CapEx was in the quarter and what we should expect in 2016.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tony. With respect to Samsung, yes, we actually are seeing some improving conditions at Samsung. We should be up in the March quarter. We've got some new design wins that will be ramping with the GS7 platform, and we're actually reiterating what Dav
componenttext: Sure, Tony. With respect to Samsung, yes, we actually are seeing some improving conditions at Samsung. We should be up in the March quarter. We've got some new design wins that will be ramping with the GS7 platform, and we're actually reiterating what David said about content and SkyOne and filters. We're seeing Samsung really now adopt in earnest somebody's content-rich solutions not only on the transmit chain but also on the receive side. So that's a move up for us that will be sustainable. Samsung is our #2 customer. We got a great relationship there. So you should expect some solid results through the year.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And CapEx, Don?
componenttext: And CapEx, Don?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. CapEx, we had talked about that a little earlier, $79.5 million for the quarter. I mean, we're just recommending there'll be a couple of quarters we'll be real closer to the depreciation. We're out $50 million. And then it might go up a little as we
componenttext: Yes. CapEx, we had talked about that a little earlier, $79.5 million for the quarter. I mean, we're just recommending there'll be a couple of quarters we'll be real closer to the depreciation. We're out $50 million. And then it might go up a little as we get in the back half with volumes going up, and there may be some more investments that we make. So that's what I think of it.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then as far as BAW filters for yourselves, I think you had talked on the last call about 2017 getting there. How necessary is that? And as we push into a higher-frequency stuff later in later years, is it -- is it -- is that the right tec
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then as far as BAW filters for yourselves, I think you had talked on the last call about 2017 getting there. How necessary is that? And as we push into a higher-frequency stuff later in later years, is it -- is it -- is that the right technology where we just have to see some other technology emerge in filtering to handle that?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's -- that's a great question. Clearly, for today, we're doing low band and now mid-band. We're well up above 2 gigahertz with great performance using temperature-compensated devices. I think, BAW technology, what it will do for us in that '17 time
componenttext: Yes. It's -- that's a great question. Clearly, for today, we're doing low band and now mid-band. We're well up above 2 gigahertz with great performance using temperature-compensated devices. I think, BAW technology, what it will do for us in that '17 time frame will open up the high band, the very highest band in some of these back PAD configurations. I think, that'll be very good for us. We'll be able to have the enviable trade-off between using SAW, temperature-compensated SAW in bulk devices in using the right application for the function because if you look across the world today, most world phones, most smartphones don't use BAW technologies. They have a different configuration or a different band lineup that doesn't require it. But for those customers who are looking for sort of a low, mid, high, very high performance, truly a world phone, what BAW will do will open up high band for us in which we don't participate, market we do not participate in today. So it'll increase our TAM, and we'll get there by '17.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Cody Acree with Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: We'll go next to Cody Acree with Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just following up on that, Dave, and maybe for Liam as well. With your filtered capacity, expanded total capacity, is there a way to quantify some of the dollar count increases that you're able to attack today that maybe you weren't able to get into
componenttext: Maybe just following up on that, Dave, and maybe for Liam as well. With your filtered capacity, expanded total capacity, is there a way to quantify some of the dollar count increases that you're able to attack today that maybe you weren't able to get into a couple of years ago knowing that so much of the RF content increases is coming on the filter side?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that the increase over the last couple of years and for the next couple of years on the RF side and smartphones are mobile. It's probably equally weighted between filter-enabled devices, receive and transmit and other functionality that w
componenttext: Yes. I would say that the increase over the last couple of years and for the next couple of years on the RF side and smartphones are mobile. It's probably equally weighted between filter-enabled devices, receive and transmit and other functionality that we talked about, which is voltage regulation, power management, receive technology and higher-performance WiFi and the like. So I'm going to just broad brush it and tell you roughly equal growth within mobile coming about through filter-enabled solutions and coming about through other system-level blocks that we didn't previously address.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And to add to that, I think, one of the real unique characteristics of what we do here and we've talked about in this call is our ability to integrate. So it isn't just taking the filter and taking the amplifier and integrating it. There's a lot of u
componenttext: Yes. And to add to that, I think, one of the real unique characteristics of what we do here and we've talked about in this call is our ability to integrate. So it isn't just taking the filter and taking the amplifier and integrating it. There's a lot of unique Skyworks DNA that develops these engines. They're highly customizable. Each base band partner, each OEM, we configure to their needs. We look at their current budget. We look at what they need to do in terms of bands. We look at the filter technology you want to deploy. And all that comes together, and it's worked out great. And TC capabilities that we have today are unbelievable. They're world-class world manufacturer. In this last calendar year, we manufactured about 1.5 billion TC SAWs. All of which were consumed by our integrated system. So we're very bullish on that concept, and we'll continue to use the best technologies to win.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Dave, just on a high level on an M&A approach after what happened with PMC. Just what are your -- what's your interest? Are you looking at that -- ways to expand vertically? I guess, what would you be looking at?
componenttext: And Dave, just on a high level on an M&A approach after what happened with PMC. Just what are your -- what's your interest? Are you looking at that -- ways to expand vertically? I guess, what would you be looking at?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, similar to what we've done in the past, we're always looking for -- if you think about our power management acquisition that we did to AATI or SiGe or the Panasonic filter capability, they all did 2 things for us. They gave us a much bigger
componenttext: Yes. I think, similar to what we've done in the past, we're always looking for -- if you think about our power management acquisition that we did to AATI or SiGe or the Panasonic filter capability, they all did 2 things for us. They gave us a much bigger target and more relevance at the system performance level for our mobile customers, and they also opened up new target markets that gave us opportunities within IoT. So we would continue to look at that, whether it's cloud-based computing, whether it's machine to machine, whether it's being able to do more at the kind of IoT sensor, MCU RF module capability, we see those as being attractive, surgical, strategic, accretive deals.

componenttext: Just wanted to get into the broad markets a little bit. 20% of the revenue, around $185 million came from IoT broad markets. If you can just comment a little bit about the incremental growth in 2016, where it's coming from. Is it a broad stroke amongst auto, connected home, wearables, drone? And also, if you can just comment on the outlook for margins in that quarter, if it's above 50% or if it's sort of a different range for the different verticals, please.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, yes. The broad market business is actually quite diversified. I would say the strongest elements are around kind of the streaming media, the WiFi integration, connected home. We have just a large roster of design wins in that part of the space.
componenttext: Sure. Yes, yes. The broad market business is actually quite diversified. I would say the strongest elements are around kind of the streaming media, the WiFi integration, connected home. We have just a large roster of design wins in that part of the space. And we're also seeing -- and if you look at some teardowns with these boxes, we're seeing 3-x-3 streams, which will triple our content. And so you've got $10 to $12 per box. We're in markets like DIRECTV, Technicolor, some of the NetGear routers. Those are just examples. So that's a real strong area, and there's a lot of upgrades to go here in the U.S. and in developing markets. So we like that. Connected home, I mentioned, some of these appliance opportunities, customers like Nest, lots of names like that. Automotive, relatively new. You have not only the traditional IoT applications like WiFi and Bluetooth, but you have a telematics play there. And then other space that has been a bit quiet but we do think will turn is one with infrastructure. You have great deal of content with companies like Nokia, Siemens, Ericsson, Huawei, and we do see that getting a little stronger probably back half of 2016. A little bit soft so far, but it's another market where we have some solid designs.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, and welcome to Skyworks Solutions' First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Steve Ferranti, Vice President of Investor Relations for Skywork
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, and welcome to Skyworks Solutions' First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Steve Ferranti, Vice President of Investor Relations for Skyworks. Mr. Ferranti, please go ahead.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks first fiscal quarter 2016 conference call. Joining me today are Dave Aldrich, Don Palette and Liam Griffin. Dave will begin today's call with a business overview, followed by Don's financ
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks first fiscal quarter 2016 conference call. Joining me today are Dave Aldrich, Don Palette and Liam Griffin. Dave will begin today's call with a business overview, followed by Don's financial review and outlook. We will then open the lines for your questions.
Please note that our comments today will include statements relating to future results that are forward-looking as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially and adversely from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, those noted in our earnings release and those detailed from time to time in our SEC filings.
I would also like to remind everyone that the results and guidance we will discuss today are from our non-GAAP income statement, consistent with the format we've used in the past. Please refer to our press release within the Investor Relations section of our company website for a complete reconciliation to GAAP. With that, I will turn the call over to Dave for his comments on the quarter.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and welcome, everyone. We had a solid first quarter performance with revenue, profitability and earnings ahead of expectations in spite of the challenging macro environment. Now specifically during the quarter, we delivered revenue of $927
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and welcome, everyone. We had a solid first quarter performance with revenue, profitability and earnings ahead of expectations in spite of the challenging macro environment. Now specifically during the quarter, we delivered revenue of $927 million, that's up 15% year-over-year. 
We produced operating income of $367 million, that's up 30% year-over-year, translating into a 39.6% operating margin. And we posted $1.60 in earnings per share, that's up 27% versus the prior year. We also generated more than $345 million in operating cash flow and ended the quarter with just over $1.2 billion in cash on hand and with no debt. 
This was another well-executed quarter from the Skyworks team. Our content gained, our diversification and our disciplined approach -- our disciplined operational focus were key factors in achieving these Q1 results. And as we look ahead, we continue to see tangible opportunities to capitalize on a number of high-level growth trends across the technology landscape. These include growing consumption of wireless data within consumer and enterprise applications, advancements in cloud-based services, the proliferation of connectivity within the emerging markets, and increasing adoption of the Internet of Things. These macro themes are irrefutable and they're far-reaching, creating expanding uses for our technology and higher addressable content opportunities with each new product generation.
Leveraging our industry-leading integration capabilities, we positioned Skyworks to capitalize on these powerful market tailwinds. 
Now despite these positive long-term drivers, this year, the March quarter, which is normally a seasonally soft period, has been impacted by above-normal forecast reductions and inventory adjustments at one of our top customers. This dynamic has been well-documented across the supply chain over the last few weeks. 
After closely analyzing the market environment, we have adopted an appropriately conservative outlook for our Q2 revenue guidance. However, through strong gross margin performance and a disciplined focus on cost, the overall impact to EPS is relatively small. And our guidance represents high single digit earnings growth on a year-over-year basis. Don will provide more specifics later in the call. 
It is worth emphasizing that we're well positioned for a strong second half of calendar '16, based on clear visibility into design wins across our flagship smartphone customers. And from this vantage point, we are highly confident in our prospects for gaining dollar content within upcoming generations, putting us on track to continue delivering above-market revenue growth with expanding profit margins and earnings leverage. 
Before providing a more detailed view of the market, I'll turn it over now to Don for a more in-depth review of the financial results.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. Thanks for joining us, everyone. Revenue for the first quarter was $926.8 million, in line with our guidance and up 15% versus the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $476.1 million or 51.4% of revenue, ahead of guidance and up 470 basis poin
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. Thanks for joining us, everyone. Revenue for the first quarter was $926.8 million, in line with our guidance and up 15% versus the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $476.1 million or 51.4% of revenue, ahead of guidance and up 470 basis points from the quarter of fiscal 2015. Operating expenses were $109.5 million, consisting of R&D expense of $71.9 million and SG&A expense of $37.6 million. 
We generated $366.6 million of operating income, up 30% from the year-ago quarter, translating into a 39.6% operating margin. Our cash tax rate was 15%, resulting in net income of $311.2 million or $1.60 of diluted earnings per share, as compared with diluted EPS of $1.26 in the year-ago quarter. That equates to a 27% year-over-year earnings growth.
Turning to our first quarter balance sheet and cash flow statement, we invested $79.5 million in capital expenditures with depreciation of $51.5 million. We generated $345 million in cash flow from operations, which includes the $88.5 million termination fee from PMC-Sierra, and exited the quarter with over $1.2 billion in cash on hand and no debt.
Moving to product mix. For the first quarter of fiscal 2016, power amplifiers represented 16% of revenue, integrated mobile systems was 64% and broad markets was 20%. We saw healthy growth in both integrated mobile systems and broad markets. In fact, IMS was up a full 16 points versus a year ago as a percentage of our mix. Power amplifier products continue to decline as a percentage of our revenue, as the market shifts toward higher-value integrated solutions.
Now for our second quarter business outlook. We expect second quarter revenue to be approximately $775 million. We suggest modeling gross margin in the range of 50.5% to 51% with operating expenses flat to Q1 at approximately $109.5 million. 
It's worth noting that the midpoint of our gross margin guidance range implies over a 400-basis-point improvement versus the prior year. Our strong gross margin outlook in the face of current market dynamics highlights the benefits of our higher-value integrated systems, along with our scale and flexible manufacturing operations. 
Looking ahead, we see continued opportunity for margin improvement, as we leverage our recent capital investments and ramp our custom integrated solutions and precision analog products. For modeling purposes, we recommend using a 60% incremental gross margin off of the second quarter baseline. We are targeting a goal of at least 53% gross margin for the company and have a number of initiatives in place to accelerate our progress toward achieving this goal. 
Below the line, we anticipate $500,000 in interest and other expenses and a cash tax rate around 15%. We project our tax rate to remain at these levels for the remainder of our 2016 fiscal year. We expect share count to be around 194.5 million shares, resulting in second quarter EPS of $1.24, and that's up 8% versus last year.
Finally, we recently entered into an agreement to divest Trans-Tech, a small subsidiary of ours, to Kyocera for roughly $42 million. Trans-Tech produces ceramic substrates and materials for a number of broad market applications and had become a noncritical -- had become noncritical to our corporate strategy. We expect the transaction to close sometime in early April. For modeling purpose, we recommend assuming around $14 million per quarter of revenue impact, starting in the June quarter with no impact to EPS. This transaction helps to improve the financial returns of our business, while sharpening focus on our core strategy. 
Our Q2 margin and EPS guidance highlights the robustness of our business model within the context of challenging market conditions. For the second half of calendar 2016, we see momentum building off of this baseline. Many of the drivers supporting this are already in place, giving us a high level of confidence to extend our track record of best-in-class financial results. And we remain on track toward our midterm goal of $8 in annualized EPS. And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Dave.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don. Before closing and taking your questions, I wanted to take a moment to reiterate a few market realities that will continue to fuel our growth in the coming years. First, demand for wireless data continues to skyrocket, with no end in sig
componenttext:
Thank you, Don. Before closing and taking your questions, I wanted to take a moment to reiterate a few market realities that will continue to fuel our growth in the coming years. 
First, demand for wireless data continues to skyrocket, with no end in sight, driven by the adoption of streaming media and cloud-based services across consumer and enterprise applications. Now these services are in their infancy and consume a tremendous amount of bandwidth, drastically increasing demands on network and on devices. 
Secondly, growing data consumption requires dramatically higher levels of analog performance at the semiconductor level. To improve throughput, our customers are facing mounting technical challenges, including navigating spectrum limitations, improving signal reality -- reliability and mitigating interference, all while extending battery life. The end result is greater addressable content per device, and TAM growth well in excess of the semiconductor sector. 
Third, as a technology integration leader, we are consolidating market share. And our visibility to new content wins and future architectures is very strong. The solutions we're developing for future generations are tremendously complex. And they require best-in-class core technologies, advanced integration capabilities and deep system-level expertise. Skyworks is uniquely positioned in all these regards to address these opportunities. This focuses -- this fosters closer engagement with customers and higher-value solutions across the board with a narrowing field of capable competitors. 
And fourth, the Internet of Things is real, and it's happening today, facilitating entirely new growth avenues for us and enhancing our diversification. At this year's Consumer Electronics Show, there was a showcase of groundbreaking new devices, leveraging the power of wireless connectivity. Much of the excitement at CES this year was around innovations in the connected car, in the automated home, wearable technologies and entirely new categories like drones, utilizing enabling technologies like GPS, Wi-Fi, ZigBee, Bluetooth and others. And we participate at Skyworks in all of these markets through our suite of connectivity solutions. 
And lastly, we've successfully redefined our business model, combining a strategic focus on higher value-added integrated solutions, with unrivaled scale, with advanced manufacturing capabilities and deep operational knowhow. 
The end result is that we are consistently delivering among the best financial returns in the semiconductor sector in a variety of market conditions. As just one measure of this, our return on invested capital for 2015 was 33%. And over the last 2 years, we've averaged 30%.
So in closing, looking past the near-term volatility, we've created a unique and a robust business model, fueled by the proliferation of connectivity and combining above-market top-line growth, healthy cash flow and the financial returns of a best-in-class diversified analog company.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, let's open the lines for questions, please.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to give my congratulations for reacting so quickly to that change on the top line there, preserving EPS. My first question is just really, what are your expectations, I guess, for the overall RF content growth for the overall market over the nex
componenttext: Just want to give my congratulations for reacting so quickly to that change on the top line there, preserving EPS. My first question is just really, what are your expectations, I guess, for the overall RF content growth for the overall market over the next couple years? And if you guys expect to outgrow the market, where do you have the most leverage there to take share?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think the market for smartphones, for example, is going to grow in the mid-single digits. And if -- however, if you look at the complexity, analog and RF complexity, driven by increasing band count, by a higher adoption rate of AC, carrier aggreg
componenttext: Well, we think the market for smartphones, for example, is going to grow in the mid-single digits. And if -- however, if you look at the complexity, analog and RF complexity, driven by increasing band count, by a higher adoption rate of AC, carrier aggregation and other complex switching algorithms, looking to improve the signal integrity on the receive side, through DRx technologies, high-performance, low-noise amplifiers. We think the market growth rate would be at least double that for our class of products. And of course, we look to a broadening array of vertical markets and IoT to continue to round out the business and become more diversified with higher margins.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then a follow-up to that. Can you discuss content trends that you're seeing with the China -- Chinese handset OEMs? And maybe put in context how that growth there compares with what you're seeing with -- from the Tier 1 guys, maybe in Korea, Nor
componenttext: Okay, and then a follow-up to that. Can you discuss content trends that you're seeing with the China -- Chinese handset OEMs? And maybe put in context how that growth there compares with what you're seeing with -- from the Tier 1 guys, maybe in Korea, North America, wherever? And maybe part of that answer I'm curious, what your expected -- what you expect to see in terms of the impact from the move to 5 mode -- the 5-mode rollout in China?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rick, great question. Well, China is certainly a growth driver for Skyworks. So we're in the early innings of a 4G upgrade cycle. And just in the last quarter, December quarter, we were up about 20% year-over-year across China. Now there's been some
componenttext: Sure, Rick, great question. Well, China is certainly a growth driver for Skyworks. So we're in the early innings of a 4G upgrade cycle. And just in the last quarter, December quarter, we were up about 20% year-over-year across China. Now there's been some choppiness and near-term volatility. And we understand that well. We've been in this market for quite a while. We are encouraged by the content growth and the move towards these systems solutions that we speak of. We're starting to see that with the larger Tier 1s in China and also the white-box players. And we're continuing to go beyond just the transmit/receive solutions to start to move into things like Wi-Fi and GPS and power management. So that's all positive. And as we see this move to 5 more clearly, that's incremental content. So we are seeing that move up. It's really in line with the China subscribers wanting more and more functionality and more capability. And that plays right into our strengths. So we're very positive about that and expect China to be a long-term grower for us.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as Liam commented a moment ago, Vivek, the China TAM story and the upgrade to 4G has been very positive for the company. And in fact, I think, we were something like 20% year-over-year growth in our China revenue in the December quarter. An
componenttext: Well, I think, as Liam commented a moment ago, Vivek, the China TAM story and the upgrade to 4G has been very positive for the company. And in fact, I think, we were something like 20% year-over-year growth in our China revenue in the December quarter. And that's content, that's share, that's being lined out with the right set of baseband and SoC partners. And if you look at our customer, Samsung, our second largest customer, we've seen very high attach rate now with our more complex solutions, on the Galaxy 7 on there, and then the emerging 16 platforms. And the fact, Vivek, is our China customers and Samsung, they're all adopting virtually across the board a more complex system, RF system, that's highly integrated for size, for current consumption and just to merely handle the complexity and get these designs, these SKUs out into the market on time. And that's been very, very good for us. Very bad for the discrete companies. Very, very good for us.

componenttext: Well, it's obviously -- we're monitoring the demand environment in China and elsewhere very closely. However, the visibility in new designs and in new platforms, both in terms of flagship but also some of our IoT platforms, gives us a very keen sense that the second half of calendar '16 will be very strong and the growth rate will be very high. After we work through obviously, as you said, the well-publicized issue and inventory burn with a large customer. Maybe, Don, you could comment on the TTI transaction?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Sure. Yes. Vivek, so the way to think about it is when we're doing our models, you look at the business as it is today and assign appropriate growth rates throughout the fiscal period. And then off of that, you would just deduct $14 million a quarter for the June and September quarter and beyond, as you're starting at that point. And there's no earnings impact with that $14 million. So it's a much lower margin business for us. And then that's offset by their OpEx. So there's no earnings associated with that.
