componenttext: Just following up on the China side. We did -- while we did see the weakness from your top customer, it did seem the Chinese handset OEMs rebounded pretty nicely in the December quarter and ramping into Chinese New Year. So I'm just wondering if that's affected your customer mix? If you could give us an update on how big China is as a percent? And do you expect that to grow into the March quarter? And then also we heard a lot about India last night from your partner/competitor. I'm curious what your exposure is out there and the outlook?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Mike. With respect to China, as we've spoken, it's a very diverse set of customers. It's not just mobile. We do a great deal of business in IoT markets, Wi-Fi and even infrastructure, But we are seeing within China names like Huawei really acce
componenttext: Yes, sure, Mike. With respect to China, as we've spoken, it's a very diverse set of customers. It's not just mobile. We do a great deal of business in IoT markets, Wi-Fi and even infrastructure, But we are seeing within China names like Huawei really accelerate, Xiaomi to some degree and some of the other white-box players. And if you take the China Mobile businesses as well as our broad market, I mean, China is about 20% of our revenue at Skyworks. We do see them coming up this quarter, again, in March sequentially, so they're going to be one of the drivers for us in the March quarter. And again, throughout the year as we mentioned before, there's just a tremendous opportunity with the 2G and 3G customers and subscribers moving up into 4G. So we're encouraged by that. But you're going to see some improvement in China in the March quarter, following a strong December.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then for Don, if I could extend [ph] the OpEx. Great job on the gross margin. But how should we think about puts and takes for OpEx going forward after -- into this next calendar year? And then also just any thoughts on cash. Obviously, it's --
componenttext: Okay. And then for Don, if I could extend [ph] the OpEx. Great job on the gross margin. But how should we think about puts and takes for OpEx going forward after -- into this next calendar year? And then also just any thoughts on cash. Obviously, it's -- given the macro environment uncertainty, was your plan really to get more aggressive on the buyback? Or would you still be looking at some fairly large acquisitions?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the OpEx side, we said in the prepared remarks that we see $109.5 million kind of level for the next several fiscal quarters. After that, modeling up a couple million a quarter, as we've talked, $2 million to $3 million, as we've talked about befo
componenttext: Yes, on the OpEx side, we said in the prepared remarks that we see $109.5 million kind of level for the next several fiscal quarters. After that, modeling up a couple million a quarter, as we've talked, $2 million to $3 million, as we've talked about before, I think is a safe bet. As far as the cash, yes, we continue to generate very strong cash off of the earnings. We have that 40% target of free cash flow that we want to distribute to the shareholders through dividend, buybacks. We didn't do any buybacks this quarter, I mean, we also balance at about what's going on in potential M&A activity, what we're looking at and those things. And bottom line is that 40%, we'll continue to do. So stay tuned.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We now have a question from Blayne Curtis with Barclays.
componenttext: We now have a question from Blayne Curtis with Barclays.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just kind of following up on the use of cash, Don. If you could talk about what your CapEx was and what your plans are this year? And maybe, Dave, if you could talk about just -- update on your filter strategy as you build that out, as it becomes mo
componenttext: Maybe just kind of following up on the use of cash, Don. If you could talk about what your CapEx was and what your plans are this year? And maybe, Dave, if you could talk about just -- update on your filter strategy as you build that out, as it becomes more and more of these integrated modules?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we spent $80 million in the first fiscal quarter. We would expect that to come down closer to more like -- we don't really guide it, but more like the depreciation level. Depreciation is in the high 40s to 50 kind of a level. So it is coming down. An
componenttext: Yes, we spent $80 million in the first fiscal quarter. We would expect that to come down closer to more like -- we don't really guide it, but more like the depreciation level. Depreciation is in the high 40s to 50 kind of a level. So it is coming down. And some of that -- when we're spending capital, it's a direct result of the volume that we're looking at. So with sort of the backdrop right now, that number is going to be able to come down a little bit. The use of cash as we said, we like the 40% targeted for our shareholders. And that will be through dividend and buybacks. We'll continue to focus on doing that.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Blayne, with respect to filters in the last few quarters, as we've discussed on each call, we've dramatically increased our footprint in Japan and again processing in Singapore. We are probably roughly quadrupled the capability from a facility standp
componenttext: And, Blayne, with respect to filters in the last few quarters, as we've discussed on each call, we've dramatically increased our footprint in Japan and again processing in Singapore. We are probably roughly quadrupled the capability from a facility standpoint. We're hiring. We're getting very good performance at the RF level as well as yields. And so we continue to see advantages in using really the highest performance temperature-compensated service device in the world. And we are starting to see more bands at higher frequencies that are capable of using TC SAW, which of course, we see a real performance and cost advantage, both on the transmit and the receive side. So I think you should look for us to continue to line out modules, SkyOne, and other type of products, power amplified duplexers, more and more of our internal devices, as well as our receive DRx with temperature-compensated SAW for better receive performance.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up, as you look out this year, you talked about content gains, your large smartphone customers. Can you maybe just talk about where -- what types of products you're seeing the best traction for content gain? That would be helpful
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up, as you look out this year, you talked about content gains, your large smartphone customers. Can you maybe just talk about where -- what types of products you're seeing the best traction for content gain? That would be helpful.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Blayne. Yes, with regard to large flagship programs, in general, what you're seeing is, as Dave articulated, more and more adoption of our SkyOne filter rich multiple bands -- multiple power amplifier band switching, integrated in a transmit section
componenttext: Sure, Blayne. Yes, with regard to large flagship programs, in general, what you're seeing is, as Dave articulated, more and more adoption of our SkyOne filter rich multiple bands -- multiple power amplifier band switching, integrated in a transmit section. Coupled with that, we're doing really good work on the receive chain with these DRx solutions that look at LNAs against switching, against filtering, integrating in it with single engine. And then to augment that, we're really seeing great traction in our 11ac portfolio, often in MIMO, often [ph] 2 per smartphone. We're seeing power management devices and Bluetooth connectivity, et cetera. So we're really rounding out this analog content around very rich filter-integrated systems. So that's what you will see in the flagship phones. And we're starting to see our value tier customers even move up into that area.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Harsh Kumar with Stephens.
componenttext: We'll go next to Harsh Kumar with Stephens.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on your content in the Chinese handset guys, versus the Tier 1. And what opportunity do you see as the Chinese handset guys try to move up and match sort of what the Tier 1 guys are offering [ph]?
componenttext: Question on your content in the Chinese handset guys, versus the Tier 1. And what opportunity do you see as the Chinese handset guys try to move up and match sort of what the Tier 1 guys are offering [ph]?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- hi, Harsh. I think, that the upgrade cycle in China is the largest content gain in the history of the company, because the volumes are so very high and the embedded base there of 2G and 3G has relatively low content for us. And now as the
componenttext: Well, I think -- hi, Harsh. I think, that the upgrade cycle in China is the largest content gain in the history of the company, because the volumes are so very high and the embedded base there of 2G and 3G has relatively low content for us. And now as the world is adopting these more integrated system solutions for all the sort of well-publicized, performance, size, cost, and just a reality of how do you deal with the complexity when you're a customer who has other things to worry about than the RF portion. So we continue to see a great deal of content gain, and frankly, share consolidation. And it is turning into a big scale advantage to have the breadth of content as well as the cost structure around high volume. So I think you'll continue to see that.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up, a couple of companies, such as Avago and others, talk about content growing above 15%. I know you guys are somewhere in there. Most of you guys talk about greater than 10%. I'm curious what the latest, greatest standpoint is with
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, a couple of companies, such as Avago and others, talk about content growing above 15%. I know you guys are somewhere in there. Most of you guys talk about greater than 10%. I'm curious what the latest, greatest standpoint is with respect to how you guys see content growth for smartphones?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would echo what you stated. I think the content growth is every bit of kind of a low mid-teens and could be higher. We have to decouple the true content growth that's driven by complexity, which everybody talks about. There's more bands, there's mo
componenttext: Yes, I would echo what you stated. I think the content growth is every bit of kind of a low mid-teens and could be higher. We have to decouple the true content growth that's driven by complexity, which everybody talks about. There's more bands, there's more high-frequency bands, there's more complexity around delivering, as Liam mentioned, MIMO-based solutions on the receive side. Powered voltage is becoming an increasing issue. Of course, you remember we did an acquisition that gives us some unique IP around driving more refined voltage through the transmit path. And that's a real advantage in our system solution that can't be replicated by an RF-only company. So we continue to see that as a real differential advantage for Skyworks.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Atif Malik with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll go next to Atif Malik with Citigroup.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on strong execution. Dave, can you just talk about your strategy on filters. Do you need a BAW solution for carrier aggregation opportunity, which is taking off this year? And then I have a follow up.
componenttext: Congratulations on strong execution. Dave, can you just talk about your strategy on filters. Do you need a BAW solution for carrier aggregation opportunity, which is taking off this year? And then I have a follow up.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do need a high-performance filter technology. And we're finding that we're able to do very high-frequency, very tight frequency spacing with our temperature-compensated SAW. We also have BAW filter partners and a lot of IP that's giving us the capabili
componenttext: We do need a high-performance filter technology. And we're finding that we're able to do very high-frequency, very tight frequency spacing with our temperature-compensated SAW. We also have BAW filter partners and a lot of IP that's giving us the capability to enter in strategic band configurations using a bulk device, coupled with a temperature-compensated -- coupled with a SAW. But you mentioned carrier aggregation. What we're really seeing is we can get the performance, for example, on the transmit path or any carrier aggregation system. If we can drive the right topology and the right device performance, we find that it's a little bit less dependent than one normally thinks about the actual filter technology and process. That it is about the whole linked budget, that is from the transceiver to the antenna and back. And so we're getting, I mean, some of the power-added efficiency numbers and the current consumption reduction we're getting out of these newest generation SkyOne, SkyLiTE, PAD architectures, it really -- frankly, unheard of in the space. And it's not all about the filters, it's much more about the device performance and the way we architect it.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then how does the TDK Qualcomm JV impact your relationship or arrangement in outsourcing parts at TDK?
componenttext: Okay. And then how does the TDK Qualcomm JV impact your relationship or arrangement in outsourcing parts at TDK?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we buy SAW filters from TDK. We have a long-term supply agreement. That deal is not going to close for a while. We're very lucky that we have a big footprint now in filters, and so we can build our own SAWs and our own TC SAWs. We'll see how that pl
componenttext: Well, we buy SAW filters from TDK. We have a long-term supply agreement. That deal is not going to close for a while. We're very lucky that we have a big footprint now in filters, and so we can build our own SAWs and our own TC SAWs. We'll see how that plays out. But I don't think it has any material impact on supply at all. And in fact, it's been on our roadmap, particularly when you look at DRx technology, which is a lot of filters, a lot of passives. It's always been on our roadmap for margins -- frankly, for margin as well as performance to pull that technology more and more in-house. So we can pull it in if we have to. And it really will be -- will play out over time. But I wouldn't worry about it from a supply constraint.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Edward Snyder with Charter Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Edward Snyder with Charter Equity Research.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, I kind of want to hit on the same point. You're -- just get a glimpse of your capacity in Panasonic. They used to build their own SAW. Then you guys converted them over to TC, but it sounds like you could go back fairly easy if you had the capacity.
componenttext: Dave, I kind of want to hit on the same point. You're -- just get a glimpse of your capacity in Panasonic. They used to build their own SAW. Then you guys converted them over to TC, but it sounds like you could go back fairly easy if you had the capacity. And then Qualcomm has been making a lot of this JV, but can you just refresh our memory before the JV was announced. Were you seeing Qualcomm in any of the competitions for any of the RF in any of the major players? I know they've been doing RF360 for like 3 years now. And so I just want to get kind of a snapshot before we lose our minds on the JV on what was going on with Qualcomm in RF before then. And then, Don, the 60% incremental gross margins, what's the primary driver that you're going to need to get there? What's driving that? And the 53% target margin, the primary driver there, is it a higher mix of integrated products? Or is it just throughput? And then if you could maybe give us an update on the gas capacity? And most importantly your packaging assembly test capacity in Mexico?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a long question, Ed. Thank you.
componenttext: That's a long question, Ed. Thank you.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, that's -- yes. So with respect to the first half of the question, I think you're absolutely right. The TDK and Qualcomm have been working closely together and fielding designs for a long time. We've competed very successfully against those designs, so
componenttext: Ed, that's -- yes. So with respect to the first half of the question, I think you're absolutely right. The TDK and Qualcomm have been working closely together and fielding designs for a long time. We've competed very successfully against those designs, so there hasn't been a lot of traction in the sweet spot of what we do. There've been other RF360 components of that system, in which we don't compete, where they've had success. But these decades of gallium arsenide performance and driving switch technologies and multi-chip module technology and getting to put our own high-performance filters has really given us a system-level performance that has not been easy for competition to replicate. We know TDK very well. We've used them in the past. They're mostly SAW. They've got some limited capability involved. But remember, I think, as your question alluded to, our customers are awarding business based purely on performance and on configurability. And what it does at the system level. And we have a clear advantage at the system level over anybody. And we've not seen the combination of Qualcomm, TDK to be any meaningful threat over the last 3 years.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the margins, Ed, yes, the modeling. We suggested a 60%, and the target's 53%. And at 51% for this quarter we're -- obviously feel good about, we're well on our way. We've had some nice gains on consecutive quarters. And it's really a lot of things.
componenttext: And on the margins, Ed, yes, the modeling. We suggested a 60%, and the target's 53%. And at 51% for this quarter we're -- obviously feel good about, we're well on our way. We've had some nice gains on consecutive quarters. And it's really a lot of things. You're right. One of the things is the overall suite of new products we release, because there's more integration, more value for the customer. We're just seeing better margins on that. So that's -- you could -- that's a mix, but it's not mix that's real -- it's more value-added integrated solutions. And that's really helping. And it's the things we do on CapEx. It's the things we do on driving productivity improvements through the fab, through the assembly and test operation in Mexicali. We've driven filter costs down dramatically. So we're executing as we have for a long time pretty well across all fronts. And they're all contributing to the margin story. As far as capacity, we're in really good shape. We've got square footage on a new lease facility in Mexicali. So it's short money for equipment. We can expand that very, very quickly. That pays back quickly. Dave already talked about quadrupling the filter capacity as far as square footage in Japan. So with equipment, again, we can do that very quickly. And we've got our outsourced partners for our wafers. So we're in really good shape to be able to expand capacity when it's required.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tim Long with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tim Long with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones if I could. You covered China pretty well. I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about what you're seeing or what your customers are saying about some of the other emerging markets right now? And then back to Qualcomm. Obvi
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones if I could. You covered China pretty well. I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about what you're seeing or what your customers are saying about some of the other emerging markets right now? And then back to Qualcomm. Obviously, they haven't -- as you talked about, they haven't had a lot of success. They are talking about now, a little bit more aggressively about gallium arsenide. So from the competitive landscape, do you think that can change anything? And I guess, while we're on that topic, anything else from anyone in the CMOS camp?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Maybe I'll do the second half first, and, Liam, you can comment on the other emerging markets. Tim, it really is the case that there hasn't been a single successful new PA company in many, many years, with PA device technology. And the merchant GaAs
componenttext: Sure. Maybe I'll do the second half first, and, Liam, you can comment on the other emerging markets. Tim, it really is the case that there hasn't been a single successful new PA company in many, many years, with PA device technology. And the merchant GaAs foundries are, I would estimate, at least 5 years behind what Skyworks is able to do today, state of the art, at the device level. And it's been through decades of experience. So I think that the merchant GaAs market, merchant GaAs capability pales in comparison to the stellar device performance that companies like Skyworks and we specifically are getting. So I'm not too worried about any new GaAs entrant. And I'm definitely not worried about CMOS technology being able to accomplish the kind of current consumption, the kind of transmit requirements that we're seeing across our markets today. Every single time there is an advance in a different technology or with a different competitor, what we're finding is that the next-generation system has increased the bar so high that it doesn't matter. That improvement isn't anywhere near capable of delivering the system-level performance that our customer is requiring. We're designing platforms now that are 2018, and in those platforms, boy, I tell you, it is the best of the best who are going to compete successfully. And we think we've got a unique capability there.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then following up on the emerging markets. I mean, what we do see there is certainly our larger global brands participate across the emerging markets. But more frequently, we see some of the China players drive a great deal of their exports throu
componenttext: Yes. And then following up on the emerging markets. I mean, what we do see there is certainly our larger global brands participate across the emerging markets. But more frequently, we see some of the China players drive a great deal of their exports through markets like India, Middle East, Latin America. Of those, the India market has actually been consuming probably at the highest level, again, buying product typically manufactured by our China OEM. So we play it through that channel. And there's definitely a lot of room to grow in that geography.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gabriela Borges with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gabriela Borges with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just one on the near-term environment if I could. You mentioned the above-normal inventory reductions. But I'd love to get your thoughts on where you think we are with that inventory correction? And whether inventory is getting more back in line wit
componenttext: Maybe just one on the near-term environment if I could. You mentioned the above-normal inventory reductions. But I'd love to get your thoughts on where you think we are with that inventory correction? And whether inventory is getting more back in line with end of mod [ph] and sell-through?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- clearly, there's been a disruption in the December and March time frame, as a very large flagship phone model has seen the numbers come down. And we're working through that. And I think that, from my standpoint, any inventory correction in
componenttext: I think it's -- clearly, there's been a disruption in the December and March time frame, as a very large flagship phone model has seen the numbers come down. And we're working through that. And I think that, from my standpoint, any inventory correction in the system should be gone in the June quarter. And we ought to be off to the races in the second half of the year.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on the broad market segment, clearly a number of drivers of that business segment. But maybe you could highlight for us 1 or 2 applications that you think can contribute the most from a dollar revenue growth perspective, as we look out over
componenttext: And then just on the broad market segment, clearly a number of drivers of that business segment. But maybe you could highlight for us 1 or 2 applications that you think can contribute the most from a dollar revenue growth perspective, as we look out over the next few quarters?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure, yes. The broad markets business has been doing quite well. We're up about 12% year-over-year in Q1. And we'll continue to be at teens level or higher growth rate into the calendar year. So I mean, what we're seeing is really a wide variety of
componenttext: Sure, sure, yes. The broad markets business has been doing quite well. We're up about 12% year-over-year in Q1. And we'll continue to be at teens level or higher growth rate into the calendar year. So I mean, what we're seeing is really a wide variety of applications in the broad portfolio. We've got some great IoT programs that go into set-top box and streaming media, in many cases, $10 to $12 per box, WiFi switching, ZigBee technology. There's a connected home opportunity now that's really playing out, got some great content there. And one of the markets that we're excited about now, it's early innings, but we are seeing some uptake in automotive. We're starting to see high-end LTE telematics applications. We've got design wins in vehicle-to-vehicle communication. We've got customers like GM, like Volkswagen, Continental. So that's a market that we think we'll do very well for several years. And the opportunity there for us is outstanding. So that's a little color on where we are. But broadest, has been growing quite well and quite steady.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We now have a question from Craig Ellis with B. Riley.
componenttext: We now have a question from Craig Ellis with B. Riley.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with one that relates to the longer-term financial targets. In the quarter, you were a hair's distance from your operating margin target. And it looks like you're making very good progress towards the gross margin target. How should in fact jus
componenttext: I'll start with one that relates to the longer-term financial targets. In the quarter, you were a hair's distance from your operating margin target. And it looks like you're making very good progress towards the gross margin target. How should in fact just investors think about the time frame to the revenue target and the earnings per share target, guys?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, thanks for the question, Craig. The -- what's -- despite the backdrop right now, I mean, when you look at the -- the model for us is absolutely intact. I mean, you look at the drivers, we're making -- continue to make progress on the gross ma
componenttext: Yes. I mean, thanks for the question, Craig. The -- what's -- despite the backdrop right now, I mean, when you look at the -- the model for us is absolutely intact. I mean, you look at the drivers, we're making -- continue to make progress on the gross margin front. Volume will have some impact on that in the short term. But we're continuing to drive that. We know disciplined OpEx investments. We know how to measure those to manage that very effectively. So when you roll all that together, once we get through this pause that we're seeing right now and given the back half of the year and beyond, we see an opportunity to get there in a couple of years. And by the way, we're not at -- what we deliver, we're not at the OpEx target, because the model will be in the low 40s. We're not quite there yet. So we got room to run.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good stuff. And then a follow-up just on gross margins, Don. If I look at the last 3 quarters, which represents the bulk of calendar '15, the incrementals were 75% on average, which is amongst the best in semis. And I understand that the 60% increme
componenttext: Okay. Good stuff. And then a follow-up just on gross margins, Don. If I look at the last 3 quarters, which represents the bulk of calendar '15, the incrementals were 75% on average, which is amongst the best in semis. And I understand that the 60% incremental target is a nice uptick from where the company had been. But what would cause -- given the initiatives that you have in play and the business divestiture, which is low margin, what would cause a regression back to 60%, rather than staying at the levels the business has recently been at?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a fair question. But you got to remember that those are averages to assume over period. There are events that happen quarter-to-quarter that can move those. And what happened in those quarters, there were multiple things. We were seeing some b
componenttext: Yes, that's a fair question. But you got to remember that those are averages to assume over period. There are events that happen quarter-to-quarter that can move those. And what happened in those quarters, there were multiple things. We were seeing some benefit from the filter asset and driving costs down. We had new product launches. All of those things can create a short-term step-function that moves you into a different spot. But sustaining 75% is just -- that's off the charts. 60% is very, very good. So modeling 60%, you'll see you get a very, very good answer.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question now from Anthony Stoss with Craig-Hallum.
componenttext: We have a question now from Anthony Stoss with Craig-Hallum.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you talked about China being up, your biggest customer being down in March. Can you talk about Samsung? And also, Don, if you wouldn't mind taking us through kind of what CapEx was in the quarter? And what we should expect in 2016.
componenttext: So you talked about China being up, your biggest customer being down in March. Can you talk about Samsung? And also, Don, if you wouldn't mind taking us through kind of what CapEx was in the quarter? And what we should expect in 2016.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tony. With respect to Samsung, yes, we actually are seeing some improving conditions at Samsung. We should be up in the March quarter. We've got some new design wins that will be ramping with the GS7 platform. And we're actually reiterating what Dav
componenttext: Sure, Tony. With respect to Samsung, yes, we actually are seeing some improving conditions at Samsung. We should be up in the March quarter. We've got some new design wins that will be ramping with the GS7 platform. And we're actually reiterating what David said about content and SkyOne and filters. We're seeing Samsung really now adopt in earnest some of these content-rich solutions, not only on the transmit chain but also on the receive side. So that's a move up for us that will be sustainable. Samsung is our #2 customer. We got a great relationship there. So you should expect some solid results through the year.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And CapEx, Don?
componenttext: And CapEx, Don?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. CapEx, we had talked about that a little earlier, $79.5 million for the quarter. I mean, we're just recommending there'll be a couple of quarters we'll be real closer to the depreciation of around $50 million. And it might go up a little as we get in
componenttext: Yes. CapEx, we had talked about that a little earlier, $79.5 million for the quarter. I mean, we're just recommending there'll be a couple of quarters we'll be real closer to the depreciation of around $50 million. And it might go up a little as we get in the back half with volumes going up. And there may be some more investments that we make. So that's what I think of it.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Great. And then as far as BAW filters for yourselves, I think you had talked on the last call about 2017 getting there. How necessary is that? And as we push into higher-frequency stuff later, in later years, is it -- is that the right technology? Or will we have to see some other technology emerge in filtering to handle that?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's -- that's a great question. Clearly, for today, we're doing low band and now mid-band. We're well up above 2 gigahertz with great performance using temperature-compensated devices. I think, BAW technology, what it will do for us in that '17 time
componenttext: Yes. It's -- that's a great question. Clearly, for today, we're doing low band and now mid-band. We're well up above 2 gigahertz with great performance using temperature-compensated devices. I think, BAW technology, what it will do for us in that '17 time frame will open up the high band, the very highest band in some of these PAD configurations. I think, that'll be very good for us. We'll be able to have the enviable trade-off between using SAW, temperature-compensated SAW in bulk devices and using the right application for the function, because if you look across the world today, most world phones, most smartphones don't use BAW technologies. They have a different configuration or a different band lineup that doesn't require it. But for those customers who are looking for sort of a low, mid, high, very high performance, truly a world phone, what BAW will do will open up high band for us, in which we don't participate, a market we do not participate in today. So it'll increase our TAM, and we'll get there by '17.

componenttext: Maybe just following up on that, Dave, and maybe for Liam as well. With your filtered capacity, expanded total capacity, is there a way to quantify some of the dollar count increases that you're able to attack today that maybe you weren't able to get into a couple years ago, knowing that so much of the RF content increases is coming on the filter side?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that the increase over the last couple of years and for the next couple of years on the RF side and smartphones or mobile, is probably equally weighted between filter-enabled devices, receive and transmit, and other functionality that we
componenttext: Yes. I would say that the increase over the last couple of years and for the next couple of years on the RF side and smartphones or mobile, is probably equally weighted between filter-enabled devices, receive and transmit, and other functionality that we talked about, which is voltage regulation, power management, receive technology and higher-performance WiFi and the like. So I'm going to just broad brush it and tell you roughly equal growth within mobile coming about through filter-enabled solutions and coming about through other system-level blocks that we didn't previously address.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And to add to that, I think, one of the real unique characteristics of what we do here, and we've talked about in this call, is our ability to integrate. So it isn't just taking the filter and taking the amplifier and integrating it. There's a lot of
componenttext: Yes. And to add to that, I think, one of the real unique characteristics of what we do here, and we've talked about in this call, is our ability to integrate. So it isn't just taking the filter and taking the amplifier and integrating it. There's a lot of unique Skyworks DNA that develops these engines. They're highly customizable. Each baseband partner, each OEM, we configure to their needs. We look at their current budget. We look at what they need to do in terms of bands. We look at the filter technology you wanted to deploy. And all that comes together. And it's worked out great. And the TC capabilities that we have today are unbelievable. They're world-class. We'll manufacture -- in this last calendar year, we manufactured about 1.5 billion TC SAWs, all of which were consumed by our integrated system. So we're very bullish on that concept. And we'll continue to use the best technologies to win.

componenttext: Yes. I think, Cody, similar to what we've done in the past, we're always looking for -- if you think about the power management acquisition that we did through AATI or SiGe or the Panasonic filter capability, they all did 2 things for us. They gave us a much bigger target and more relevance at the system performance level for our mobile customers. And they also opened up new target markets that gave us opportunities within IoT. So we would continue to look at that, whether it's cloud-based computing, whether it's machine to machine, whether it's being able to do more at the kind of IoT sensor, MCU RF module capability, we see those as being attractive, surgical, strategic, accretive deals.

componenttext: Just wanted to get into the broad markets a little bit. 20% of the revenue, around $185 million, came from IoT broad markets. If you can just comment a little bit about the incremental growth in 2016. Where it's coming from? Is it a broad stroke amongst the auto, connected home, wearables, drone? And also, if you can just comment on the outlook for margins in that quarter, if it's above 50%? Or if there's sort of a different range for the different verticals, please?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, yes. The broad market business, it is actually quite diversified. I would say the strongest elements are around kind of the streaming media, the WiFi integration, connected home. We have just a large roster of design wins in that part of the sp
componenttext: Sure. Yes, yes. The broad market business, it is actually quite diversified. I would say the strongest elements are around kind of the streaming media, the WiFi integration, connected home. We have just a large roster of design wins in that part of the space. And we're also seeing -- and if you look at some of the teardowns of these boxes, we're seeing 3-by-3 streams, which will triple our content. And so you've got $10 to $12 per box. We're in markets like DIRECTV, Technicolor, some of the NetGear routers. Those are just examples. So that's a real strong area. And there's a lot of upgrades to go here in the U.S. and in developing markets. So we like that. Connected home, I mentioned, some of these appliance opportunities, customers like Nest, lots of names like that. Automotive, relatively new. You have not only the traditional IoT applications like WiFi and Bluetooth, but you have a telematics play there. And then the other space that has been a bit quiet, but we do think will turn, is one with infrastructure. We have a great deal of content with companies like Nokia-Siemens, Ericsson, Huawei. And we do see that getting a little stronger probably back half of 2016. A little bit soft so far, but it's another market where we have some solid designs.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, and welcome to Skyworks Solutions Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Steve Ferranti, Vice President of Investor Relations for Skywork
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, and welcome to Skyworks Solutions Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Steve Ferranti, Vice President of Investor Relations for Skyworks. Mr. Ferranti, please go ahead.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks' second fiscal quarter 2016 conference call. Joining me today are Dave Aldrich, Don Palette and Liam Griffin. Dave will begin today's call with the business overview, followed by Don's fi
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks' second fiscal quarter 2016 conference call. Joining me today are Dave Aldrich, Don Palette and Liam Griffin. Dave will begin today's call with the business overview, followed by Don's financial review and outlook. We will then open the lines for your questions.
Please note that our comments today will include statements relating to future results that are forward-looking as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially and adversely from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including but not limited to, those noted in our earnings release and those detailed from time to time in our SEC filings.
I'd also like to remind everyone that the results and guidance we will discuss today are from our non-GAAP income statement, consistent with the format we've used in the past. Please refer to our press release within the Investor Relations section of our company website for a complete reconciliation to GAAP. With that, I will turn the call over to Dave for his comments on the quarter.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and welcome, everyone. We delivered another solid financial performance for the second fiscal quarter of 2016, posting year-over-year growth in revenue, profitability and earnings even as we navigated to a combination of inventory adjustmen
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and welcome, everyone. We delivered another solid financial performance for the second fiscal quarter of 2016, posting year-over-year growth in revenue, profitability and earnings even as we navigated to a combination of inventory adjustments and a forecast reductions at one of our major customers.
During the quarter, we delivered revenue of $775 million, that's in line with our guidance, and posted gross margin of 50.8%, that's up 410 basis points year-over-year. We generated operating income of $285 million, that's up 10% year-over-year. We produced operating margin of 36.8%, and we provided $1.25 in earnings per share, that's up 9% versus the prior year.
For the first half of fiscal 2016, we generated roughly $383 million in free cash flow, redistributing over 60% or $234 million to shareholders through our dividend plan and our share repurchase activity.
Q2 was a solid quarter, highlighting the strong execution of our team and the robustness of our financial model. Our gross margin initiatives and operating expense discipline enabled us to both expand margins and earnings in the seasonally down quarter.
The market environment remains challenging entering the third fiscal quarter. The June quarter is normally a transitional period in our sector, bridging the March quarter's seasonal trough with the stronger second half of the calendar year. This year, inventory drawdowns and slower sell-through trends of our top customer are providing a drag on overall demand levels, impacting our Q3 guidance despite our strong growth in growing markets and with other OEMs.
As we navigate through these customer-specific dynamics, our competitive position and our financial model remained quite strong. We continue to improve our gross margins and our overall financial returns while investing aggressively in innovation and in capacity. It's also worth emphasizing a couple of important points. First, among our top customers, we see complexity and increasing performance requirements driving content expansion across the board. As an example, our overall content on Samsung's flagship Galaxy S7 platform is up 20% versus prior year models. We've also secured more than $9 of content within Huawei's new flagship smartphone platforms, helping to drive over 40% year-over-year growth with this customer.
Secondly, we continue to be highly successful in leading the market transition towards integrated solutions and we're consolidating share while expanding our technology leadership.
And third, we continue to see significant traction with the Internet of Things as evidenced by our 18% year-over-year growth in our broad markets product segment. These factors give us a high confidence in our longer-term gross prospects. And before providing more specifics on the market environment, turn the call over to Don for more in-depth review of our financial results.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and thanks for joining us, everyone. We appreciate it. Revenue for the second quarter was $775.1 million, and that's in line with our guidance and up 1.7% versus the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $393.6 million or 50.8% of revenue, in l
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and thanks for joining us, everyone. We appreciate it. Revenue for the second quarter was $775.1 million, and that's in line with our guidance and up 1.7% versus the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $393.6 million or 50.8% of revenue, in line with our guidance and up 410 basis points from the second quarter of fiscal 2015. Operating expenses were $108.6 million, consisting of R&D expense of $73.1 million and SG&A expense of $35.5 million.
We generated $285 million of operating income, up 10% of the year-ago quarter and that translates into a 36.8% operating margin. Our cash tax rate was 14.3%, resulting in net income of $242.3 million or $1.25 of diluted earnings per share, and that's $0.01 ahead of our guidance and represents around a 9% year-over-year earnings growth.
Turning to our second quarter balance sheet and cash flow statement. We invested $37 million in capital expenditures and with depreciation of $53.6 million, we generated $154.5 million in cash flow from operations and we exited the quarter with roughly $1.2 billion in cash on hand and no debt. We also repurchased 2 million shares of our common stock during the quarter at an average price of just over $67.50 a share. Given our confidence in our long-term business trends, we expect to continue to be very active with our share repurchase activity at current levels.
Moving to product mix. For the second quarter of fiscal 2016, power amplifiers represented 17% of revenue; integrated mobile systems was 58%; and broad markets was 25%. We saw healthy growth in both integrated mobile systems and broad markets. We're quite pleased that our broad markets portfolio grew over 18% year-over-year in the second quarter. We continue to expect IMS to remain our strongest growth segment followed by broad markets, while power amplifier products continue to decline as a percentage of our revenue as the market shifts toward higher value integrated solutions.
Now for our third quarter business outlook. We expect third quarter revenue to be approximately $750 million, with softness at our largest customer being partially offset by strong year-over-year growth at Samsung in China and across the broad markets. At this revenue level, we suggest modeling gross margin at 51% with operating expenses flat to Q2 at approximately $108.5 million.
It is worth noting that our Q3 gross margin guidance implies a 200 basis point improvement versus the prior year. Our strong gross margin outlook in the face of current market conditions highlight the benefits of our higher value integrated systems, along with our scale and flexible manufacturing operations.
Looking ahead, we see opportunity for additional margin improvement as we continue to ramp our custom solutions and leverage our recent capital investments. As a guideline, we recommend modeling a 60% incremental gross margin off of the third quarter baseline. We continue to target a goal of at least 53% gross margin for the company and have a number of initiatives in place to accelerate our progress towards achieving this goal.
And below the line, we anticipate around $1 billion in interest and other expenses and a cash tax rate between 14.5% to 15%. We project our tax rate to remain in this range for the remainder of our 2016 fiscal year. And we expect share count to be around 192.5 million shares, which results in a third quarter EPS of $1.21.
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Dave.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. While I'm very pleased by the resilience of our financial model in spite of the well-publicized market challenges to our near-term top line growth. And even more importantly, I'm highly confident that the underlying technology themes fielding
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. While I'm very pleased by the resilience of our financial model in spite of the well-publicized market challenges to our near-term top line growth. And even more importantly, I'm highly confident that the underlying technology themes fielding our long-term growth remain quite positive. And we're fortunate to be leveraged to powerful security technology trends and we've spent of the last decade aligning the company to capitalize on these. And with that in mind, I want to take just a moment to reiterate a couple of the more significant drivers that we see fueling our growth in the coming years.
First is the Internet of Things. This opportunity is measured in the tens of billions of units and projected to grow at an 83% CAGR through 2020. And our success here has been borne out by a broad and a growing list of wins in new markets like automotive, medical, industrial, wearables and the smart home. Today, we participate in all of these verticals to our suite of connectivity solutions, which now includes support for low-power, for wide area networking, for Wi-Fi, ZigBee, Bluetooth and GPS standards. Our design win pipeline provides a number of tangible examples of our success in this market. In fact, in this quarter alone, we landed new opportunities which include vehicle-to-vehicle communication systems with Cadillac's 2017 platform; GPS-based industrial tracking devices for Iotera; a new connected home hub designed -- for a leading online realtor -- retailer; Cat-M solutions for machine-to-machine applications in a variety of end markets; connectivity modules and set-top boxes for Ares; temperature control systems for multiple smart home solutions; analog ICs supporting new Smartwatch platforms; and 16 Skyworks devices in Cisco's latest large enterprise access point systems.
The second major growth theme for us is the skyrocketing demand for data -- wireless data, which is being fueled by a growing number of applications like streaming media, like mobile advertising, virtual reality and cloud-based services across consumer and enterprise applications. These services are all in -- and they consume a tremendous amount of bandwidth drastically increasing demands on networks and on devices. As sophisticated as today's devices are, they're simply not good enough to support the immense data requirements of these types of new applications which will be rolling out over the next few years. To address this performance gap, OEMs today are incrementing techniques like carrier aggregation, received diversity, MIMO and ultimately 5G, which require dramatically higher levels of analog performance at the semiconductor level.
As a technology enabler to these system upgrades, our addressable content per device is rising, driving TAM growth well in excess of the broader semiconductor space. Both of these secular growth teams are playing out for us in real time. And we're capitalizing by combining a strategic focus on higher value-added integrated solutions with unrivaled scale, advanced manufacturing capabilities and a deep system-level know-how. This is the key reason that we are consistently delivering among the best financial returns in the semiconductor sector in a variety of market conditions.
In closing, looking past the near-term volatility, we have created a unique and a robust business model, fueled by the proliferation of connectivity and combining above-market topline growth, healthy cash flow and the financial returns of a best-in-class diversified analog company.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, let's open the line, please.

componenttext: Well, hi, Rick. as you mentioned in the prepared remarks, I think it's normally a seasonal and a transitional period for us. Now it's a little bit challenging this year for a couple of reasons and it's with our largest customer, right? Unlike prior years, units will be down year-over-year really for the first time. And they're also absorbing some excess inventory which adds a headwind. So I think as we absorb that issue, outside of this, we expect all other areas of the business to be very strong. We think our revenue will be up over 10% when we exclude this customer. We're seeing strength at Samsung on G7, growth in China. Our broad markets business will be up 15% to 20% on a year-over-year basis. So we're obviously not immune to other significant reductions from this customer. But I think we'll fair better than most and we'll continue to focus on returns for the business.

componenttextpreview: Hi, Rick. This is Don. One of the things, if you look at what the forecasts continued to change in this quarter and one of the things you see is that our inventory is up a little bit but it normally would be up for us, and that's you're seeing there where
componenttext: Hi, Rick. This is Don. One of the things, if you look at what the forecasts continued to change in this quarter and one of the things you see is that our inventory is up a little bit but it normally would be up for us, and that's you're seeing there where we discontinued the product. It was a lot easier to do that in the short term than to worry about taking labor out and making changes, so that will make sense for us. So as far as going forward -- so our fabs and our Mexicali facility were pretty much a utilization. And we don't expect that to change a lot going forward. So the margin improvement you're seeing is just a more normal improvement that we would build off of the product mix that we're shipping. So I wouldn't expect a big change because of that.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Just on a big picture, if you look at the RF TAM markets for 2016 and 2017, obviously with Apple going through its product transition, softer demand in the premier tier, that's impacting the growth for 2016. Do you still see this growth in the market as a midteens CAGR? And do you think it would reaccelerate in 2017 or do you think the industry can be below 10% growth this year?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think in -- there's -- Mike, there's some positives and negatives going on in the current environment, right? On the positive side, answering the growth question, we continue to see our content go up with each and every degeneration. This year is
componenttext: Sure. I think in -- there's -- Mike, there's some positives and negatives going on in the current environment, right? On the positive side, answering the growth question, we continue to see our content go up with each and every degeneration. This year is no different. No different. We're probably more functionality into our integrated mobile systems, we're expanding our footprint with more functionality. And in fact, we're continuing to see fewer competitors who are able to consolidate share. Our IoT business, as we mentioned in the prepared comments, is up both sequentially and year-over-year and these are very positive tailwinds. I think '16 is a little bit of a unique year because you're going to see some high-level smartphone softness given the global macroeconomic choppiness. And, of course, as we discussed with our top customer, there's overall unit sales decline in the second half of the year, which gives unfavorable comps. And of course, there aggressively ramping down the legacy model so it creates an inventory burn. So I think 2016, we have as a phenomenon and I suspect as you go through the second half of 2016 will be much more positive. We'll start to see some strong sequential growth in '17. I do absolutely see growth in the overall RF and analog TAM being double digits year-over-year.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vivek, thanks for the question. We think it's diversification 2 ways. First of all, we have been consistently diversifying our business. We've used M&A each year since we formed the company to continue to look for more functionality, more relevance to the
componenttext: Vivek, thanks for the question. We think it's diversification 2 ways. First of all, we have been consistently diversifying our business. We've used M&A each year since we formed the company to continue to look for more functionality, more relevance to the broad market sector, more content in both mobile and our broad markets business. And most recent addition of was filters prior to that, call it management, Wi-Fi and the like. So we view acquisitions as an important element of our growth. We are selective. We don't need to by growth. What we need to do is continue to look for ways to differentiate ourselves and our target markets. So you should look for us to continue to add strategically acquisitions that make sense and they'll primarily be as you mentioned in the diversification, driving diversification into more markets and more content in new markets.

componenttext: Yes, thank you. And I'm glad you brought that particular platform. The customer's Huawei and their flagship model. And we have over $9 in content quality. And I'm particularly pleased by the fact that it's low, mid and high band PAD, this power management pretty sophisticated switching architectures we're controlling. We're using an architecture that's allowing us to control power management levels and voltage across all bands where we're starting to see the ability to take a very sophisticated module and integrate using different approaches. Much lower current consuming functions. And we're incorporating things like temperature compensated SAW, -- SAW bulk acoustic devices. And it's an architecture that our customers see simply as being elegance easy for them to use in the sense it's by highly indicated. It tunes up with the antenna and save some point of current inside. And we'll absolutely will see that the customers the and architectural approaches will be customized for different markets that you'll see continued to contribute to our gross margin. But a bit of a more of a winner-take-all capability because it's so easy for our customers to use and far fewer competitors.

And you see that, for instance, on the margin line where we just guided at 51%. So we're up sequentially at margin even though we are down some in revenue. componenttext: Question on carrier aggregation. David, you like to talk about ramping -- next year. if you can share the update on what are the plans on how you can kind of plan to ramp that? Are you looking to licensing that technology or you have that in-house? And then I have a follow-up?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you, Atif. I'm glad you asked that question. I'm going to take it may be a two-pronged approach to it. First, the details are that when we look at the carrier aggregation requirements for the advanced switching, with the tuning, with the module
componenttext: Yes, thank you, Atif. I'm glad you asked that question. I'm going to take it may be a two-pronged approach to it. First, the details are that when we look at the carrier aggregation requirements for the advanced switching, with the tuning, with the module capabilities that you require different band aggregation and combination that are quite challenging to our customers, there's a lot of content expansion. And so what we've been doing is we're leveraging a lot of in-house filter expertise. You ask specific about filters and intellectual property. We've been making investments in foundry partnerships to support bulk acoustic technologies, plus we have our own increasingly high piquancy temperature compensated SAW. So we'll continue -- you'll continue to see wins at the higher frequencies. And the SkyBlue system architecture allows for more content because we are able to control all the system parameters in a way that they get the current consumption and they're able to do with and we're tuning it quite -- in a quite sophisticate of a between the end amplifiers and switches, the filters and obviously the antenna on the transmit side. But if you take a step back, our customers truly don't care what the process technology is in those filters. What they want is current, they need size, they need them to market, obviously they need overall component performance. So I think over time the question of what filter technology is chosen, which band will be less relevant and what will be relevant to will be being able to have a system architecture that provides the kind of current that they need to have the functionality that their customers demand.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon, and welcome to Skyworks Solutions Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. 
At this time, I will turn the call over to Steve Ferranti, Vice President of Investor Relations for Skyworks. Mr. Ferranti, please go ahead.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks' Second Fiscal Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me today are Dave Aldrich, Don Palette and Liam Griffin. Dave will begin today's call with a business overview, followed by Don's fina
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks' Second Fiscal Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me today are Dave Aldrich, Don Palette and Liam Griffin. Dave will begin today's call with a business overview, followed by Don's financial review and outlook. We will then open the lines for your questions.
Please note that our comments today will include statements relating to future results that are forward-looking as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially and adversely from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including but not limited to, those noted in our earnings release and those detailed from time to time in our SEC filings.
I'd also like to remind everyone that the results and guidance we will discuss today are from our non-GAAP income statement, consistent with the format we've used in the past. Please refer to our press release within the Investor Relations section of our company website for a complete reconciliation to GAAP. 
With that, I will turn over the call to Dave for his comments on the quarter.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and welcome, everyone. Well, we delivered another solid financial performance for the second fiscal quarter of 2016, posting year-over-year growth in revenue, profitability and earnings, even as we navigated through a combination of invento
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and welcome, everyone. Well, we delivered another solid financial performance for the second fiscal quarter of 2016, posting year-over-year growth in revenue, profitability and earnings, even as we navigated through a combination of inventory adjustments and forecast reductions at one of our major customers.
During the quarter, we delivered revenue of $775 million, that's in line with our guidance. And posted gross margin of 50.8%, that's up 410 basis points year-over-year. We generated operating income of $285 million, that's up 10% year-over-year. We produced operating margin of 36.8%. And we provided $1.25 in earnings per share, that's up 9% versus the prior year.
For the first half of fiscal 2016, we generated roughly $383 million in free cash flow, redistributing over 60% or $234 million to shareholders through our dividend plan and our share repurchase activity.
Q2 was a solid quarter, highlighting the strong execution of our team and the robustness of our financial model. Our gross margin initiatives and operating expense discipline enabled us to both expand margins and earnings in the seasonally down quarter.
The market environment remains challenging entering the third fiscal quarter. The June quarter is normally a transitional period in our sector, bridging the March quarter's seasonal trough with the stronger second half of the calendar year. This year, inventory drawdowns and slower sell-through trends at our top customer are providing a drag on overall demand levels, impacting our Q3 guidance despite our strong growth in broad markets and with other OEMs.
As we navigate through this customer's -- through these customer-specific dynamics, our competitive position and our financial model remained quite strong. We continue to improve our gross margins and our overall financial returns while investing aggressively in innovation and in capacity. It's also worth emphasizing a couple of important points. First, among our top customers, we see complexity and increasing performance requirements driving content expansion across the board. As an example, our overall content on Samsung's flagship Galaxy S7 platform is up 20% versus prior models. We've also secured more than $9 of content within Huawei's new flagship smartphone platforms, helping to drive over 40% year-over-year growth with this customer.
Secondly, we continue to be highly successful in leading the market transition toward integrated solutions, and we're consolidating share while extending our technology leadership.
And third, we continue to see significant traction with the Internet of Things, as evidenced by our 18% year-over-year growth in our broad markets product segment. These factors give us a high confidence in our longer-term growth prospects. 
And before providing more specifics on the market environment, I'll turn the call over to Don for more in-depth review of our financial results.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and thanks for joining us, everyone. We appreciate it. Revenue for the second quarter was $775.1 million, and that's in line with our guidance and up 1.7% versus the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $393.6 million or 50.8% of revenue, in l
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and thanks for joining us, everyone. We appreciate it. Revenue for the second quarter was $775.1 million, and that's in line with our guidance and up 1.7% versus the year-ago quarter. Gross profit was $393.6 million or 50.8% of revenue, in line with our guidance and up 410 basis points from the second quarter of fiscal 2015. Operating expenses were $108.6 million, consisting of R&D expense of $73.1 million and SG&A expense of $35.5 million.
We generated $285 million of operating income, up 10% from the year-ago quarter, and that translates into a 36.8% operating margin. Our cash tax rate was 14.3%, resulting in net income of $242.3 million or $1.25 of diluted earnings per share, and that's $0.01 ahead of our guidance and represents around a 9% year-over-year earnings growth.
Turning to our second quarter balance sheet and cash flow statement. We invested $37 million in capital expenditures. And with depreciation of $53.6 million, we generated $154.5 million in cash flow from operations. And we exited the quarter with roughly $1.2 billion in cash on hand and no debt. We also repurchased 2 million shares of our common stock during the quarter at an average price of just over $67.50 a share. Given our confidence in our long-term business trends, we expect to continue to be very active with our share repurchase activity at current levels.
Moving to product mix. For the second quarter of fiscal 2016, power amplifiers represented 17% of revenue; integrated mobile systems was 58%; and broad markets was 25%. We saw healthy growth in both integrated mobile systems and broad markets. We're quite pleased that our broad markets portfolio grew over 18% year-over-year in the second quarter. We continue to expect IMS to remain our strongest growth segment, followed by broad markets, while power amplifier products continue to decline as a percentage of our revenue as the market shifts toward higher-value integrated solutions.
Now for our third quarter business outlook. We expect third quarter revenue to be approximately $750 million, with softness at our largest customer being partially offset by strong year-over-year growth at Samsung in China and across the broad markets. At this revenue level, we suggest modeling gross margin at 51%, with operating expenses flat to Q2 at approximately $108.5 million.
It is worth noting that our Q3 gross margin guidance implies a 200 basis point improvement versus the prior year. Our strong gross margin outlook in the face of current market conditions highlight the benefits of our higher-value integrated systems, along with our scale and flexible manufacturing operations.
Looking ahead, we see opportunity for additional margin improvement as we continue to ramp our custom solutions and leverage our recent capital investments. As a guideline, we recommend modeling a 60% incremental gross margin off of the third quarter baseline. We continue to target a goal of at least 53% gross margin for the company and have a number of initiatives in place to accelerate our progress towards achieving this goal.
And below the line, we anticipate around $1 million in interest and other expenses and a cash tax rate between 14.5% to 15%. We project our tax rate to remain in this range for the remainder of our 2016 fiscal year. And we expect share count to be around 192.5 million shares, which results in a third quarter EPS of $1.21.
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Dave.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Well, I'm very pleased by the resilience of our financial model in spite of the well-publicized market challenges to our near-term top line growth. And even more importantly, I'm highly confident that the underlying technology themes fueling
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Well, I'm very pleased by the resilience of our financial model in spite of the well-publicized market challenges to our near-term top line growth. And even more importantly, I'm highly confident that the underlying technology themes fueling our long-term growth remain quite positive. And we're fortunate to be levered to powerful secular technology trends, and we've spent of the last decade aligning the company to capitalize on these. And with that in mind, I want to take just a moment to reiterate a couple of the more significant drivers that we see fueling our growth in the coming years.
First is the Internet of Things. This opportunity is measured in the tens of billions of units and projected to grow at an 83% CAGR through 2020. And our success here has been borne out by a broad and a growing list of wins in new markets, like automotive, medical, industrial, wearables and the smart home. Today, we participate in all of these verticals through our suite of connectivity solutions, which now includes support for low-power, for wide area networking, for Wi-Fi, ZigBee, Bluetooth and GPS standards. 
Our design win pipeline provides a number of tangible examples of our success in this market. In fact, in this quarter alone, we landed new opportunities, which include: Vehicle-to-vehicle communication systems with Cadillac's 2017 platform; GPS-based industrial tracking devices for Iotera; a new connected home hub designed -- for a leading online realtor -- retailer; Cat-M solutions for machine-to-machine applications in a variety of end markets; connectivity modules and set-top boxes for Arris; temperature control systems for multiple smart home solutions; analog ICs supporting new Smartwatch platforms; and 16 Skyworks devices in Cisco's latest large enterprise access point systems.
The second major growth theme for us is the skyrocketing demand for data -- wireless data, which is being fueled by a growing number of new applications, like streaming media, like mobile advertising, virtual reality and cloud-based services across consumer and enterprise applications. These services are all in their infancy, and they consume a tremendous amount of bandwidth, drastically increasing demands on networks and on devices. As sophisticated as today's devices are, they're simply not good enough to support the immense data requirements of these types of new applications which will be rolling out over the next few years. To address this performance gap, OEMs today are implementing techniques like carrier aggregation, receive diversity, MIMO and ultimately 5G, which require dramatically higher levels of analog performance at the semiconductor level. As a technology enabler to these system upgrades, our addressable content per device is rising, driving TAM growth well in excess of the broader semiconductor space. 
Both of these secular growth teams are playing out for us in real time, and we're capitalizing by combining a strategic focus on higher-value-added integrated solutions with unrivaled scale, advanced manufacturing capabilities and a deep system-level know-how. This is the key reason that we are consistently delivering among the best financial returns in the semiconductor sector in a variety of market conditions.
In closing, looking past the near-term volatility, we've created a unique and a robust business model, fueled by the proliferation of connectivity and combining above-market topline growth, healthy cash flow and the financial returns of a best-in-class diversified analog company.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, let's open the line, please.

componenttext: Well, Rick. As we mentioned in the prepared remarks, I think June is normally a seasonal and a transitional period for us. Now it's a little bit challenging this year for a couple of reasons, and it's with our largest customer, right? Unlike prior years, units will be down year-over-year, really, for the first time. And they're also absorbing some excess inventory, which adds a headwind. So I think as we absorb that issue, outside of this, we expect all other areas of the business to be very strong. We think our revenue will be up over 10% when we exclude this customer. We're seeing strength at Samsung on G7, growth in China. Our broad markets business will be up 15% to 20% on a year-over-year basis. So we're obviously not immune, though, to significant reductions from this customer, but I think we'll fare better than most, and we'll continue to focus on returns to the business.
