headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, as we discussed in the prepared remarks, a lot of that inventory is filter-driven, and really, filters that are designed into known programs with known ramps in the second half on not only transmit solutions, but also receipt-side technologies
componenttext: Sure. Well, as we discussed in the prepared remarks, a lot of that inventory is filter-driven, and really, filters that are designed into known programs with known ramps in the second half on not only transmit solutions, but also receipt-side technologies, some GPS technologies and an expanding set of customers now that will be taking those filters and though solutions into their applications. So the lion's share of that material, that inventory of largely filters is really lined up relative to second half ramps with known customers so and a very clear demand curve.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just follow up, we know generically on the inventory, just keep in mind that that inventory growth that you're seeing into Q3 is -- supports the second half of. Volumes were up about 11% quarter-over-quarter, and there's growth as we continue to fisca
componenttext: And just follow up, we know generically on the inventory, just keep in mind that that inventory growth that you're seeing into Q3 is -- supports the second half of. Volumes were up about 11% quarter-over-quarter, and there's growth as we continue to fiscal Q1 of '17. There are multiple things that Liam was talking about burning the inventory down. I'm just going to give you summary of why the level's where it's at. At the level, we were level-loading factories to meet that second half demand. The share gains in filters, especially silicon, is driven by new programs. There's specific growth designed with some ramps and there's essentially no risk with any of -- risk with this inventory. We also had a new hub arrangement for large customer in Asia. That's a onetime stocking bump in inventory. some of the projected product mix into Q4 just has longer lead times for some of the outsourced materials, and it's primarily silicon wafer. So the bottom line, we're very confident in the decline going forward and getting the turns back towards historical levels. this is a short-term issue that we're working through based on those dynamics.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. As a follow-up, I guess with the -- given the buyback, could you just maybe run through some of your thoughts on M&A and your strategy on diversification via M&A?
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. As a follow-up, I guess with the -- given the buyback, could you just maybe run through some of your thoughts on M&A and your strategy on diversification via M&A?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean we, first and foremost, committed to running our core business. And we think there's great opportunity to leverage not only our strength in mobile. But now you're hearing more and more our opportunities in broad market, specifically IoT. So w
componenttext: Sure. I mean we, first and foremost, committed to running our core business. And we think there's great opportunity to leverage not only our strength in mobile. But now you're hearing more and more our opportunities in broad market, specifically IoT. So we are committed to that. Now in parallel, we have the disciplined view on M&A, but we are looking at potential opportunities. We'll share more with you as they come about. But we're focused on our core, but have the powder, the balance sheet and the opportunity to augment that with M&A as needed.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the first one, Liam, I was wondering if you could just give us a sense of the overall demand environment. Obviously the industry has come through in inventory correction at your largest customer. are we past all of those problems, and now we should st
componenttext: For the first one, Liam, I was wondering if you could just give us a sense of the overall demand environment. Obviously the industry has come through in inventory correction at your largest customer. are we past all of those problems, and now we should start to expect more normalized growth, if you could address that? And then also if you could take it more broadly to the trends you're seeing at your Korean and Chinese customers. I think basically, I think investors want to understand, are we past some of the issues we saw on the first half and it's a more normalized growth environment going forward? Or -- is the industry still struggling with a little bit of the inventory issues that came about in the first half?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vivek, I'll take both of those questions. Well yes, I mean we've been through a challenging first half of the calendar year, for sure. And I think that's been well-publicized and reflected in our numbers in the past. We are seeing improving conditio
componenttext: Sure, Vivek, I'll take both of those questions. Well yes, I mean we've been through a challenging first half of the calendar year, for sure. And I think that's been well-publicized and reflected in our numbers in the past. We are seeing improving conditions right now. We're seeing all of our Tier 1s grow. And more importantly, we are seeing our content position expand and their need for the content expand. So the dynamic around performance and our ability to resolve performance with system-level solution is coming together quite well. And you can see in the Sky, 10% to 11%, pretty solid guide up into Q4. We feel that that's sustainable. We expect -- So early for Q1, but we expect to be cup up again in Q1. so that's a broad statement. If you look at China and Samsung, both of those opportunities, China being more of broad opportunity with some of the flagship names like Huawei doing very, very well. And China will be one of our faster growing areas. Samsung, we've got content gains on the GS7. That's looking good this year. Samsung will be probably a 15%-plus account for us year-over-year. We're lining out for the GS8. So what you can look at here at a high level is this continuous need for performance and Skyworks' ability to address not only our core positions in SkyOne and some of the transmit chain, but also an increasing position in analog and increasing position in the receive side, WiFi and other technologies will allow us to grow our share.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and the next question comes from the line of Atif Malik Citigroup.
componenttext: Okay, and the next question comes from the line of Atif Malik Citigroup.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the gross margins. I mean, your gross margin is a smidge [ph] below the 51% guidance you gave, even with the higher revenue level and broad markets doing better. And your guidance of 51% is flat on higher revenue. Can you just talk about inc
componenttext: A question on the gross margins. I mean, your gross margin is a smidge [ph] below the 51% guidance you gave, even with the higher revenue level and broad markets doing better. And your guidance of 51% is flat on higher revenue. Can you just talk about incremental gross margins? We have not seen these lower committed gross margins in last [indiscernible] 6 quarters. Can you talk about the puts and takes on your gross margin line? And should we be thinking about 60% incremental gross margins moving forward and also a 53% midterm model that you have shared in the past? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. We'll talk about incremental contribution margin that we saw in Q3, being that that was a down revenue quarter, was actually a number that was very good, in the high 40s. And when you're in down revenue, you want the number to be below which yo
componenttext: Yes, sure. We'll talk about incremental contribution margin that we saw in Q3, being that that was a down revenue quarter, was actually a number that was very good, in the high 40s. And when you're in down revenue, you want the number to be below which you're [indiscernible] posting. So that's good. When you look at the guidance, we're at about 52.5% on an incremental basis. That's simply reflective of the backdrop, the unique elements that we highlighted in the Q4 inventory. Going forward when you're looking at our earnings model opportunity, the 53% is absolutely still our target. And we expect these incremental margins very, very quickly to get back to the 58% kind of level, which is what we have communicated externally. So there's no issues there. We're just working through the inventory issues and the tough backdrop issues that Liam mentioned, but nothing else specific.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then you mentioned in your prepared remarks about the low, mid and high socket wins in the Huawei phone. just talk about why we don't see you in mid- and high band in some of the other flagship models in India, Korea in the U.S. and if you guys
componenttext: Great. And then you mentioned in your prepared remarks about the low, mid and high socket wins in the Huawei phone. just talk about why we don't see you in mid- and high band in some of the other flagship models in India, Korea in the U.S. and if you guys are planning to get to those sockets, maybe the specifications of the microphones different than those other device?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, that's a great question. So first off, I will tell you we are encroaching some the mid- and high bands organically with enhanced performance in our [indiscernible] factory. as noted the prepared remarks, we shipped over 2.5 billion filters, all o
componenttext: Yes, no, that's a great question. So first off, I will tell you we are encroaching some the mid- and high bands organically with enhanced performance in our [indiscernible] factory. as noted the prepared remarks, we shipped over 2.5 billion filters, all of which were consumed by our system solution. So we are not a discrete filter company. Having said that, our performance levels not only with the filter, but the entirety of the system, so if you think about what customers want from us, as they want solutions that resolve this tremendous complexity. And the solutions from Skyworks are really system-level. include our own gallium arsenide HBT process we have in-house, our SOI process, our deep IP and switching, our ability to craft MCMs for very, very low loss in high efficiency, delivering a complete module. So our modules can often include our own TC SAW. We've been able to move the TC frequency up to mid-band. And in some cases, if there frequencies are not applicable for TC SAW we can address by foundry partners for [indiscernible]. So that's what you're seeing now in the Huawei phone. I think you'll continue to see us extend our reach and frequency and continue to do customers want, really simplify solutions, give them the best end-to-end efficiency and the best systems-level performance.

componenttext: Yes, and then also just recall that we've 3x the size of our filter franchise of to speak. When we get the deal with Panasonic we had 1 site in [indiscernible]. We've added a large site in Osaka. We have many more customers now engaged with us with filter-based solutions. So running that larger factory, running that larger footprint in high-performance filters, there's more WIP, there's more inventory and there's were programs by which we're going to sell into. That's the difference when you look at year-over-year. The size of our filter franchise is quite a bit bigger. The number of customers that we address is quite a bit larger. And specifically in the second half calendar year, you are going to see that action come to bear. And we're going to see the inventories come down as well.

componenttext: sorry. One thing that I wanted to add, too, when you look at the bill that we have this queue, it's all raw materials and WIP. There's literally no finished goods build, very little. So that supports the future growth opportunity.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think I mean for the most part if you look at the quarter here, we're speaking Q4 guide, we are still -- there's still headwind in some ways of mix, legacy mix SAW really hasn't come to bear. but we factored that in. We are seeing overall growth.
componenttext: Well, I think I mean for the most part if you look at the quarter here, we're speaking Q4 guide, we are still -- there's still headwind in some ways of mix, legacy mix SAW really hasn't come to bear. but we factored that in. We are seeing overall growth. If you were to exclude our largest customer, we're up 10% to 12% year-over-year in the quarter. So some of the headwinds with our larger customers still are reflected in our numbers. We are growing the noncore business quite well. That's IoT. That's diversity received technologies new for us. WiFi business is strong. All those portfolio look very good on a year-over-year basis. And we're starting to get out of the inventory hole that we mentioned with some of our larger customers. And things definitely look better in the second half with respect to that.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Liam, on broad markets, we had a very strong quarter in June despite the divestiture [indiscernible]. can you just talk about the trajectory [indiscernible] in September?

componenttextpreview: Yes, would be up a little bit in September, probably 5% to 8%. I will tell you this though. Within broad market, IoT is -- will be up 10% to 15%. And year-over-year, IoT is probably headed for high teens. So within the broad market space, what you have th
componenttext: Yes, would be up a little bit in September, probably 5% to 8%. I will tell you this though. Within broad market, IoT is -- will be up 10% to 15%. And year-over-year, IoT is probably headed for high teens. So within the broad market space, what you have there, Blayne, is some markets are doing quite well IoT. We also have some legacy markets like infrastructure that are great markets and have super margin, but just have been flattish in terms of top line. So the blend together looks good, but IoT is a sweet spot within broad. It's really special for us right now.

componenttext: As you introduced a whole bunch of new products here such as digital attenuators and tuning, et cetera. Can you talk a little bit about how much of your content on the phone now comes from outside of pad [ph] type device? I know there's lots of SKUs and there. just trying to get a sense of how broad you're getting now across the phone outside of some more classic parts?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, that's a great -- I don't have an exact stat for you. But I will tell you, it's definitely increased over the last year and it will increase in the second half of this year. Some examples you've mentioned us talk about diversity received. I mean,
componenttext: Yes, no, that's a great -- I don't have an exact stat for you. But I will tell you, it's definitely increased over the last year and it will increase in the second half of this year. Some examples you've mentioned us talk about diversity received. I mean, this is some real elegant proprietary technology that Skyworks created. It levers filter technology. levers our low and mid amplifier expertise, our switching again, that configurability with our own MCM. Great technology, and what it does is just tremendous, tremendous improvements in the developments portion of the phone. And if you think about the way typical usage cases on the phone, downlink is critical. So we provide a great enhancement to downlink speed. That's one area that is relatively new for us and should be a big growth driver. Some of the SkyBlue technology with you mentioned before is unique for us, driving power efficiency through the system. We've had WiFi for quite a while, but now we're starting to see is MIMO [ph] WiFi in some of the leading flagship phones our content virtually can double with MIMO. A lot of good things happening in ATtuning and other point, GPS for location-based services. you think about we've talked about the ecosystem with some of the big tech players now engaged in mobile. A lot of these are involved in payment. They want to know exactly where people are, precise location. We have a GPS portfolio now that is really emerging and increasing attach rate with some of our customers. all of those things blend in. And you're seeing definitely a larger increase in kind of the nontraditional pad business, although that remains core, but a bigger swing now to some of these newer devices.

componenttext: Yes, absolutely. Okay, I get your question now. Certainly, we get to the second half year. Obviously we're coming off of $752 million, 10% up. We expect to be up again in Q1. We don't have a full guide yet for that quarter. But I think when we get into the March quarter, we should we back on track with year-over-year growth. I mean also just to remind you, I think we mentioned before. But even in the September quarter, we're looking at comparable levels of operating income percentage, so comparable levels of profitability even at lower revenue. So it has been a challenging period for us, last couple of quarters. But I think you can see some financial discipline here, at least in the P&L.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Filters, you mentioned over 200 -- or 2 billion of those filters, but probably like 37 are TC SAW. Is the big expansion in Panasonic's facility all for TC SAW, Liam? Or would you get into the SAW manufacturing? And if you do, how is that going to impact your GM? because I know think you find this in the outside world now? And then the second question, the competitive environment when you're done, please.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, great question. Yes, the filters we produce is far largely been TC SAW. And as you know well, I mean that is a flavor of high-performance filters that's in high demand. And it's allowed us to lever that up into SkyOne systems for low, and in some
componenttext: Yes, no, great question. Yes, the filters we produce is far largely been TC SAW. And as you know well, I mean that is a flavor of high-performance filters that's in high demand. And it's allowed us to lever that up into SkyOne systems for low, and in some cases, mid-band. served us very well. Now going back to standard SAW filters is easy. It's fewer process. eliminate the silicon dioxide plating. It's a cheaper process for us. And you are correct that we do still spend quite a bit of money outside for a third-party source. there's potential opportunity for us to bring that in-house. finally, that site in Osaka has the ability. It's a phenomenal site, class 10 clean room, beautiful facility. And we do have the opportunity to expand further and higher frequencies if needed.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you're clearly #1 in TC saw, but by a distant margin here. sounds like your expansion plans are going to be even further. the competitive environment, I mean it seems like it's shifting pretty dramatically here. Marotta [ph] stated it's los
componenttext: Okay. And then you're clearly #1 in TC saw, but by a distant margin here. sounds like your expansion plans are going to be even further. the competitive environment, I mean it seems like it's shifting pretty dramatically here. Marotta [ph] stated it's losing share to your largest customer this year, and it looks like that's all to you. you're also splitting [indiscernible] with [indiscernible]. you did that do last year. [indiscernible] also entered the DRx section in Samsung when they weren't last year. So how do you see, Liam, the competitive environment shaking out in say, calendar 2017? Are the Japanese firm which are disappearing, and you guys got Panasonic [indiscernible]. Are they going to disappear faster than, say, [indiscernible] in of these sockets? And is all this going to be kind of footnote to overall TAM growth in the RF section in '17? I'm just trying to get your view of the bigger picture.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, let's that's a lot. Let me try to help you with that. So I'll tell you what we see. We see the performance nodes going up and up and up, with each successive generation would be our largest customer over the next 2 or 3 down, we really see that
componenttext: Yes, yes, let's that's a lot. Let me try to help you with that. So I'll tell you what we see. We see the performance nodes going up and up and up, with each successive generation would be our largest customer over the next 2 or 3 down, we really see that happening. And that's actually -- that's propelled our growth more than anything. Our ability to hit challenging architectures and do it with profitable solutions and integrated solutions served us very, very well. We're confident that you'll be able to see content gains with all of the leading accounts, regardless of partitioning. We are agnostic to [indiscernible]. We work with Qualcomm. We work with Intel. We work with MediaTek, high silicon, all of those players. And so we don't expect any issue with that. But yes, competitively, the companies that can hit the performance and the companies that can do that elegantly and unburden our customers with these daunting challenges that they're facing, those are the ones that are going to win and will be at the top of that list. I mean, that's the whole essence of Skyworks, to try to drive a strategy around performance, integrate as much as we can, work with our customers, listen to what they need. It may be different. Every account wants something different, but be flexible enough, leveraging our internal capabilities, leveraging Mexicali [ph] for highly configurable devices, picking the right flavor of filter, but really looking at systems performance from input to output. If we do that well, our business will follow.

componenttext: Maybe just continuing on that theme with your expansion in capacity and really seeing significant expansion in [indiscernible] and Broadcom as well. Are you concerned at all about the supply-demand balance of this industry as we  I mean [indiscernible] over the next few quarters?

componenttextpreview: Yes, Cody, xim it's funny if you look at what is happening in these devices now, it is incredible, the filter count that is absolutely required by our customers, and just by virtue of the crowded spectrum that we see. So there's going to be I think a shak
componenttext: Yes, Cody, xim it's funny if you look at what is happening in these devices now, it is incredible, the filter count that is absolutely required by our customers, and just by virtue of the crowded spectrum that we see. So there's going to be I think a shake on who's going to and who isn't going to invest in how we put those filters in complete systems. Our customers really are less interested in buying discrete components today and more interested in those highly efficient engines that we spoke off. So we're very confident with our ability to address, and as you know from history with Skyworks, we're very disciplined in our CapEx and we're careful with where we invest. So we certainly know where our strategic is going and our ability to win. And with respect our competition, we've competed with [indiscernible] and Corvo [ph] and others for years and years. and we certainly like our outlook at Skyworks.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just trying to get into a more clearer picture on the September guide, I know you've been asked and answered these those questions about inventory. But do you believe that you're still dealing with anything that's either causing you to be conservative
componenttext: And just trying to get into a more clearer picture on the September guide, I know you've been asked and answered these those questions about inventory. But do you believe that you're still dealing with anything that's either causing you to be conservative or weighing a bit on that 10% 11% guide? You've got obviously there are major customer builds that you're prepping for. You've got some seasonality happening. You've got what appears to be relatively healthy market in China. Maybe I think I'm just a bit surprised that this wasn't a bit stronger guide.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, I mean, 10% to 11% is I think a pretty healthy move up for us. Yes, there has been of course some lingering effects of legacy platforms that we've had to manage through, and -- that is be managed through. So all of that is reflected in the numb
componenttext: Sure. Yes, I mean, 10% to 11% is I think a pretty healthy move up for us. Yes, there has been of course some lingering effects of legacy platforms that we've had to manage through, and -- that is be managed through. So all of that is reflected in the numbers. I'll tell you one thing we need to highlight here again is absent our largest customer, we're up 10% to 12% year-over-year. And also across mobile, we are specifically expanding our content reach. It was a question that was asked earlier on the call. But the percentage of revenue we derive in mobile with technologies that are really more like analog mixed-signal, that percentage is going up. IoT business looks very strong right. our broad business looks -- very strong. It's been a tough opening 2 quarters of the calendar year, quite frankly. And we're coming out of that now. Is there some lingering headwinds that, that reflect in the number? Yes, possibly so, but that's in the guide.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Just [indiscernible] on China, could you talk about how much was it up in June? Do you expect it to be up in the September quarter? What present China makes for your business total revenues? And what you think the inventory in the channel looks like into China?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tony. Well at a high level, China is about 25% of our company revenue. And they were up sequentially more than 10%. They look good in the second half calendar year. I think one of the accounts that we highlighted in the prepared remarks was Huawei.
componenttext: Sure, Tony. Well at a high level, China is about 25% of our company revenue. And they were up sequentially more than 10%. They look good in the second half calendar year. I think one of the accounts that we highlighted in the prepared remarks was Huawei. We've got a great position there, not only with the P9 phone we mentioned, but the honor [ph] series and others. There's also another opportunity in China I think most of you know. But China is a tremendous export player to the rest of the world, and there is still 2 billion to 3 billion people out there will have no connectivity. And so we are able to feed through our partnerships with MediaTek and Spreadtrum and even high silicon that that often make models will go to India, the Middle East, Africa and some of the other emerging markets. And so we look good there. The recent numbers in China have been strong. We're also seeing -- I think some of these came through some of our peer group's calls as well. We are seeing a move towards 5 mode from 3 modes, so that increases our content. The recent carrier data shows a better pickup in 4G, LTE. That's good. So for the most part, China's been actually really an improving story here in the last few months.

componenttext: This is Colin . China, we also heard others talk about strength in China recently. Are you concerned about overbuilding there, given the strength in China?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no, we're not concerned about overbuilding. We have -- one of the larger accounts we have in China now, we've moved to a hub arrangement, which is again part of the inventory issue. But it's fully lined up. you can't overbuild in that environment.
componenttext: No, no, no, we're not concerned about overbuilding. We have -- one of the larger accounts we have in China now, we've moved to a hub arrangement, which is again part of the inventory issue. But it's fully lined up. you can't overbuild in that environment. basically meet your customers' hub needs. pull the open market, broad customers in China. We work very closely with MediaTek and some of the other baseband partners to get a broad forecast. Some of the solutions that we sell into that ecosystem are fungible. So they can be sold to multiple customers. That will net out the puts and takes of kind of broader market within China. But no, we feel very, very solid about the inventory dynamics and revenue dynamics with respect to China. We've been in that market for a long time. We were a 2G player, a 3G player. And now actually with 4G and our ability to expand reach, the market for us now is probably the best it's ever been.

So as far as velocity of the inventory, you're going to see is to get back here very, very quickly.

componenttext: No, we feel very positive about the growth in dollar content. And I said it a couple of times already in the call, it's really twofold. And you'll see that more and out by leading customers.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Liam, congratulations on your new position. One of the questions we get a lot from investors is about your [indiscernible] strategy or lack of it  How much of the upper-end slots and filters can TC SAW address? eventually, what would you guys have to do t
componenttext: Liam, congratulations on your new position. One of the questions we get a lot from investors is about your [indiscernible] strategy or lack of it  How much of the upper-end slots and filters can TC SAW address? eventually, what would you guys have to do to be able to get to that upper level of filters?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, thanks, Harsh. as I outlined earlier, we can address the upper level of filters today. We just do it with foundry partners, for example. would love to be able to build it in-house, and that something that's not out of our reach. It just isn't there
componenttext: Sure, thanks, Harsh. as I outlined earlier, we can address the upper level of filters today. We just do it with foundry partners, for example. would love to be able to build it in-house, and that something that's not out of our reach. It just isn't there today. Our TC socket ability is has moved in frequency where it was largely just low band play, maybe 600, 900 meg. We now have technology well over 1 gig, getting close to 2 and 2.5 gig. again back to what I was mentioning before, we don't have an appetite for selling discrete filters. when we sell a filter, it is wrapped within a complete system. So the filter contributes some level of performance. But you also have your HBT, switch, MCM and your ability to minimize losses within your layout. So a lot -- and that -- with Skyworks, all of that I mentioned is controlled in-house. so think about us a system solutions player. Filters play a role in the system, but the entirety of the architecture is what matters. So we've won programs with Huawei. We're close with other customers. There may be a few opportunities where optimal filter performance is the #1 requirement. That may be the case for some of the discrete applications or maybe some super high-performance, high band sockets. Today, perhaps we can't address that. But we have the engineering talent, the filter assets and the people and other processes in place to continue to push that envelope and grow them.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. a follow-up, Liam, what is -- what are the 1 or 2 focus areas for you in the first 12 months of your CEO-hood?
componenttext: Great. a follow-up, Liam, what is -- what are the 1 or 2 focus areas for you in the first 12 months of your CEO-hood?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, sure, thanks. number one, we definitely want to continue this push by leveraging our core in mobile and taking advantage of this expanding opportunity that we mentioned, receive-side technology, WiFi technology, GPS, power management and others,
componenttext: Yes, yes, sure, thanks. number one, we definitely want to continue this push by leveraging our core in mobile and taking advantage of this expanding opportunity that we mentioned, receive-side technology, WiFi technology, GPS, power management and others, and try to create the same systems-level approach in that section that worked so well for us and SkyOne and in transmit. That's one. The second is stepping up in IoT. I mean, this is a market we talked about the last few years. We talked about broad market. But within that, the IoT landscape and the class of customers that we engage with today is phenomenal. And we have a unique opportunity because most of the players in IoT feature 1 or 2 connectivity topologies. We have WiFi. We have Bluetooth. We have ZigBee. We have low-power technology. We have power management. And we have a tremendous know-how on how to make connected things work and make them work wirelessly. So we are excited about that. We're going to put more resources around that part of our business. Some other opportunities have really come along nicely, albeit still quite small, are markets like automotive. We're being pulled into some of the premier players that we mentioned in the opening remarks, bringing in full LTE modules and automotive very high performance high reliability modules, that's looking good so we're going to fire on all of those cylinders and then for near continue to drive the best people in the best execution in our state.

componenttext: Yes, they come in very, very quickly, part of it when we talked about the inventory issue and the level-loading that's been going on. I mean even though the hybrid model serves us really well, we were able to pull, in a down quarter, we were able to pull production capacity and externally. We're still not, during this period, we aren't running completely full. So that's going to be something that's very quickly going to get us back up into the incremental margin track. And that's a big driver of this. the other thing is the new product launches as we move forward. We said we are very focused on every new generation of products going to provide incremental margins. that will all be in the mix as we move forward. We're excited about some of the IoT opportunity, as Liam talked about. So those are the things, that -- and we have a lot of confidence in the visibility to get down the road to the 53% target. That's still right in front of us, for sure.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the follow-up is for Liam. Liam, Skyworks I think has been well known for an above-industry average grower. It doesn't look like it's playing out that way this year, but we understand the challenges that exist with the large customer. The question is,
componenttext: And the follow-up is for Liam. Liam, Skyworks I think has been well known for an above-industry average grower. It doesn't look like it's playing out that way this year, but we understand the challenges that exist with the large customer. The question is, how patient will you be with the business in getting back to above-industry average growth organically? and at what point will you feel like you have to press for M&A to diversify the business and get back to some of the growth rates and relative growth rates that we're used to seeing from the company?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig. That's a great question. Well first of all, I am committed and have great confidence that the organic business, the organic franchise will be an outformer in terms of growth. Now we're bigger company than we were a couple of years ago. There'
componenttext: Sure, Craig. That's a great question. Well first of all, I am committed and have great confidence that the organic business, the organic franchise will be an outformer in terms of growth. Now we're bigger company than we were a couple of years ago. There's a some level of maturity in unit growth and in mobile, which has been the biggest market for us. But we're able to augment that with the share moves we've talked about. And think again about the usage case that the entities that use mobile technology and what they want, and it's daunting. I think be solid in core mobile. And I'm very comfortable with the opportunity with TAM, given some of the new architectures and road maps that we have visibility into. Broad market things to become much more of an IoT play for us. I think that's really what broad markets means now. we have great solutions for it. I think we need to put more people behind, more engineering and help folks behind that. That should work. parallel, in parallel, M&A is absolutely an opportunity for Skyworks. And we have a tremendous balance sheet. We generated a ton of cash. And I think we'll be able to do the right deal when it comes about. So -- but having said all of that, we're running the franchise, optimizing the franchise, doing every thing we can to continue to put the growth up, the margins up, and satisfy our customers. M&A is another area that we will continue to pursue.

I think that ultimately that's all going to level out at some point, so we're not too concerned about it. Again we have one of our larger customers now in Asia that is requiring a hub arrangement with us. So we have work to that, and that was actually part of our inventory here that Don mentioned.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the Skyworks Third Fiscal Quarter 2016 conference call. With me on the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Liam Griffin; and Chief Financial Officer, Don Palette. Before we begin, I would
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the Skyworks Third Fiscal Quarter 2016 conference call. With me on the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Liam Griffin; and Chief Financial Officer, Don Palette. 
Before we begin, I would like to remind everyone that our discussion will include statements relating to future results and expectations that are or may be considered forward-looking statements. Please refer to our earnings press release and other SEC filings, including our annual report on Form 10-Q, for information on certain risks that could cause actual outcomes to differ materially and adversely from any forward-looking statements made today. 
Additionally, the results and guidance we will discuss today are from our non-GAAP income statement, consistent with the format we have used in the past. Please refer to our press release within the Investor Relations section of our company website for a complete reconciliation to GAAP. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Liam.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mitch, and welcome, everyone. Q3 marked another quarter of solid execution on the part of the Skyworks team. We exceeded our guidance, returned over $240 million in cash to our shareholders and importantly, continued to broaden our design win pipe
componenttext:
Thanks, Mitch, and welcome, everyone. Q3 marked another quarter of solid execution on the part of the Skyworks team. We exceeded our guidance, returned over $240 million in cash to our shareholders and importantly, continued to broaden our design win pipeline, setting the stage for sustained market outperformance. 
Looking at the results in more detail, we delivered revenue of $752 million ahead of our guidance; expanded gross margins to 50.9%, up 190 basis points year-over-year; produced operating income of $275 million, with operating margins over 36%. Finally, we generated $1.24 in earnings per share, $0.03 above consensus.  Execution on revenue and margins, along with operating cost discipline, were all key elements of this performance. 
In addition to the strong financial results, we continue to gain broad market traction. Specifically during the quarter, we powered Huawei's P9 phone, incorporating 10 unique devices including our SkyOne systems across low, mid-and high bands; launched advanced carrier aggregation capabilities across a suite of premium and value tier accounts including Samsung, Motorola as well as Oppo, Vivo and ZTE. We secured design wins for Continental's 4G LTE automotive systems, captured a digital attenuator and multimode repeater designs at Audi, and enabled enterprise radio for Google's 3.5 gigahertz band ecosystem. 
We also achieved several other milestones, including surpassing production of 2 billion filters cumulatively from our joint venture with Panasonic; ramping SkyBlue innovative technology for enhanced power management in LED flash drivers; commencing volume production of proprietary diversity received solutions; and supporting the world's first headcam with LTE connectivity in 4k video streaming.
These major wins and others demonstrate our expanding customer and end market reach across both mobile platforms and the Internet of Things. 
At this point, I will turn the call over to Don for a more in-depth review of our financial results.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Liam, and thanks again for joining us, everyone. We appreciate it. Revenue for the third quarter was $751.7 million, and that's ahead of our guidance. Gross profit was $382.3 million or 50.9% of revenue, and that's in line with our guidance and
componenttext:
Thanks, Liam, and thanks again for joining us, everyone. We appreciate it. 
Revenue for the third quarter was $751.7 million, and that's ahead of our guidance. Gross profit was $382.3 million or 50.9% of revenue, and that's in line with our guidance and up 190 basis points from the third quarter last year. Operating expenses were $107.6 million. That consists of R&D expense of $70.2 million and SG&A expense of $37.4 million. We generated $274.7 million of operating income, translating into a 36.5% operating margin. 
Our cash tax rate was 12.7%, resulting in net income of $238.1 million or $1.24 diluted earnings per share, $0.03 ahead of our guidance. Our cash tax rate is now projected lower for fiscal 2016 at 14%. The Q3 rate was favorably impacted by a year-to-date adjustment from the prior 14% -- 14.7% annual rate. 
Turning to a summary of our third fiscal quarter cash flow metrics, we invested $57 million in capital expenditures with depreciation of $54.6 million, generated $141 million in cash flow from operations. We returned over $240 million to shareholders via dividends and the repurchase of 3 million shares during the quarter. 
Looking at product mix for the third quarter of fiscal 2016, integrated mobile systems was 55% of revenue, broad markets was 29% and power amplifiers was 16%. 
Now moving on to our fourth fiscal quarter business outlook.  Based on the broad market traction, our new program ramps as well as the content gains Liam has outlined, we expect fourth quarter revenue to be up 10% to 11% sequentially to $831 million at the midpoint. The  double-digit revenue growth we expect in Q4 followed by continued growth into our first fiscal quarter will reduce inventory. We have level loaded our factories and positioned ourselves well to address a series of new filter-rich program ramps with leading customers.
For fiscal Q4, we suggest modeling gross margin at 51%. it's worth noting that our Q4 gross margin guidance implies 100 basis point improvement versus the prior year fourth quarter even with a lower revenue base. 
Looking at OpEx, we expect R&D and SG&A expenses to be flat with Q3, reflecting continued cost structure discipline. 
Below the line, we anticipate around $1 million in interest and other expenses, a cash tax rate of 14%. 
We expect share count to be roughly 190 million shares, driving fourth fiscal quarter fully diluted EPS of $1.43. 
Lastly, we also announced today that our board has authorized an 8% dividend increase and a new 400 million stock repurchase program, underscoring the confidence as we have in our business model and ability to deliver superior returns to our shareholders. 
And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Liam.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Our third quarter execution highlights our differentiated competitive positioning and the strength of our business model. We are levered to [ph] powerful secular technology forces and have spent the last decade aligning the company to capit
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. 
Our third quarter execution highlights our differentiated competitive positioning and the strength of our business model. We are levered to [ph] powerful secular technology forces and have spent the last decade aligning the company to capitalize on these strategic macro trends, propelling our mobile IoT and broad market opportunity.
First is the explosive growth of mobile data across the vast set of applications and usage cases, driving performance from device to cloud and beyond. Next, we are seeing an ever-increasing expansion of connectivity, with tens of billions of connected devices brought to market over the next 5 years. And finally, we address a tremendous ecosystem and new economy that thrives on the ability to leverage high-speed and secure connectivity at the heart of their business. 
Enabling these connections is the sweet spot of our franchise. In mobile, we have growing content positions across all of the world's premier OEMs, leveraging our unique capabilities to meet our customers' increasing need for higher-performance solutions. We are also building momentum in broad markets, particularly in IoT, with engagements at leading players including Amazon, Arris, Cisco, Fitbit, GE, Google Nest, Honeywell, Itron, LG and others.
Our success here has been brought about by a broad and growing list of wins in adjacent markets like industrial, energy management, security, health and fitness and the smart home. Today, we participate in all of these verticals through our suite of diverse technologies, including support for WiFi, ZigBee, Bluetooth, GPS, small cell and LTE standards. At the same time, we are building presence in key verticals like automotive with leaders such as Continental, Audi, Ford, Kia, GM and Volkswagen.
Underpinning all of our solutions is the skyrocketing demand for wireless data. Whether it's Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google or Tesla, there is a powerful and expanding ecosystem, monetizing and relying upon efficient, high speed, low latency, seamless and secure connections.  This ecosystem spans across enterprise to e-commerce to social media and a burgeoning set of entirely new applications, fueled by connectivity. In an effort to facilitate this massive and growing wave of data delivery, creation and movement in storage, our customers are implementing methods to improve performance with carrier aggregation, received diversity, and ultimately 5G capabilities. This dynamic requires a continuous increase in the levels of analog and mixed signal performance, enhanced power efficiency, high-precision filtering as well as configurable systems integration capabilities. Skyworks' suite of products and systems in solution are squarely aimed at resolving the intense performance demands facing our customers.
So to summarize, we delivered above-guidance results in the quarter, driven by increasing global demand for high-speed connectivity coupled with strong operational execution. And as our guidance reflects, we are planning for sustained market outperformance with operating leverage and strong cash flow generation. Clearly, we remain well positioned to realize our vision of connecting everyone and everything all the time. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, let's open the lines for questions.

So the lion's share of that material, that inventory of largely filters is really lined up relative to second half ramps with known customers so and a very clear demand curve.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just follow up, we know generically on the inventory, just keep in mind that that inventory growth that you're seeing into Q3 is -- supports the second half of. Volumes were up about 11% quarter-over-quarter, and there's growth as we continue to fisca
componenttext: And just follow up, we know generically on the inventory, just keep in mind that that inventory growth that you're seeing into Q3 is -- supports the second half of. Volumes were up about 11% quarter-over-quarter, and there's growth as we continue to fiscal Q1 of '17. There are multiple things that Liam was talking about burning the inventory down. I'm just going to give you summary of why the level's where it's at. At the level, we were level-loading factories to meet that second half demand. The share gains in filters, especially silicon, is driven by new programs. There's specific growth designed with some ramps and there's essentially no risk with any of -- risk with this inventory. We also had a new hub arrangement for large customer in Asia. That's a onetime stocking bump in inventory. some of the projected product mix into Q4 just has longer lead times for some of the outsourced materials, and it's primarily silicon wafer. So the bottom line, we're very confident in the decline going forward and getting the turns back towards historical levels. this is a short-term issue that we're working through based on those dynamics.

componenttext: Sure. I mean we, first and foremost, committed to running our core business. And we think there's great opportunity to leverage not only our strength in mobile. Now in parallel, we have the disciplined view on M&A, but we are looking at potential opportunities. We'll share more with you as they come about. But we're focused on our core, but have the powder, the balance sheet and the opportunity to augment that with M&A as needed.

componenttext: For the first one, Liam, I was wondering if you could just give us a sense of the overall demand environment. Obviously the industry has come through in inventory correction at your largest customer. are we past all of those problems, and now we should start to expect more normalized growth, if you could address that? And then also if you could take it more broadly to the trends you're seeing at your Korean and Chinese customers. I think basically, I think investors want to understand, are we past some of the issues we saw on the first half and it's a more normalized growth environment going forward? Or -- is the industry still struggling with a little bit of the inventory issues that came about in the first half?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vivek, I'll take both of those questions. Well yes, I mean we've been through a challenging first half of the calendar year, for sure. And I think that's been well-publicized and reflected in our numbers in the past. We are seeing improving conditio
componenttext: Sure, Vivek, I'll take both of those questions. Well yes, I mean we've been through a challenging first half of the calendar year, for sure. And I think that's been well-publicized and reflected in our numbers in the past. We are seeing improving conditions right now. We're seeing all of our Tier 1s grow. And more importantly, we are seeing our content position expand and their need for the content expand. So the dynamic around performance and our ability to resolve performance with system-level solution is coming together quite well. And you can see in the Sky, 10% to 11%, pretty solid guide up into Q4. We feel that that's sustainable. We expect -- So early for Q1, but we expect to be cup up again in Q1. so that's a broad statement. If you look at China and Samsung, both of those opportunities, China being more of broad opportunity with some of the flagship names like Huawei doing very, very well. And China will be one of our faster growing areas. Samsung, we've got content gains on the GS7. That's looking good this year. Samsung will be probably a 15%-plus account for us year-over-year. We're lining out for the GS8. So what you can look at here at a high level is this continuous need for performance and Skyworks' ability to address not only our core positions in SkyOne and some of the transmit chain, but also an increasing position in analog and increasing position in the receive side, WiFi and other technologies will allow us to grow our share.

componenttext: Yes, sure. We'll talk about incremental contribution margin that we saw in Q3, being that that was a down revenue quarter, was actually a number that was very good, in the high 40s. And when you're in down revenue, you want the number to be below which you're [indiscernible] posting. So that's good. When you look at the guidance, we're at about 52.5% on an incremental basis. That's simply reflective of the backdrop, the unique elements that we highlighted in the Q4 inventory. Going forward when you're looking at our earnings model opportunity, the 53% is absolutely still our target. And we expect these incremental margins very, very quickly to get back to the 58% kind of level, which is what we have communicated externally. So there's no issues there. We're just working through the inventory issues and the tough backdrop issues that Liam mentioned, but nothing else specific.

componenttext: Great. And then you mentioned in your prepared remarks about the low, mid and high socket wins in the Huawei phone. just talk about why we don't see you in mid- and high band in some of the other flagship models in India, Korea in the U.S. and if you guys are planning to get to those sockets, maybe the specifications of the microphones different than those other device?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, that's a great question. So first off, I will tell you we are encroaching some the mid- and high bands organically with enhanced performance in our [indiscernible] factory. as noted the prepared remarks, we shipped over 2.5 billion filters, all o
componenttext: Yes, no, that's a great question. So first off, I will tell you we are encroaching some the mid- and high bands organically with enhanced performance in our [indiscernible] factory. as noted the prepared remarks, we shipped over 2.5 billion filters, all of which were consumed by our system solution. So we are not a discrete filter company. Having said that, our performance levels not only with the filter, but the entirety of the system, so if you think about what customers want from us, as they want solutions that resolve this tremendous complexity. And the solutions from Skyworks are really system-level. include our own gallium arsenide HBT process we have in-house, our SOI process, our deep IP and switching, our ability to craft MCMs for very, very low loss in high efficiency, delivering a complete module. So our modules can often include our own TC SAW. We've been able to move the TC frequency up to mid-band. And in some cases, if there frequencies are not applicable for TC SAW we can address by foundry partners for [indiscernible]. So that's what you're seeing now in the Huawei phone. I think you'll continue to see us extend our reach and frequency and continue to do customers want, really simplify solutions, give them the best end-to-end efficiency and the best systems-level performance.

componenttext: Filters, you mentioned over 200 -- or 2 billion of those filters, but probably like 37 are TC SAW. Is the big expansion in Panasonic's facility all for TC SAW, Liam? Or would you get into the SAW manufacturing? And if you do, how is that going to impact your GM? because I know think you find this in the outside world now? headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, great question. Yes, the filters we produce is far largely been TC SAW. And as you know well, I mean that is a flavor of high-performance filters that's in high demand. And it's allowed us to lever that up into SkyOne systems for low, and in some
componenttext: Yes, no, great question. Yes, the filters we produce is far largely been TC SAW. And as you know well, I mean that is a flavor of high-performance filters that's in high demand. And it's allowed us to lever that up into SkyOne systems for low, and in some cases, mid-band. served us very well. Now going back to standard SAW filters is easy. It's fewer process. eliminate the silicon dioxide plating. It's a cheaper process for us. And you are correct that we do still spend quite a bit of money outside for a third-party source. there's potential opportunity for us to bring that in-house. finally, that site in Osaka has the ability. It's a phenomenal site, class 10 clean room, beautiful facility. And we do have the opportunity to expand further and higher frequencies if needed.

componenttext: Okay. Marotta [ph] stated it's losing share to your largest customer this year, and it looks like that's all to you. you're also splitting [indiscernible] with [indiscernible]. you did that do last year. [indiscernible] also entered the DRx section in Samsung when they weren't last year. So how do you see, Liam, the competitive environment shaking out in say, calendar 2017? Are the Japanese firm which are disappearing, and you guys got Panasonic [indiscernible]. Are they going to disappear faster than, say, [indiscernible] in of these sockets? And is all this going to be kind of footnote to overall TAM growth in the RF section in '17? I'm just trying to get your view of the bigger picture.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, let's that's a lot. Let me try to help you with that. So I'll tell you what we see. We see the performance nodes going up and up and up, with each successive generation would be our largest customer over the next 2 or 3 down, we really see that
componenttext: Yes, yes, let's that's a lot. Let me try to help you with that. So I'll tell you what we see. We see the performance nodes going up and up and up, with each successive generation would be our largest customer over the next 2 or 3 down, we really see that happening. And that's actually -- that's propelled our growth more than anything. Our ability to hit challenging architectures and do it with profitable solutions and integrated solutions served us very, very well. We're confident that you'll be able to see content gains with all of the leading accounts, regardless of partitioning. We are agnostic to [indiscernible]. We work with Qualcomm. We work with Intel. We work with MediaTek, high silicon, all of those players. And so we don't expect any issue with that. But yes, competitively, the companies that can hit the performance and the companies that can do that elegantly and unburden our customers with these daunting challenges that they're facing, those are the ones that are going to win and will be at the top of that list. I mean, that's the whole essence of Skyworks, to try to drive a strategy around performance, integrate as much as we can, work with our customers, listen to what they need. It may be different. Every account wants something different, but be flexible enough, leveraging our internal capabilities, leveraging Mexicali [ph] for highly configurable devices, picking the right flavor of filter, but really looking at systems performance from input to output. If we do that well, our business will follow.

componenttext: Maybe just continuing on that theme with your expansion in capacity and really seeing significant expansion in [indiscernible] and Broadcom as well. Are you concerned at all about the supply-demand balance of this industry as we  I mean [indiscernible] over the next few quarters?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Cody, xim it's funny if you look at what is happening in these devices now, it is incredible, the filter count that is absolutely required by our customers, and just by virtue of the crowded spectrum that we see. So there's going to be I think a shak
componenttext: Yes, Cody, xim it's funny if you look at what is happening in these devices now, it is incredible, the filter count that is absolutely required by our customers, and just by virtue of the crowded spectrum that we see. So there's going to be I think a shake on who's going to and who isn't going to invest in how we put those filters in complete systems. Our customers really are less interested in buying discrete components today and more interested in those highly efficient engines that we spoke off. So we're very confident with our ability to address, and as you know from history with Skyworks, we're very disciplined in our CapEx and we're careful with where we invest. So we certainly know where our strategic is going and our ability to win. And with respect our competition, we've competed with [indiscernible] and Corvo [ph] and others for years and years. and we certainly like our outlook at Skyworks.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just trying to get into a more clearer picture on the September guide, I know you've been asked and answered these those questions about inventory. But do you believe that you're still dealing with anything that's either causing you to be conservative
componenttext: And just trying to get into a more clearer picture on the September guide, I know you've been asked and answered these those questions about inventory. But do you believe that you're still dealing with anything that's either causing you to be conservative or weighing a bit on that 10% 11% guide? You've got obviously there are major customer builds that you're prepping for. You've got some seasonality happening. You've got what appears to be relatively healthy market in China. Maybe I think I'm just a bit surprised that this wasn't a bit stronger guide.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, I mean, 10% to 11% is I think a pretty healthy move up for us. Yes, there has been of course some lingering effects of legacy platforms that we've had to manage through, and -- that is be managed through. So all of that is reflected in the numb
componenttext: Sure. Yes, I mean, 10% to 11% is I think a pretty healthy move up for us. Yes, there has been of course some lingering effects of legacy platforms that we've had to manage through, and -- that is be managed through. So all of that is reflected in the numbers. I'll tell you one thing we need to highlight here again is absent our largest customer, we're up 10% to 12% year-over-year. And also across mobile, we are specifically expanding our content reach. It was a question that was asked earlier on the call. But the percentage of revenue we derive in mobile with technologies that are really more like analog mixed-signal, that percentage is going up. IoT business looks very strong right. our broad business looks -- very strong. It's been a tough opening 2 quarters of the calendar year, quite frankly. And we're coming out of that now. Is there some lingering headwinds that, that reflect in the number? Yes, possibly so, but that's in the guide.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Anthony of .

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just [indiscernible] on China, could you talk about how much was it up in June? Do you expect it to be up in the September quarter? What present China makes for your business total revenues? And what you think the inventory in the channel looks like into
componenttext: Just [indiscernible] on China, could you talk about how much was it up in June? Do you expect it to be up in the September quarter? What present China makes for your business total revenues? And what you think the inventory in the channel looks like into China?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tony. Well at a high level, China is about 25% of our company revenue. And they were up sequentially more than 10%. They look good in the second half calendar year. I think one of the accounts that we highlighted in the prepared remarks was Huawei.
componenttext: Sure, Tony. Well at a high level, China is about 25% of our company revenue. And they were up sequentially more than 10%. They look good in the second half calendar year. I think one of the accounts that we highlighted in the prepared remarks was Huawei. We've got a great position there, not only with the P9 phone we mentioned, but the honor [ph] series and others. There's also another opportunity in China I think most of you know. But China is a tremendous export player to the rest of the world, and there is still 2 billion to 3 billion people out there will have no connectivity. And so we are able to feed through our partnerships with MediaTek and Spreadtrum and even high silicon that that often make models will go to India, the Middle East, Africa and some of the other emerging markets. And so we look good there. The recent numbers in China have been strong. We're also seeing -- I think some of these came through some of our peer group's calls as well. We are seeing a move towards 5 mode from 3 modes, so that increases our content. The recent carrier data shows a better pickup in 4G, LTE. That's good. So for the most part, China's been actually really an improving story here in the last few months.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: And the next question, it comes from the line of Ambrish Srivastava BMO Capital.

componenttext: No, no, no, we're not concerned about overbuilding. We have -- one of the larger accounts we have in China now, we've moved to a hub arrangement, which is again part of the inventory issue. But it's fully lined up. you can't overbuild in that environment. basically meet your customers' hub needs. pull the open market, broad customers in China. We work very closely with MediaTek and some of the other baseband partners to get a broad forecast. Some of the solutions that we sell into that ecosystem are fungible. So they can be sold to multiple customers. That will net out the puts and takes of kind of broader market within China. But no, we feel very, very solid about the inventory dynamics and revenue dynamics with respect to China. We've been in that market for a long time. We were a 2G player, a 3G player. And now actually with 4G and our ability to expand reach, the market for us now is probably the best it's ever been.

componenttext: to answer your question specifically, they continue to be part of a business. We haven't gone ahead with that sale. And it's just a business that at this point, we're comfortable keeping. And we think that there's some growth opportunity going forward associated with it.

componenttext: Yes, as far as where we think it's going to be, it's going to be flat to slightly down going into this quarter. But remember, it's also supporting revenue growth going forward. componenttext: No, we feel very positive about the growth in dollar content. And I said it a couple of times already in the call, it's really twofold. It's continuing to do well in our core business and our core opportunities in mobile, but also getting a larger region to some of these other opportunities within a handset. And you'll see that more and out by leading customers.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from the line of Harsh Kumar of Stephens, Inc.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Liam, congratulations on your new position. One of the questions we get a lot from investors is about your [indiscernible] strategy or lack of it  How much of the upper-end slots and filters can TC SAW address? eventually, what would you guys have to do t
componenttext: Liam, congratulations on your new position. One of the questions we get a lot from investors is about your [indiscernible] strategy or lack of it  How much of the upper-end slots and filters can TC SAW address? eventually, what would you guys have to do to be able to get to that upper level of filters?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, thanks, Harsh. as I outlined earlier, we can address the upper level of filters today. We just do it with foundry partners, for example. would love to be able to build it in-house, and that something that's not out of our reach. It just isn't there
componenttext: Sure, thanks, Harsh. as I outlined earlier, we can address the upper level of filters today. We just do it with foundry partners, for example. would love to be able to build it in-house, and that something that's not out of our reach. It just isn't there today. Our TC socket ability is has moved in frequency where it was largely just low band play, maybe 600, 900 meg. We now have technology well over 1 gig, getting close to 2 and 2.5 gig. again back to what I was mentioning before, we don't have an appetite for selling discrete filters. when we sell a filter, it is wrapped within a complete system. So the filter contributes some level of performance. But you also have your HBT, switch, MCM and your ability to minimize losses within your layout. So a lot -- and that -- with Skyworks, all of that I mentioned is controlled in-house. so think about us a system solutions player. Filters play a role in the system, but the entirety of the architecture is what matters. So we've won programs with Huawei. We're close with other customers. There may be a few opportunities where optimal filter performance is the #1 requirement. That may be the case for some of the discrete applications or maybe some super high-performance, high band sockets. Today, perhaps we can't address that. But we have the engineering talent, the filter assets and the people and other processes in place to continue to push that envelope and grow them.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. a follow-up, Liam, what is -- what are the 1 or 2 focus areas for you in the first 12 months of your CEO-hood?
componenttext: Great. a follow-up, Liam, what is -- what are the 1 or 2 focus areas for you in the first 12 months of your CEO-hood?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, sure, thanks. number one, we definitely want to continue this push by leveraging our core in mobile and taking advantage of this expanding opportunity that we mentioned, receive-side technology, WiFi technology, GPS, power management and others,
componenttext: Yes, yes, sure, thanks. number one, we definitely want to continue this push by leveraging our core in mobile and taking advantage of this expanding opportunity that we mentioned, receive-side technology, WiFi technology, GPS, power management and others, and try to create the same systems-level approach in that section that worked so well for us and SkyOne and in transmit. That's one. The second is stepping up in IoT. I mean, this is a market we talked about the last few years. We talked about broad market. But within that, the IoT landscape and the class of customers that we engage with today is phenomenal. And we have a unique opportunity because most of the players in IoT feature 1 or 2 connectivity topologies. We have WiFi. We have Bluetooth. We have ZigBee. We have low-power technology. We have power management. And we have a tremendous know-how on how to make connected things work and make them work wirelessly. So we are excited about that. We're going to put more resources around that part of our business. Some other opportunities have really come along nicely, albeit still quite small, are markets like automotive. We're being pulled into some of the premier players that we mentioned in the opening remarks, bringing in full LTE modules and automotive very high performance high reliability modules, that's looking good so we're going to fire on all of those cylinders and then for near continue to drive the best people in the best execution in our state.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: with a question for Don, Don if I approach the gross margin issue in a different way. As you look at getting from where you are back to those 58% incremental gross margins and prioritizing the improvement drivers that can close that Gap. what's on the list? It sounds like getting inventory down is one item. I think I heard you mention that filter insourcing is another. But what else is on the list? And how quickly did those different factors come into play really provide tailwinds for the margin structure of the business?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they come in very, very quickly, part of it when we talked about the inventory issue and the level-loading that's been going on. I mean even though the hybrid model serves us really well, we were able to pull, in a down quarter, we were able to pull
componenttext: Yes, they come in very, very quickly, part of it when we talked about the inventory issue and the level-loading that's been going on. I mean even though the hybrid model serves us really well, we were able to pull, in a down quarter, we were able to pull production capacity and externally. We're still not, during this period, we aren't running completely full. So that's going to be something that's very quickly going to get us back up into the incremental margin track. And that's a big driver of this. the other thing is the new product launches as we move forward. We said we are very focused on every new generation of products going to provide incremental margins. that will all be in the mix as we move forward. We're excited about some of the IoT opportunity, as Liam talked about. So those are the things, that -- and we have a lot of confidence in the visibility to get down the road to the 53% target. That's still right in front of us, for sure.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the follow-up is for Liam. Liam, Skyworks I think has been well known for an above-industry average grower. It doesn't look like it's playing out that way this year, but we understand the challenges that exist with the large customer. The question is,
componenttext: And the follow-up is for Liam. Liam, Skyworks I think has been well known for an above-industry average grower. It doesn't look like it's playing out that way this year, but we understand the challenges that exist with the large customer. The question is, how patient will you be with the business in getting back to above-industry average growth organically? and at what point will you feel like you have to press for M&A to diversify the business and get back to some of the growth rates and relative growth rates that we're used to seeing from the company?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig. That's a great question. Well first of all, I am committed and have great confidence that the organic business, the organic franchise will be an outformer in terms of growth. Now we're bigger company than we were a couple of years ago. There'
componenttext: Sure, Craig. That's a great question. Well first of all, I am committed and have great confidence that the organic business, the organic franchise will be an outformer in terms of growth. Now we're bigger company than we were a couple of years ago. There's a some level of maturity in unit growth and in mobile, which has been the biggest market for us. But we're able to augment that with the share moves we've talked about. And think again about the usage case that the entities that use mobile technology and what they want, and it's daunting. I think be solid in core mobile. And I'm very comfortable with the opportunity with TAM, given some of the new architectures and road maps that we have visibility into. Broad market things to become much more of an IoT play for us. I think that's really what broad markets means now. we have great solutions for it. I think we need to put more people behind, more engineering and help folks behind that. That should work. parallel, in parallel, M&A is absolutely an opportunity for Skyworks. And we have a tremendous balance sheet. We generated a ton of cash. And I think we'll be able to do the right deal when it comes about. So -- but having said all of that, we're running the franchise, optimizing the franchise, doing every thing we can to continue to put the growth up, the margins up, and satisfy our customers. M&A is another area that we will continue to pursue.

componenttext: No, I mean, the BAW OpEx, engineers we have in the joint venture our operations in Japan are already in the run rates.
