componenttext: I guess I'm still trying to understand the inventory. You said that you're building ahead of the ramp, but the revenue is guided down like $50 million year-over-year at the midpoint. So I would have thought that if you're building for more content gains, that you would think that the revenue guidance would have been a little bit better year-over-year. So is the answer really that it's going to sell through more in the fourth calendar quarter? Because, I guess, if you could commit to a big up fourth calendar quarter then it would -- then the inventory build would make a little more sense. So I'm wondering if you can comment on that.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Part of the sell-through you will see both Q4 and into Q1 as well. You'll see both of those. So that's clearly part of it.
componenttext: Part of the sell-through you will see both Q4 and into Q1 as well. You'll see both of those. So that's clearly part of it.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then also, just to recall that we've 3x-ed the size of our filter franchise, so to speak. We -- when we did the deal with Panasonic, we had 1 site in Kadoma. We've added a large site in Osaka. We have many more customers now that are engaged with
componenttext: Yes. And then also, just to recall that we've 3x-ed the size of our filter franchise, so to speak. We -- when we did the deal with Panasonic, we had 1 site in Kadoma. We've added a large site in Osaka. We have many more customers now that are engaged with us with filter-based solutions. So running that larger factory, running that larger footprint in high-performance filters, there's more WIP, there's more inventory and there's more programs by which we're going to sell into. So that's the difference when you look at year-over-year. The size of our filter franchise is quite a bit bigger. The number of customers that we address is quite a bit larger. And specifically, in the second half calendar year, you are going to see that action come to bear. And we're going to see the inventories come down as well.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry. One thing that I wanted to add, too, is that when you look at the build that we had this quarter, it's all raw materials and WIP. There's literally no finished goods build, very little. So that just supports that future growth opportunity.
componenttext: I'm sorry. One thing that I wanted to add, too, is that when you look at the build that we had this quarter, it's all raw materials and WIP. There's literally no finished goods build, very little. So that just supports that future growth opportunity.

componenttext: Maybe just when you look at the September guidance, just trying to better understand what you're embedding in there, if you can talk what you think broad markets will do into September. And then assuming that's not down a ton, it looks like integrated mobile is down year-over-year. Obviously, your largest customer's got unit headwind to deal with. You have content gains offsetting. Is there any other headwinds that you're dealing with in integrated mobile?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think for the most part, if you look at the quarter here, we're speaking Q4 guide, we are still -- there's some headwind in some ways of mix, legacy mix, SAW [ph] that really hasn't come to bear, but we've factored that in. We are seeing o
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think for the most part, if you look at the quarter here, we're speaking Q4 guide, we are still -- there's some headwind in some ways of mix, legacy mix, SAW [ph] that really hasn't come to bear, but we've factored that in. We are seeing overall growth. If you were to exclude our largest customer, we're up 10% to 12% year-over-year in the quarter. So some of the headwinds with our larger customer still are reflected in our numbers. We are growing the non-core PAD business quite well. That's IoT. That's diversity receive technologies that are quite new for us. Our WiFi business is strong. All those portfolios look very good on a year-over-year basis. And we're starting to get out of the inventory hole that we mentioned with some of our larger customers. And things definitely look better in the second half with respect to that.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. Liam, just on broad markets, you had a very strong quarter in June despite the divestiture was up. Can you just talk about the trajectory of that into September?
componenttext: Good. Liam, just on broad markets, you had a very strong quarter in June despite the divestiture was up. Can you just talk about the trajectory of that into September?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll be up a little bit in September, probably 5% to 8%. I will tell you this though, within broad market, IoT is -- will be up 10% to 15%. And year-over-year, IoT is probably headed for high teens. So within the broad market space, what you have th
componenttext: Yes, we'll be up a little bit in September, probably 5% to 8%. I will tell you this though, within broad market, IoT is -- will be up 10% to 15%. And year-over-year, IoT is probably headed for high teens. So within the broad market space, what you have there, Blayne, is some markets that are doing quite well, IoT. We also have some legacy markets like infrastructure that are great markets and have super margin but just have been flattish in terms of top line. So the blend together looks good, but IoT is a sweet spot within broad. It's really special for us right now.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you introduced a whole bunch of new products here such as the digital attenuators and antenna tuning, et cetera, can you talk a little bit about how much of your content on the phone now comes from outside of, say, a PAD-type device? I know there's lot
componenttext: As you introduced a whole bunch of new products here such as the digital attenuators and antenna tuning, et cetera, can you talk a little bit about how much of your content on the phone now comes from outside of, say, a PAD-type device? I know there's lots of SKUs out there, but just trying to get a sense of how broad you're getting now across the phone outside of just some more classic parts?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, that's a great -- I don't have an exact stat for you, but I will tell you, it's definitely increased over the last year and it will increase in the second half of this year. Some examples, you've mentioned us talk about diversity receive. I mean,
componenttext: Yes, no, that's a great -- I don't have an exact stat for you, but I will tell you, it's definitely increased over the last year and it will increase in the second half of this year. Some examples, you've mentioned us talk about diversity receive. I mean, this is some real elegant proprietary technology that Skyworks has created. It levers our filter technology. It levers our LNA, low noise amplifier expertise, our switching and, again, that configurability with our own MCM. Great technology, and what it does is just tremendous, tremendous improvements in the downlink portion of a phone. And if you think about the way typical usage cases have to work [ph] on a phone, downlink is critical. So we provide a great enhancement to downlink speed. That's one area that is relatively new for us and it should be a big growth driver. Some of the SkyBlue technology that we mentioned before is unique for us, driving power efficiency through the system. We've had WiFi for quite a while, but now what we're starting to see is MIMO WiFi in some of the leading flagship phones. So our content virtually can double it with MIMO. There's a lot of great things happening, antenna tuning another point, GPS for location-based services. If you think about -- we've talked about the ecosystem with some of the big tech players now engaged in mobile. A lot of these folks are involved in payment. They want to know exactly where people are, precise location. We have a GPS portfolio now that is really emerging and increasing attach rate with some of our customers. So all those things blend in. And you're seeing, definitely, a larger increase in kind of the nontraditional PAD business, although that remains core, but a bigger swing now to some of these newer devices.

componenttext: Yes, yes. No, absolutely, okay, I got your question now. Yes, I mean, certainly, we get through the second half here. Obviously, we are coming off of $752 million, 10% up. We expect to be up again in Q1. We don't have a full guide yet for that quarter. But I think when we get into the March quarter, we should we back on track with year-over-year growth. And then just also, just to remind you, I think we mentioned it before, but even in the September quarter, we're looking at comparable levels of operating income percentage, so comparable levels of profitability even at lower revenue. So it has been a challenging period for us, the last couple of quarters, but I think you can see some financial discipline here, at least in the P&L.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And you'll see sort of normal sequential growth patterns starting again, but the year-over-year, as Liam said, is going to be in the second quarter. We see that.
componenttext: Yes. And you'll see sort of normal sequential growth patterns starting again, but the year-over-year, as Liam said, is going to be in the second quarter. We see that.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Filters, you mentioned over 200 -- or 2 billion of those filters. All but like 37 of them were TC SAW. Is the big expansion in Panasonic's facility all for TC SAW, Liam? Or would you get into SAW manufacturing? And if you do, how is that going to impact y
componenttext: Filters, you mentioned over 200 -- or 2 billion of those filters. All but like 37 of them were TC SAW. Is the big expansion in Panasonic's facility all for TC SAW, Liam? Or would you get into SAW manufacturing? And if you do, how is that going to impact your GM, because I know you're buying those on the outside world now? And then the second question, on the competitive environment and when you're done, please.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, a great question. So, yes, certainly, the filters that we produce thus far have largely been TC SAW. And as you know well, I mean, that is a flavor of high-performance filters that's in high demand, and it's allowed us to lever that up into SkyO
componenttext: Okay. No, a great question. So, yes, certainly, the filters that we produce thus far have largely been TC SAW. And as you know well, I mean, that is a flavor of high-performance filters that's in high demand, and it's allowed us to lever that up into SkyOne systems for low and, in some cases, mid-band. And it's been -- served us very well. Now going back to standard SAW filters it's actually quite easy. It's fewer process steps. You really -- you eliminate the silicon dioxide plating. It's a cheaper process for us. And you are correct that we do still spend quite a bit of money outside for third-party SAW. So there's a potential opportunity for us to bring that in-house. And then finally, that site in Osaka has the ability -- it's a phenomenal site, class 10 clean room, beautiful facility. And we do have the opportunity to expand further in higher frequencies if needed.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you're clearly #1 in TC SAW by a distant margin here. So it sounds like your expansion plans are going to be even further. And then on the competitive environment, I mean, it seems like it's shifting pretty dramatically here. Murata has already s
componenttext: Okay. So you're clearly #1 in TC SAW by a distant margin here. So it sounds like your expansion plans are going to be even further. And then on the competitive environment, I mean, it seems like it's shifting pretty dramatically here. Murata has already stated that it's losing share. It's your largest customer this year, and it looks like that's all to you. But then you're also splitting the low band PAD with Qorvo, and you didn't do that last year. Qorvo has also entered the DRx section in Samsung where they weren't last year. So how do you see, Liam, the competitive environment shaking out in, say, calendar 2017? Of the Japanese firm which are disappearing, I mean, you guys got Panasonic. TDK's been sopped [ph] up here. Are they going to disappear faster than, say, Qorvo shows up with some of these sockets? And is all this going to be kind of a footnote to overall TAM growth in the RF section in '17? I'm just trying to get your view of the bigger picture.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, that's a lot, but let me try to help you with that. So I'll tell you what we see. We see the performance nodes going up and up and up with each successive generation, whether it be our largest customer or the next 2 or 3 down. We really see that
componenttext: Yes, yes, that's a lot, but let me try to help you with that. So I'll tell you what we see. We see the performance nodes going up and up and up with each successive generation, whether it be our largest customer or the next 2 or 3 down. We really see that happening. And that's actually -- that's propelled our growth more than anything. Our ability to hit the more challenging architectures and do it with profitable solutions and integrated solutions has served us very, very well. We're confident that you'll be able to see content gains with all of the leading accounts, regardless of baseband partitioning. We are agnostic to baseband. We work with Qualcomm. We work with Intel. We work with MediaTek, HiSilicon, all of those players. And so we don't expect any issue with that. But, yes, competitively, the companies that can hit the performance and the companies that can do it elegantly and unburden our customers with these daunting challenges that they're facing, those are the ones that are going to win, and we'll be at the top of that list. I mean, that's the whole essence of Skyworks, to try to drive a strategy around performance, integrate as much as we can, work with our customers, listen to what they need. It may be different. Every account wants something different. But be flexible enough, leveraging our internal capabilities, leveraging Mexicali for highly configurable devices, picking the right flavor of filter, but really looking at systems performance from input to output. And if we do that well, our business will follow.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from the line of Cody Acree of Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: And the next question is from the line of Cody Acree of Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe just continuing on that theme with your expansion in capacity and really seeing a significant expansion at Qorvo and at Broadcom as well. Are you concerned at all about the supply-demand balance of this industry as we get that over the next few q
componenttext: So maybe just continuing on that theme with your expansion in capacity and really seeing a significant expansion at Qorvo and at Broadcom as well. Are you concerned at all about the supply-demand balance of this industry as we get that over the next few quarters?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Cody, it's funny, if you look at what is happening in these devices now, it is incredible, the filter count that is absolutely required by our customers and just by virtue of the crowded spectrum that we see. So there's going to be, I think, a shake
componenttext: Yes, Cody, it's funny, if you look at what is happening in these devices now, it is incredible, the filter count that is absolutely required by our customers and just by virtue of the crowded spectrum that we see. So there's going to be, I think, a shake out on who's going to win and who isn't going to win based on how we put those filters into complete systems. Our customers really are less interested in buying discrete components today and more interested on those highly efficient engines that we spoke of. So we're very confident with our ability to address. And as you know, from history with Skyworks, we're very disciplined on our CapEx, and we're careful with where we invest. So we certainly know where our filter strategy is going and our ability to win. And with respect to our competition, we've competed with Avago and Qorvo and others for years and years, and we certainly like our outlook here at Skyworks.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just trying to get maybe a little clearer picture on the September guide. I know you've been asked and answered these questions about inventory, but do you believe that you're still dealing with anything that's either causing you to be conservative or
componenttext: And just trying to get maybe a little clearer picture on the September guide. I know you've been asked and answered these questions about inventory, but do you believe that you're still dealing with anything that's either causing you to be conservative or weighing a bit on that 10% to 11% guide? You've got a, obviously, very major customer build that you're prepping for. You've got some seasonality happening. You've got what appears to be a relatively healthy market in China. Maybe I think I'm just a bit surprised that this wasn't a bit stronger guide.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, I mean, 10% to 11% is -- I think is a pretty healthy move up for us. Yes, there has been, of course, some lingering effects of legacy platforms that we've had to manage through. And that is being managed through, so all of that is reflected in
componenttext: Sure. Yes, I mean, 10% to 11% is -- I think is a pretty healthy move up for us. Yes, there has been, of course, some lingering effects of legacy platforms that we've had to manage through. And that is being managed through, so all of that is reflected in the numbers. I'll tell you one thing that we really need to highlight here again is absent our largest customer, we're up 10% to 12% year-over-year. And also -- and across mobile, we're specifically expanding our content reach. It was a question that was asked earlier on the call. But the percentage of revenue we derive in mobile with technologies that are really more like analog, mixed-signal, that percentage is going up. Our IoT business looks very strong right now. Our broad market business looks right -- very strong. It's been a tough opening 2 quarters of the calendar year, quite frankly, and we're coming out of that now. Is there some lingering headwinds that are reflected in the number? Yes, possibly so, but that's in the guide.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Anthony Stoss of Craig-Hallum.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Anthony Stoss of Craig-Hallum.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just drilling down a little bit further, Liam, on China. Can you talk about how much it was up in June? Do you expect it to be up also in the September quarter, what percent China currently makes for your business overall, total revenues, and what you thi
componenttext: Just drilling down a little bit further, Liam, on China. Can you talk about how much it was up in June? Do you expect it to be up also in the September quarter, what percent China currently makes for your business overall, total revenues, and what you think the inventory in the channel looks like into China?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tony. Well, at a high level, China is about 25% of our company revenue, and they were up sequentially more than 10%. They look good in the second half calendar year. I think one of the accounts that we highlighted in the prepared remarks was Huawei.
componenttext: Sure, Tony. Well, at a high level, China is about 25% of our company revenue, and they were up sequentially more than 10%. They look good in the second half calendar year. I think one of the accounts that we highlighted in the prepared remarks was Huawei. We've got a great position there, not only with the P9 phone that we mentioned, but the Honor series and others. There's also another opportunity in China I think most of you know. But China is a tremendous export player to the rest of the world, and there is still 2 billion to 3 billion people out there that have no connectivity. And so we are able to feed that through our partnerships with MediaTek and Spreadtrum and even HiSilicon that often make models that will go to India, the Middle East, Africa and some of the other emerging markets. So we look good there. The recent numbers in China have been strong. We're also seeing -- I think some of this came through some of our peer group's calls as well. We are seeing a move more towards 5 mode from 3 mode, so that increases our content. The recent carrier data shows some better pickup in 4G LTE. That's good. So for the most part, China's been actually really an improving story here in the last few months.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Ambrish Srivastava of BMO Capital.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Ambrish Srivastava of BMO Capital.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Kulin Patel for Ambrish. On China, we also heard from others talk about strength in China recently. Are you concerned about overbuilding there, given the strength in China?
componenttext: This is Kulin Patel for Ambrish. On China, we also heard from others talk about strength in China recently. Are you concerned about overbuilding there, given the strength in China?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. We're not concerned about overbuilding. We have -- one of the larger accounts that we have in China now, we've moved to a hub arrangement, which is, again, part of the inventory issue, but it's fully lined out. You can't overbuild in that envi
componenttext: No, no, no. We're not concerned about overbuilding. We have -- one of the larger accounts that we have in China now, we've moved to a hub arrangement, which is, again, part of the inventory issue, but it's fully lined out. You can't overbuild in that environment. So you basically just meet your customers' hub needs. They poll the open market broad customers in China. We work very closely with MediaTek and some of the other baseband partners to get a broad forecast. Some of the solutions that we sell into that ecosystem are fungible. So they can be sold to multiple customers that will net out the puts and takes of kind of the broader market within China. But, no, we feel very solid about the inventory dynamics and revenue dynamics with respect to China. We've been in that market for a long time. We were a 2G player, a 3G player. And now actually with 4G and our ability to expand reach, the market for us now is probably the best it's ever been.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And a quick follow-up. Earlier in the year, you talked about divesting Trans-Tech. I think it was a ceramic filter company. And I think in your last 10-Q, it looks like you're no longer divesting this asset. Can you talk about what made you change your mi
componenttext: And a quick follow-up. Earlier in the year, you talked about divesting Trans-Tech. I think it was a ceramic filter company. And I think in your last 10-Q, it looks like you're no longer divesting this asset. Can you talk about what made you change your mind on that?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, to answer your question specifically, they continue to be part of a business. We haven't gone ahead with that sale. And it's just a business that, at this point, we're comfortable keeping. And we think that there's some growth opportunity going forw
componenttext: Well, to answer your question specifically, they continue to be part of a business. We haven't gone ahead with that sale. And it's just a business that, at this point, we're comfortable keeping. And we think that there's some growth opportunity going forward associated with it.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just going back to the inventory build. Do you think this will be kind of a 1-quarter issue? Or is it something that it takes kind of into the December quarter to work down? And then any kind of sense of just for the gross margin impact that you've s
componenttext: Yes, just going back to the inventory build. Do you think this will be kind of a 1-quarter issue? Or is it something that it takes kind of into the December quarter to work down? And then any kind of sense of just for the gross margin impact that you've seen as you have to throttle back a bit?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as where we think it's going to be, it's going to be flat to slightly down going into this quarter. But remember, that's also supporting higher revenue growth going forward. So some of that is the impact of the revenue growth. The turns are go
componenttext: Yes, as far as where we think it's going to be, it's going to be flat to slightly down going into this quarter. But remember, that's also supporting higher revenue growth going forward. So some of that is the impact of the revenue growth. The turns are going to begin to move back to historical levels. So as far as the velocity of the inventory, you're going to see us get back there very, very quickly.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just going back from a dollar content perspective as you look into the full and upcoming launches, do you have just a general sense as to how you feel about the growth in dollar content?
componenttext: Got it. And then just going back from a dollar content perspective as you look into the full and upcoming launches, do you have just a general sense as to how you feel about the growth in dollar content?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we feel very positive about the growth in dollar content. And I know I've said it a couple of times already in the call, it's really twofold. It's continuing to do well in our core business and our core opportunities in mobile but also getting a large
componenttext: No, we feel very positive about the growth in dollar content. And I know I've said it a couple of times already in the call, it's really twofold. It's continuing to do well in our core business and our core opportunities in mobile but also getting a larger reach into some of these other opportunities within a handset, and you'll see that borne out by leading customers.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from the line of Harsh Kumar of Stephens Inc.
componenttext: Next question is from the line of Harsh Kumar of Stephens Inc.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the questions we get a lot from investors is about your BAW strategy or lack of it. How many of the upper-end slots in filters can TC SAW address? And eventually, what would you guys have to do to be able to get to that upper level of filters?
componenttext: One of the questions we get a lot from investors is about your BAW strategy or lack of it. How many of the upper-end slots in filters can TC SAW address? And eventually, what would you guys have to do to be able to get to that upper level of filters?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Harsh. Well, as I outlined earlier, we can address the upper level of filters today. We just -- we do it with foundry partners, for example. I would love to be able to build it in-house, and that's something that's not out of our reach. It j
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Harsh. Well, as I outlined earlier, we can address the upper level of filters today. We just -- we do it with foundry partners, for example. I would love to be able to build it in-house, and that's something that's not out of our reach. It just isn't there today. Our TC SAW capability has moved up in frequency where it was largely just a low band play, maybe 600 to 900 meg. We now have that technology well over 1 gig, getting close to 2 and 2.5 gig. And again, back to what I was mentioning before, we don't have an appetite for selling discrete filters. So when we sell a filter, it is wrapped within a complete system. So the filter contributes some level of performance. But you also have your HBT, your switch, your MCM and your ability to minimize losses within your layout. So a lot -- and that -- with Skyworks, virtually all of that I mentioned is controlled in-house. So think about us as a system solutions player. Filters play a role in that system, but the entirety of the architecture is what matters. So we've won programs with Huawei. We're close with some other customers. There may be a few opportunities where optimal filter performance is the #1 requirement. That may be the case for some of the discrete applications or maybe some super-high performance, high band sockets. Today, perhaps, we can't address that. But we have the engineering talent, the filter assets and the people and the processes in place to continue to push that envelope and growth.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And for my follow-up, Liam, what is the -- what are the 1 or 2 major focus areas for you in the first 12 months of your CEO-hood?
componenttext: Great. And for my follow-up, Liam, what is the -- what are the 1 or 2 major focus areas for you in the first 12 months of your CEO-hood?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, sure, thanks. Well, number one, we definitely want to continue this push by leveraging our core in mobile and taking advantage of this expanding opportunity that we mentioned, receive side technology, WiFi technology, GPS, power management and o
componenttext: Yes, yes, sure, thanks. Well, number one, we definitely want to continue this push by leveraging our core in mobile and taking advantage of this expanding opportunity that we mentioned, receive side technology, WiFi technology, GPS, power management and others, and try to create the same systems-level approach in that section that has worked so well for us in SkyOne and in transmit. That's one. The second is stepping up in IoT. I mean, this is a market we talked about for the last few years. We talked about broad market, but within that, the IoT landscape and the class of customers that we engage with today is phenomenal. And we have a unique opportunity because most of the players in IoT feature 1 or 2 connectivity topologies. We have WiFi. We have Bluetooth. We have ZigBee. We have low-power technology. We have power management. And we have a tremendous know-how on how to make connected things work and make them work wirelessly. So we're excited about that. We're going to put more resources around that part of our business. Some other opportunities that have really come along nicely, albeit still quite small, are markets like automotive. We're being pulled into some of the premier players that we mentioned in the opening remarks, bringing in full LTE modules in automotive, very high-performance, high-reliability modules. That's looking good. So we're going to fire on all of those cylinders, and then from there, continue to drive with the best people and the best execution in our space.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from the line of Craig Ellis of B. Riley.
componenttext: And the next question is from the line of Craig Ellis of B. Riley.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with a question for Don. Don, if I approach the gross margin issue in a different way. As you look at getting from where you are back to those 58% incremental gross margins and prioritizing the improvement drivers that can close that gap, what'
componenttext: I'll start with a question for Don. Don, if I approach the gross margin issue in a different way. As you look at getting from where you are back to those 58% incremental gross margins and prioritizing the improvement drivers that can close that gap, what's on the list? It sounds like getting inventory down is one item. I think I heard you mention that filter insourcing is another, but what else is on the list? And how quickly did those different factors come into play and really provide tailwinds for the margin structure of the business?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they come in very, very quickly, part of it when we talked about the inventory issue and the level-loading that's been going on. I mean, even though the hybrid model serves us really well, where we're able to pull -- in a down quarter, we're able to
componenttext: Yes, they come in very, very quickly, part of it when we talked about the inventory issue and the level-loading that's been going on. I mean, even though the hybrid model serves us really well, where we're able to pull -- in a down quarter, we're able to pull production capacity and externally. You're still not -- during this period, we weren't running completely full. So that's going to be something that's very quickly going to get us back up into the incremental margin track, and that's a big driver of this. And then the other thing is the new product launches as we move forward. We've said we're very focused on every new generation of product's going to provide incremental margins. So that will all be in the mix as we move forward. We're excited about some of the IoT opportunity, as Liam talked about. So those are the things, Craig, that -- and we have a lot of confidence in the visibility to get down the road to the 53% target. That's still right in front -- that's still in front of us, for sure.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the follow-up is for Liam. Liam, Skyworks, I think, has been well-known for being an above-industry average grower. It doesn't look like it's playing out that way this year, but we understand the challenges that exist with the large custome
componenttext: Okay. And then the follow-up is for Liam. Liam, Skyworks, I think, has been well-known for being an above-industry average grower. It doesn't look like it's playing out that way this year, but we understand the challenges that exist with the large customer. The question is, how patient will you be with the business in getting back to above-industry average growth organically? And at what point will you feel like you have to press for M&A to diversify the business and get back to some of the growth rates and relative growth rates that we're used to seeing from the company?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig. That's a great question. Well, first of all, I am committed and have great confidence that the organic business, the organic franchise will be an outperformer in terms of growth. Now we're a bigger company than we were a couple of years ago.
componenttext: Sure, Craig. That's a great question. Well, first of all, I am committed and have great confidence that the organic business, the organic franchise will be an outperformer in terms of growth. Now we're a bigger company than we were a couple of years ago. There's some level of maturity in unit growth, in mobile, which has been the biggest market for us. But we're able to augment that with the share moves that we've talked about and think again about the usage case, the entities that use mobile technology and what they want. And it's daunting. So I think we'll be solid in core mobile. And I'm very comfortable with the opportunity with TAM, given some of the new architectures and road maps that we have visibility into. Broad market needs to become much more of an IoT play for us. I think that's really what broad markets means now, and we have great solutions for it. I think we need to put more people behind it, more engineering and out-bound [ph] folks behind that. That should work. Now in parallel, M&A is absolutely an opportunity for Skyworks. We have a tremendous balance sheet. We generate a ton of cash. And I think we'll be able to do the right deal when it comes about. So -- but having said all that, day to day, we're running the franchise, optimizing the franchise, doing everything we can to continue to put the growth up, the margins up, and satisfy our customers. M&A is another area that we will continue to pursue.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question from the line of Mike Burton of Brean Capital.
componenttext: Next question from the line of Mike Burton of Brean Capital.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, we're a little early to be talking about the December quarter, but given your visibility into product ramps and kind of inventory levels, how do you think we should be thinking about the December quarter relative to kind of normal seasonalit
componenttext: So obviously, we're a little early to be talking about the December quarter, but given your visibility into product ramps and kind of inventory levels, how do you think we should be thinking about the December quarter relative to kind of normal seasonality? I think it's been bouncing around quite a bit, but kind of in the mid-single digits historically?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, I don't -- I think at this point, again, we can provide some color on it. We're not into guiding the numbers. But I think if you look at sort of the historical growth opportunity of high single digits, that's a number that I think is reasonable
componenttext: Yes, Mike, I don't -- I think at this point, again, we can provide some color on it. We're not into guiding the numbers. But I think if you look at sort of the historical growth opportunity of high single digits, that's a number that I think is reasonable for you to be modeling right now when you think about that opportunity.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And, Don, also, your thoughts on OpEx going forward? Anything relative to BAW development or anything else that we should think about as we frame out our models?
componenttext: Great. And, Don, also, your thoughts on OpEx going forward? Anything relative to BAW development or anything else that we should think about as we frame out our models?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, the BAW OpEx, the engineers that we have in the joint venture, our operations in Japan are already in the run rates. I mean, the investments we make will continue to be the headcount, which is primarily going to be engineering-focused. That's
componenttext: No, I mean, the BAW OpEx, the engineers that we have in the joint venture, our operations in Japan are already in the run rates. I mean, the investments we make will continue to be the headcount, which is primarily going to be engineering-focused. That's tended to be where we've done it. And I would go ahead and model, after the December quarter, if you're adding about 2 million a quarter from that level, I think that that's a reasonable assumption as we move forward. You can see during this last 3 quarters that with the backdrop we've dealing with, we've done a good job of managing that number fairly flat during that time frame. But going forward, we will be making investments, and it'll be primarily headcount.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from the line of Vijay Rakesh of Mizuho.
componenttext: And the next question is from the line of Vijay Rakesh of Mizuho.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the filter capacity, how much capacity are you adding this year? And is TDK completely insourced now?
componenttext: Just on the filter capacity, how much capacity are you adding this year? And is TDK completely insourced now?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you repeat that?
componenttext: Can you repeat that?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of filter capacity, how much capacity are you adding this year? And I know you are sourcing some filters from TDK. Is that completely insourced now?
componenttext: In terms of filter capacity, how much capacity are you adding this year? And I know you are sourcing some filters from TDK. Is that completely insourced now?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the filter capacity, right now, we're in pretty good shape. There's a possibility, as we try to move into certain specialty filters and perhaps move up in frequency, there could be additional CapEx. But we have -- we made a very robust move i
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the filter capacity, right now, we're in pretty good shape. There's a possibility, as we try to move into certain specialty filters and perhaps move up in frequency, there could be additional CapEx. But we have -- we made a very robust move in capital, expanding our line that we talked about. We now have about 3x the capacity that we had a couple of years ago, again, with a number of platforms and customers lined up to consume that. So that's where we are in filters. Yes, we do continue to buy standard devices, standard filters from third parties, TDK, one of those. And that's, potentially, something that could change over time. But right now, they are our supplier for some of our filters, that's correct.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And on the BAW side, Liam, you guys had talked about building out your own BAW filters. You have licensed it. Where are you in that road map?
componenttext: Got it. And on the BAW side, Liam, you guys had talked about building out your own BAW filters. You have licensed it. Where are you in that road map?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we're still looking into that as what is the right path to continue on that pace, and we absolutely plan to play in high band. We're playing in it now. I talked about the Huawei platform, and there are a few others. So that's something we'll
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we're still looking into that as what is the right path to continue on that pace, and we absolutely plan to play in high band. We're playing in it now. I talked about the Huawei platform, and there are a few others. So that's something we'll give you a little bit more color on perhaps on the next call, but it's an area that we absolutely understand what's needed to win. We're winning today with our current strategy, and we'll look at enhancing our strategy as we go forward.

componenttext: Liam, I just wanted to ask, as you look back over the last year given some of the inventory problems, especially with large customers, to the extent you had more of your products flowing through consignment hubs, do you think that would have limited some of the volatility you'd seen in the business? And if so, is there a push to try and bring more customers into consignment hubs going forward? And then I've got a follow-up for Don.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Quinn, well, hindsight, you never know how it would look, right? So consignment in hubs, some of our customers demand it, and we work with them on it and it's fine. Others, they don't operate with that model, and it works out fine, too. I think we ha
componenttext: Yes, Quinn, well, hindsight, you never know how it would look, right? So consignment in hubs, some of our customers demand it, and we work with them on it and it's fine. Others, they don't operate with that model, and it works out fine, too. I think we had a unique situation here in the early part of the year. I think all of us in tech, at least in mobile, the ecosystem in our peer group felt the wrinkles on that. We've learned from it to some degree. But I don't know if that would have been mitigated or altered with a different supply chain model. Ultimately, the products that we build go into end products that get sold through the channel. So I think that ultimately, that's all going to level out at some point. So we're not too concerned about it. Again, we have one of our larger customers now in Asia that is requiring a hub arrangement with us. So we have to work through that, and that was actually part of our inventory here that Don mentioned.

componenttext: Yes, Chris, we are. We are expecting that. I think what we're seeing is kind of a nice bundle of higher-performing players that are adopting some of that real rich content that we spoke about. That's one area. And then second area, kind of a value tier, we're seeing a nice move here in customers that become exporters into emerging markets. So it's twofold. Performance is going up in China. We're starting to see some real richness. Huawei's one example. There's a few others. Xiaomi is one. And then we're also seeing this great emerging market play that allows us through MediaTek and Spreadtrum and others to participate in an opportunity to connect that 3 billion unconnected. So it's twofold. And second half will be stronger in China.

componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to Skyworks Solutions fourth quarter and fiscal year 2016 earnings call. This call is being recorded. At this time, I will turn the call over to Mitch Haws, Investor Relations for Skyworks. Mr. Haws, please go ahead.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks' fourth fiscal quarter and year and 2016 conference call. On the call today are Liam Griffin, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Kris Sennesael, our Chief Financial Officer
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks' fourth fiscal quarter and year and 2016 conference call. On the call today are Liam Griffin, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Kris Sennesael, our Chief Financial Officer. 
Before we begin, I would like to remind everyone that our discussion will include statements relating to future results and expectations that are or may be considered forward-looking. Please refer to our earnings press release and resent SEC filings, including our annual report on Form 10-K, for information on certain risks that could cause actual outcomes to differ materially and adversely from any forward-looking statements made today. Additionally, the results and guidance we will discuss today are from our non-GAAP financials, consistent with the format we have used in the past. Please refer to our press release within the Investor Relations section of our company website for a complete reconciliation to GAAP.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Liam.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mitch, and welcome, everyone. The Skyworks team delivered solid Q4 and fiscal 2016 results, demonstrating the resiliency and power of our business model. To put a few metrics in perspective, we achieved record revenue of $3.3 billion; expanded gro
componenttext:
Thanks, Mitch, and welcome, everyone. The Skyworks team delivered solid Q4 and fiscal 2016 results, demonstrating the resiliency and power of our business model. To put a few metrics in perspective, we achieved record revenue of $3.3 billion; expanded gross margin of 280 basis points; delivered 37.8% operating margin; generated record operating cash flow of $1.1 billion, allowing us to return $727 million in cash to our shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases, more than double the amount from last year. And despite headwinds with one of our leading customers, we are pleased with our ability to deliver record results in fiscal year 2016.
Now on a high-level, we see strengthening dynamics in the core markets we serve. Specifically, we are in the midst of a massive sea change in the mobile usage case, given the utility and value that connected devices are beings of the world. We are supporting, and in many ways enabling, a mobile ecosystem that is cannibalizing traditional brick-and-mortar industries transforming the way we live, work and play. Wireless platforms have become virtual hubs for e-commerce, enterprise to cloud, social media, gaming and entertainment portals. Ultimately, these devices are a conduit for a new multi-trillion dollar connected economy across a wealth of innovative technology players.
Consider that the top 5 S&P 500 companies: namely Apple, GOOGL Alphabet, Microsoft, Facebook and Amazon are all monetizing these themes with mobile-centric business models. At the same time, smartphone architectures are evolving to accommodate this rapid increase in mobile data across a densely crowded spectrum. The usage case is a catalyst for higher speed, lower latency, secure and always on connectivity, which is challenging the capabilities of existing hardware and the supporting cellular infrastructure.
Our mission at Skyworks is resolving this daunting complexity with customized -- custom-level solutions, unburdening our customers while improving the user experience, with higher levels of efficiency, enhanced streaming capabilities and expanded network coverage. All of this translates into an expanding opportunity for Skyworks.
Recall that our focus is on the wireless connection, the most critical function linking the user to this incredible ecosystem. And in addition to the rise of mobile data, we are actively addressing 2 parallel growth drivers. First, connecting the unconnected. There remain 2 billion people that have yet to benefit from this dynamic ecosystem, and Skyworks will play a leading role in bringing this population online. In addition, we are committed to connecting everything as we address an estimated 20 billion new devices brought to market over the next 5 years. 
Skyworks is seamlessly enabling these massive opportunities with highly customized system solutions, supporting a broad set of protocols, including cellular LTE to WiFi, Bluetooth, ZigBee and emerging 5G standards.
In an effort to facilitate the explosive growth of data delivery, creation, movement in storage, our customers are implementing methods to improve performance with carrier aggregation, receive diversity and my mobile functionality. This dynamic involves a step function increase in levels of requisite analog and mixed-signal performance, enhanced power efficiency and high-precision filtering, as well as configurable systems integration capabilities.
Skyworks' broad portfolio and systems-level expertise are well aligned to resolve the intense performance demands facing our customers. And further, 5G will be yet another industry catalyst and significant content driver for Skyworks. This technology will drive band proliferation in higher frequencies and play squarely into our ability to address complexity with fully integrated systems. The breadth of our portfolio and our unique market reach continues to fuel a robust and diverse design win pipeline.
To illustrate, during the most recent quarter, we leveraged our leadership SkyOne architecture across scores of 4G LTE platforms, with customers like Huawei across their Honor 8 premium lineup. We are also powering the first Google-branded LTE Pixel smartphone. And we are capturing design wins across broader markets in the Internet of Things. In particular, we continue gaining traction with customers like Amazon, supporting their Echo and Tap digital assistants. We are also enabling NETGEAR's Orbi Home Router system and providing an integrated solution to Trilliant for use in their smart grid platforms.
In addition, we are deploying small cell solutions for several leading infrastructure providers in China. And in automotive, we are delivering 4G LTE solutions for use in both Land Rover and Jaguar modules -- models. These wins and others demonstrate our expanding customer and end market reach across both mobile platforms and the IoT.
At this point, I will turn the call over to Kris for his financial review.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Liam.Revenue for the fourth fiscal quarter was $835.4 million, up 11% sequentially and exceeding our guidance and consensus. Gross profit was $425.9 million or 51% of revenue, in line with our guidance and up 100 basis points from the fourth qua
componenttext:
Thanks, Liam.
Revenue for the fourth fiscal quarter was $835.4 million, up 11% sequentially and exceeding our guidance and consensus. Gross profit was $425.9 million or 51% of revenue, in line with our guidance and up 100 basis points from the fourth quarter last year. Operating expenses were $107.5 million, consistent with our guidance for flat sequential spending. We generated $318.4 million of operating income, translating into 38.1% operating margin. Our cash tax rate was 12.6%, driving net income of $277.6 million or $1.47 of diluted earnings per share, exceeding our guidance by $0.04.
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow. Cash flow from operations was a record $455 million, driven by higher profitability and significant improvements in working capital on a sequential basis. In particular, DSOs declined from 69 to 45 days. And days of inventory declined from 108 to 94 days, and we expect further reduction of inventory dollars and inventory days in Q1.
Capital expenditures were $16 million versus $57 million in Q3, reflecting the lower investment level now required for our TC SAW builder production. Further, in Q4, we repurchased 3 million shares at an average price of roughly $66 a share. And for fiscal '16, we have repurchased 8 million shares at an average price of just under $66 per share, helping us to reduce our share count from 195 million shares entering the fiscal year to 189 million shares exiting Q4. We also distributed over $200 million in dividends over the course of fiscal 2016, up 63% year-over-year. In summary, Skyworks returned 81% of our free cash flow or $727 million to our shareholders over the fiscal year, up from the 64% distributed in fiscal 2015.
Now moving on to our outlook. For the first fiscal quarter of 2017, we anticipate our revenue to be up 7% to 9% sequentially. At the midpoint of $902 million, we expect gross margin in the low 51% range. We expect operating expenses to be $112 million, further reducing our overall OpEx ratio to 12.4% of revenue.
Below the line, we anticipate around $1 million in interest and other expenses, and a cash tax rate of approximately 15%. We expect our share count to be roughly 187 million shares. With our revenue growth and continued operating leverage, we plan to generate non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $1.58 in the first fiscal quarter.
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Liam.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kris. So to quickly summarize, we delivered above-guidance results in the fourth fiscal quarter, closing out another record year, driven by increasing global demand for high-speed connectivity, coupled with strong operational execution. Skyworks'
componenttext:
Thanks, Kris. So to quickly summarize, we delivered above-guidance results in the fourth fiscal quarter, closing out another record year, driven by increasing global demand for high-speed connectivity, coupled with strong operational execution. Skyworks' system-level expertise and scale advantages are positioning us to capitalize on the rapidly expanding mobile and IoT ecosystems, particularly with 5G on the horizon. Our profitability and strong cash generation capabilities allow us to fund growth and deliver increasingly higher returns to our shareholders. Clearly, we remain well-positioned to realize our vision of connecting everyone and everything all the time.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, let's open the line for questions.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Liam, for my first one, your December sales outlook is above Street expectations. When I look at it though, it's still somewhat down year-on-year. componenttext: Sure. Thank you, Vivek. Well, as you outlined, the guidance here for the current quarter is up strong, 7% to 9% coming off an 11% sequential here in Q4. We continue to see great momentum with the flagship players, so not just the leading U.S. player but globally. We're starting to see strength there, and that's being represented in our numbers.

componenttext: Yes. I can't speak to what happens to our competitor. And we haven't seen any major changes to the pricing environment that has been very consistent over the last couple of quarters. And looking forward, we don't see any major changes there. Let me just, on the gross margin, highlight that in fiscal '16, we improved the gross margins with 280 basis points exiting the year, that's 51%, which clearly demonstrates the strong operational execution in terms of margin improvements. And we definitely want to continue to further drive operational efficiencies. And we believe that we can improve the gross margins with another 100 basis points exiting the fiscal year of 2017.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Thanks. And then maybe just a bigger picture question if you look at next year, you mentioned several drivers. Just curious when you look at carrier aggregation, obviously you're combining bands. And some of those bands may historically be a ball [ph] band. Just curious of your view in terms of whether SAW and TC SAW can address a lot of the transmit in terms of the carrier aggregation? And then when you look at next year, where do you see your biggest gains? You're able to get and receive game content in the larger phones. Where else do you see it picking up these DC content next year?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now that's a great question. So as you articulated, there's a couple of dynamics. We have been known for leadership in the transmit chain, with power and amplifier plus duplexers like SkyOne systems. That continues to be beneficial for us. We're probably
componenttext: Now that's a great question. So as you articulated, there's a couple of dynamics. We have been known for leadership in the transmit chain, with power and amplifier plus duplexers like SkyOne systems. That continues to be beneficial for us. We're probably 30% to 40% of the way of penetrating the market right now. New names like Huawei are adopting the technology. Players like Oppo and Vivo in China, and certainly the larger Tier 1s have been with us for a while. So on the transmit chain, we continue to move up in frequency. So we've got done a great job in low band. We're starting to win mid-band. We can address high-bandwidth foundry partners for --. So that part of the food chain looks really good. When you look at the receive side, we have a very unique strategy -- a leadership strategy. We've been able to implement high-content, high-performance solutions with the leading players in the market. That again now is starting to round out into China and to some other spaces where that value is quite unique and the performance requirements on a down link side are met so we could handle that. As you move further along though, you start to look at 5G, et cetera. We think that the way that transition will occur at with TDD as well as FDD, we have time division duplexing. Our ability to leverage TC SAW looks very good there, so we can encroach frequencies that have been the domain of bulk acoustic wave with our TC SAW with a performance advantage and also taking advantage of the unique protocols that we see in 5G.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: This is Richard on for Harsh. Just wanted to start off and look at a little deeper into the December guidance up 7% to 9%. What are some of the base assumptions for broad-based growth in mobile? What are you seeing at your largest customer? And then also within China, some of the buy siders that we talked to have talked about double order intake taken place over there. Are you seeing like that?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start with Q1 and we can touch on China. So we are seeing Q1 seasonally being strong in mobile across all of our major accounts in mobile looking good. And with great enrichment in content really steering the ship there. So we see that the Io
componenttext: Well, let me start with Q1 and we can touch on China. So we are seeing Q1 seasonally being strong in mobile across all of our major accounts in mobile looking good. And with great enrichment in content really steering the ship there. So we see that the IoT and broad markets business continue to look good. So we're up substantially on a year-over-year basis. IoT was up into the teens on an overall broad markets with a full fiscal year, we're up about 12%. So we continue to see opportunities there. And then if we think about China, we have -- yes, fortunately, China has changed a bit in the last couple of years. It's moved away from this 10 to 12 white box players, where it's a great deal of distribution and just kind of hoping for the best in terms of upgrade cycles and ensuring that you pick the right horses. What's happening now is it starting to coalesce around 3 or 4, or maybe 5 players with names like Huawei leading, Oppo, Vivo, Xiaomi and then you get into a long tail of others. So we play that directly with the top 4 or 5 direct engineer-to-engineer engagements. We also play the entire China theater with our baseband partners. So close collaboration with MediaTek, Spreadtrum, HiSilicon, even Qualcomm provides a buffer of diversification. So right now, China has been a solid market. We handicap it quite well. We analyze the data from a distributors. We look at the poll rates and the upgrade data that we get from China mobile and others and we feel we have a very balanced outlook. I don't expect any volatility through any double ordering or anything like that. I don't see that, but we'll maintain a cautious view as we look out.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's extremely helpful. And then kind of wanted to get your sense on what you look for, what are your criteria is for M&A and what's the appetite for M&A right now?
componenttext: That's extremely helpful. And then kind of wanted to get your sense on what you look for, what are your criteria is for M&A and what's the appetite for M&A right now?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. Well, I mean, the good news for us is that we're very bullish on the opportunities in front of us today at Skyworks. There's a great deal for us to do in our core markets in mobile and IoT in expanding our broad portfolio. We like what we see
componenttext: Sure, sure. Well, I mean, the good news for us is that we're very bullish on the opportunities in front of us today at Skyworks. There's a great deal for us to do in our core markets in mobile and IoT in expanding our broad portfolio. We like what we see there. There's a tremendous need to support great customers looking forward. So M&A isn't something that is mission critical for Skyworks. But having said that, we continue to look at opportunities if they come about. Our track record, as you know, reflects flex that we are highly disciplined when it comes to M&A. Ideal needs to meet out all of our stringent criteria. You can see that we've done a few deals in the last few years the Panasonic JV has closed, bringing great TC technology -- TC SAW technology in-house. We got us ID deal a few years ago for WiFi technology, that's played out before beautifully. And even the power management deal with Advance Analogic. And all of those elements play very well into our long-term strategy. So we will keep our lens open for opportunities as they come about but again very stringent financial criteria.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Congratulations on turning the corner and sequential growth on the inventory. Kris, I wanted to start on a longer-term question on the growth of the business. So one of the supply chain players really in the reporting season think that smartphones will grow about 5% through 2020. So I'm not asking you to endorse that, but if that were the industry's growth rate, what growth rate would you be satisfied with organically? And do you feel like you've gotten got enough leveraging the per fully to drive sufficient organic growth there? Or do you need to have a blended organic and inorganic strategy?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think organically, Craig, if you look at the unit great, which is approximately as indicated about 5% on smartphones. It's the content lever that we're most excited about. And if you listened through the prepared remarks when the reasons why we ta
componenttext: Well, I think organically, Craig, if you look at the unit great, which is approximately as indicated about 5% on smartphones. It's the content lever that we're most excited about. And if you listened through the prepared remarks when the reasons why we talked about this mobile ecosystem in some of these great companies with our monetizing it is that they really are driving change. They're driving change with our customers and our customers are driving that change to us. And often it's a give-and-take. And in many cases, we're at the drawing board in crafting these incredible systems that move data. So we see content being really the key focus. So we see unit growth could be 3% to 5%, maybe as high as 7% in top line units. But it's the content lever that is unique and I think that is where -- I know that is where Skyworks outperforms. The higher the content in terms of the complexity and the performance needs, that's when we do our best work. So with that said, we would expect to be at or around double digits across the board, could be higher in some cases depending on the market and the mix.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then one for Kris. Kris, you mentioned that you expect that was my just to be up 100 basis points this year, that's solid but it is just 40% of what the business had done in the just completed year. So as we look at the performance of
componenttext: That's helpful. And then one for Kris. Kris, you mentioned that you expect that was my just to be up 100 basis points this year, that's solid but it is just 40% of what the business had done in the just completed year. So as we look at the performance of the business, should we expect that as the expended manufacturing facility, both the Panasonic and in packaging, as that really ramps and hits its operational stride that longer term we can get back to yours for their gross margins can improve on a multi-hundred basis point basis? Or is this the new run rate for the business?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, there are definitely multiple levers to improve gross margins. As Liam just explained, we see some above market revenue growth. And of course, incremental revenue and volume growth helps to absorb our fixed cost structure. Secondly, we are in sou
componenttext: Yes. No, there are definitely multiple levers to improve gross margins. As Liam just explained, we see some above market revenue growth. And of course, incremental revenue and volume growth helps to absorb our fixed cost structure. Secondly, we are in sourcing the filters in our own filter fab, and that is driving further margin expansion. And that, of course, there is the normal tackle and blocking and operational efficiency improvements including cycle time reduction, yield improvements and internal and external cost reductions. And maybe last but not least as well, we do see a further mix improvement in some other areas outside of mobile that have slightly above-average gross margin. And when you put it all together, we are comfortable that we can further improve our gross margins.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Atif Malik with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll go next to Atif Malik with Citigroup.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Liam, the first question, you talked about the criteria for M&A and I think the past, Skyworks has talked about acquiring something in the $2 billion to $3 billion range kind of size of the company. And can you just remind us what else in the criteria you
componenttext: Liam, the first question, you talked about the criteria for M&A and I think the past, Skyworks has talked about acquiring something in the $2 billion to $3 billion range kind of size of the company. And can you just remind us what else in the criteria you're looking at? Is this still the right size of the deals you're looking at?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't really put any boundaries on deal size. I think it's more of the merits of the opportunity and how it plays within the Skyworks franchise so to speak. So we definitely look for opportunities that -- we talk -- everyone talks about synergie
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't really put any boundaries on deal size. I think it's more of the merits of the opportunity and how it plays within the Skyworks franchise so to speak. So we definitely look for opportunities that -- we talk -- everyone talks about synergies in terms of the accretion and financials, but I also want to see entities that really do better with the Skyworks brand than they would separately. We talked about some success stories, SiGe, Panasonic, even AGI are examples of that. So we would like to have the kind of acquisitions that really raise the overall franchise that bring us into new technology opportunities that perhaps augment our strength already in the positions in the market that we enjoy today. So it's really is a complex answer. There isn't one simple thing that we're looking for. It's a number of things. We do have a very, very high bar. We've worked at a lot of franchise have a lot of assets. And for us, the bars are quite high, and I like that. I think we've worked really hard to generate the cash that now has been phenomenal for us and I think we're in a great track record to continue to do that. We have the powder to do the right deals when they come along but we'll continue to be very, very vigilant.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then as a follow-up, you guys had pretty good design wins in the latest iPhone -- modules. And Murata was quoted in a Nikkei article in Japan that they could take pricing done by like 1/3 in order to get the sockets back. And can you just talk a
componenttext: Sure. And then as a follow-up, you guys had pretty good design wins in the latest iPhone -- modules. And Murata was quoted in a Nikkei article in Japan that they could take pricing done by like 1/3 in order to get the sockets back. And can you just talk about the stickiness of these wins? And how should we think about you guys sustaining this content going into next year?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes. I mean, all of these complex solutions that you've alluded to, whether they where the lead customer or the top 3 or 4 are highly customized. I know what the offer. It's highly customized, it is very sticky. These are engineered into your develo
componenttext: Sure. Yes. I mean, all of these complex solutions that you've alluded to, whether they where the lead customer or the top 3 or 4 are highly customized. I know what the offer. It's highly customized, it is very sticky. These are engineered into your develop solutions, highly calibrated within the customer's ecosystem. There's little risk that there'll be anyone will be unseated or there'll be any pricing action post design win. And then it's incumbency, the ability to execute, the ability to manage your capacities and execute to supply and all those other things that keep you in on the long term. So we feel really good about the position with the leading accounts and our ability to grow at highly complex solutions that better -- in every new cycle, upgraded all through change to meet customers' needs.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chris Caso with CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chris Caso with CLSA.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is regarding the inventory levels. Could you talk a bit about where you expect those to be exiting the quarter? And I suppose you want to have the inventory levels down entering the season of these lower March quarter. Just talk a little bi
componenttext: First question is regarding the inventory levels. Could you talk a bit about where you expect those to be exiting the quarter? And I suppose you want to have the inventory levels down entering the season of these lower March quarter. Just talk a little bit about that, about the magnitude of any potential reduction that you'd like to see exiting the year.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so during Q4, we reduced our days of inventory from 108 days to 94 days. That's a 13% reduction and we are pleased with that. We do expect in Q1, to further reduce inventory, both as an absolute dollar level as well as in terms of days of inventory w
componenttext: Yes, so during Q4, we reduced our days of inventory from 108 days to 94 days. That's a 13% reduction and we are pleased with that. We do expect in Q1, to further reduce inventory, both as an absolute dollar level as well as in terms of days of inventory where we target to get to approximately 85 days.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's 85 days by the end of the year or is that a target for the future?
componenttext: Okay. That's 85 days by the end of the year or is that a target for the future?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: There will be some seasonal fluctuations as you go through the normal seasonality. But on average, that's what we target.
componenttext: There will be some seasonal fluctuations as you go through the normal seasonality. But on average, that's what we target.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: We have a question from Ambrish Srivastava with BMO Capital Markets.

componenttext: This is Kulin Patel calling in for Ambrish. For the year-on-year revenue headwind, you mentioned headwind with your largest customer. Is all the headwind due to legacy units or was there any share loss?
