componenttext: No. No share losses. This is really just about some headwinds on legacy units that were shipped earlier in the year, trued up now here by the middle of the end of this quarter.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And for the CapEx, you mentioned it's down because of the lower investments in TC SAW. How do we think about it for the new fiscal year. With your CapEx plan for the year, are there any investments in the pipeline?
componenttext: Okay. And for the CapEx, you mentioned it's down because of the lower investments in TC SAW. How do we think about it for the new fiscal year. With your CapEx plan for the year, are there any investments in the pipeline?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, just normal course. In fiscal '16, we spent roughly $189 million. For fiscal '17, we target $200 million to $220 million of CapEx.
componenttext: No, just normal course. In fiscal '16, we spent roughly $189 million. For fiscal '17, we target $200 million to $220 million of CapEx.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just that. I mean if you go back to -- a couple of years back, we were $400 million, $430 million to really outfit and install the significant TC SAW facility, which is a 3 billion unit per year producer of high-performance filters, so that's
componenttext: Yes, let me just that. I mean if you go back to -- a couple of years back, we were $400 million, $430 million to really outfit and install the significant TC SAW facility, which is a 3 billion unit per year producer of high-performance filters, so that's a big bump up. With that behind us, the run rate CapEx that Kris mentioned is sustainable. It's enough for us. We can do a great job with that capital and monetize our assets and filters as well.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: And then I guess I had a question about the revenue minus your largest customer. And you had guided it sort of up in the range of 10% to 12% for the September quarter. Can you give us what that actually came in at? And what the guidance implies if I exclude your largest customer?

componenttext: Yes, so in terms of the full year -- I can give you the full year. The full year '16, the balance of our business ex- our largest customer was up about 11% to 12%, and it's a portfolio of broad market, either in mobile absent the largest customer and other IoT businesses. So that's kind of the roughest cut at the high level. In Q1, our largest customer a seasonally strong, of course, go into a seasonal ramp. But the top 3 Tier 1 accounts are also ramping aggressively into Q1.

componenttext: Our next question is from Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: Question on the diverse margin outlooks for the December quarter. Typically, you'd see some fall through in terms of the higher volume. So I know you mentioned you working the inventory, maybe that's an influence. Anything else potentially from a mix perspective in terms of some of the new wins, what they might carry versus a year ago?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: No. Yes, from a mix point of view, Q1 traditionally has a higher mobile revenue which is slightly below average. And so that has an impact on the gross margin.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up, there's a number question asked on M&A and cap allocation. The diversification angle specifically, how important is that to the company as you explore potential deals out there?
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up, there's a number question asked on M&A and cap allocation. The diversification angle specifically, how important is that to the company as you explore potential deals out there?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well I mean, diversification is an element. It's something that we look for but it's really -- it isn't the only criteria. It's not the underlying criteria. I think we're looking for opportunities that really drive the entirety of the business. And as we
componenttext: Well I mean, diversification is an element. It's something that we look for but it's really -- it isn't the only criteria. It's not the underlying criteria. I think we're looking for opportunities that really drive the entirety of the business. And as we said, we feel really good about what mobile is bringing. It's a lot more than what the market expected 3 or 4 years ago or 5 years ago and what we're seeing from our customers is just a daunting and relentless portion of performance. And what was really enjoying our product developments and revenue streams that weren't on the radar screen 5 years ago. Diversity received, we talked about WiFi has been taking off, our GPS location systems are taking off. We're seeing more and more reach into our filter franchise. So there's just a lot to do. So we wouldn't look at a deal on the merit of their persecution as primary motive. It would be nice in some cases but we would also entertain opportunities that really help us advance our core business.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We now have a question from Vijay Rakesh with Mizuho.
componenttext: We now have a question from Vijay Rakesh with Mizuho.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking at your gross margins for the December quarter. Last year, when your top line was up 5%, your margins improved pretty nicely, 100, 140 bps. Here, you're guidance that. Are the incremental gross margins much lower than what you had historicall
componenttext: Just looking at your gross margins for the December quarter. Last year, when your top line was up 5%, your margins improved pretty nicely, 100, 140 bps. Here, you're guidance that. Are the incremental gross margins much lower than what you had historically?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our incremental gross margins are in the mid-50s right now.
componenttext: Our incremental gross margins are in the mid-50s right now.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And as you look at the BAW road map, I know you guys if you're getting BAW from some of your foundry partners. Can you update us how your road map looks there? Are you expecting any BAW products launching here? Or still expecting to some kind of B
componenttext: Got it. And as you look at the BAW road map, I know you guys if you're getting BAW from some of your foundry partners. Can you update us how your road map looks there? Are you expecting any BAW products launching here? Or still expecting to some kind of BAW to be kind of -- take that part of the bands, too?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I mean, there are significant growth opportunities in the areas that we are a strong today across TC SAW. We continue to push their frequency range in TC SAW quite nicely. We're winning a lot of products there not only investment but also on d
componenttext: Sure. Well, I mean, there are significant growth opportunities in the areas that we are a strong today across TC SAW. We continue to push their frequency range in TC SAW quite nicely. We're winning a lot of products there not only investment but also on diversity receive. So BAW technology is not critical. It's not mission-critical. We understand where it is and roadmaps and where it isn't in roadmaps. We are making great progress again in raising the market opportunity for our TC solutions. And also when you look at things like 5G, what we're seeing is that there's more and more TDD capability in 5G than FDD. So when you go to TDD, time division duplexing, you don't require a BAW filter or a BAW duplexer, you can do it with TC and meet its frequency, so that's another expanding opportunity for us. So having said all that, we have access to BAW. We're using it today in some of our flagship products with foundry partners. We always take a look at make versus buy. Is it an opportunity for us to invest in -- continue to weigh that balance. But we are sure that we're going to be able to address the market as we need to. We'll be able to address the cultural opportunities and the systems engines that we've been delivering for years. So there's no stop on that.

componenttext: Yes -- no, correct. I think as we anticipate typical market seasonality for our spaces, maybe 10% to 15% down in the March quarter. Our mission as to offset that to some degree. We're confident we can do it, last year was a bit of -- so our job is to continue outperform the market in March.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Ian Ing from MTM Partners.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kris. Looks like broad markets went down about 5% it went from 29% of sales to 25%. So is that just lumpiness or anything happening in WiFi or IoT?
componenttext: Kris. Looks like broad markets went down about 5% it went from 29% of sales to 25%. So is that just lumpiness or anything happening in WiFi or IoT?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The issue there was more around infrastructure more than anything else. The IoT space was about flat. That will come back up again in March. And infrastructure was a bit of a drag on broad markets in the quarter.
componenttext: Yes. The issue there was more around infrastructure more than anything else. The IoT space was about flat. That will come back up again in March. And infrastructure was a bit of a drag on broad markets in the quarter.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe talk more about SkyBlue. It looks like you've got some nice power efficiency solutions like go beyond envelope tracking. It sounds like you had Panasonic. Should we expect any progress in some other geographies and other OEMs?
componenttext: And then maybe talk more about SkyBlue. It looks like you've got some nice power efficiency solutions like go beyond envelope tracking. It sounds like you had Panasonic. Should we expect any progress in some other geographies and other OEMs?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question. I'm glad you brought that up. So SkyBlue is a -- that Skyworks uses really as a another way to provide efficiency in the amplification and transmission food chain. And so we do that with the very unique proprietary architecture we call Sky
componenttext: Great question. I'm glad you brought that up. So SkyBlue is a -- that Skyworks uses really as a another way to provide efficiency in the amplification and transmission food chain. And so we do that with the very unique proprietary architecture we call SkyBlue. It is embedded in some of our system solutions. If you looked at some of the leading platforms that we've announced and you can see that there were teardowns both devices are apparent there. They made up with our SkyOne solutions to provide higher levels of efficiency, incredible levels, higher than EP, in many cases. It's a device that is baseband agnostic. We're working with all the key chipset providers as well. And it is very early for us right now. We have a long way to go with this solution. We're continuing to provide new and additional revs with our greater performance but it is in production with 4 or 5 key brands today.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ed Snyder with Charter Equity Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Snyder with Charter Equity Research.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Liam, if the iPhone 6s inventories are all consumed by the time you exit December as you indicated, why should we expect to see orders for those parts to you from Apple if they keep selling that phone in 2018? Is that a an erroneous assumption? But if the
componenttext: Liam, if the iPhone 6s inventories are all consumed by the time you exit December as you indicated, why should we expect to see orders for those parts to you from Apple if they keep selling that phone in 2018? Is that a an erroneous assumption? But if the phone's still being built after they consume all of their raw material from you, then I would expect you'd see some sort of revenue for that product. And then on MediaTek Phase 2, Phase 3, -- has been strong for you and for your competitors. And I know that Phase 2, Phase 3, only use modules with searches and amplifiers. But it's has like MediaTek may be moving to pads earlier than expected. You currently do not sell discrete filters into that market. But if they go to pads and you're 1 of the 2 big suppliers of those parts already, why should we expect that your filter demand should step up significantly because MediaTek would obviously be buying those filters from whoever's supplying the modules and that's going to be you and maybe --?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great insights, Ed. So on the first one, certainly if there were additional demand requirements for the legacy products with our lead customer, we'd be well positioned to deliver and that could be incremental revenue for us, so that's one. And then w
componenttext: Yes, great insights, Ed. So on the first one, certainly if there were additional demand requirements for the legacy products with our lead customer, we'd be well positioned to deliver and that could be incremental revenue for us, so that's one. And then with respect to MediaTek, you got a friend. I mean, so right now we have a very strong partnership with MediaTek. And one products that has done really well in that ecosystem is our SkyLiTE product. And so the SkyLiTE product -- and I know you get this but for everyone. It is really a SkyOne solution absent the filters. So we lay out all the required amplification, transmit receipts, switching. And we do everything but the filters and we allow the MediaTek ecosystem, the customers that use the MediaTek chipset, to pick and choose the filters. That's been the way of the land here for a while. Next rev, we are looking at integrating, leveraging our TC SAW capability to bring in a complete PAD or SkyOne-like product of these MediaTek opportunity. It's a great opportunity. We're working on it right. Hopefully we'll have more to report for you here in the next quarter.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks' Fourth Fiscal Quarter and Year-end 2016 Conference Call. On the call today are Liam Griffin, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Kris Sennesael, our Chief Financial Officer
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks' Fourth Fiscal Quarter and Year-end 2016 Conference Call. On the call today are Liam Griffin, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Kris Sennesael, our Chief Financial Officer. 
Before we begin, I would like to remind everyone that our discussion will include statements relating to future results and expectations that are or may be considered forward-looking. Please refer to our earnings press release and recent SEC filings, including our annual report on Form 10-K, for information on certain risks that could cause actual outcomes to differ materially and adversely from any forward-looking statements made today. 
Additionally, the results and guidance we will discuss today are from our non-GAAP financials, consistent with the format we have used in the past. Please refer to our press release within the Investor Relations section of our company website for a complete reconciliation to GAAP.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Liam.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mitch, and welcome, everyone. The Skyworks team delivered solid Q4 and fiscal 2016 results, demonstrating the resiliency and power of our business model. To put a few metrics in perspective, we achieved record revenue of $3.3 billion; expanded gro
componenttext:
Thanks, Mitch, and welcome, everyone. The Skyworks team delivered solid Q4 and fiscal 2016 results, demonstrating the resiliency and power of our business model. To put a few metrics in perspective, we achieved record revenue of $3.3 billion; expanded gross margin by 280 basis points; delivered 37.8% operating margin; generated record operating cash flow of $1.1 billion, allowing us to return $727 million in cash to our shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases, more than double the amount from last year. And despite headwinds with one of our leading customers, we are pleased with our ability to deliver record results in fiscal year 2016.
Now at a high level, we see strengthening dynamics in the core markets we serve. Specifically, we are in the midst of a massive sea change in the mobile usage case, given the utility and value that connected devices are bringing to the world. We are supporting and in many ways, enabling a mobile ecosystem that is cannibalizing traditional brick-and-mortar industries, transforming the way we live, work and play. Wireless platforms have become virtual hubs for e-commerce, enterprise cloud, social media, gaming and entertainment portals. Ultimately, these devices are a conduit for a new multi-trillion dollar connected economy across a wealth of innovative technology players.
Consider that the top 5 S&P 500 companies: namely Apple, Google Alphabet, Microsoft, Facebook and Amazon are all monetizing these themes with mobile-centric business models. At the same time, smartphone architectures are evolving to accommodate this rapid increase in mobile data across a densely crowded spectrum. The usage case is a catalyst for higher speed, lower latency, secure and always-on connectivity, which is challenging the capabilities of existing hardware and the supporting cellular infrastructure.
Our mission at Skyworks is resolving this daunting complexity with customized -- custom-level solutions, unburdening our customers while improving the user experience, with higher levels of efficiency, enhanced streaming capabilities and expanded network coverage. All of this translates into an expanding opportunity for Skyworks. Recall that our focus is on the wireless connection, the most critical function linking the user to this incredible ecosystem. 
And in addition to the rise of mobile data, we are actively addressing 2 parallel growth drivers. First, connecting the unconnected. There remain 2 billion people that have yet to benefit from this dynamic ecosystem, and Skyworks will play a leading role in bringing this population online. In addition, we are committed to connecting everything as we address an estimated 20 billion new devices brought to market over the next 5 years. Skyworks is seamlessly enabling these massive opportunities with highly customized system solutions, supporting a broad set of protocols, including cellular LTE to WiFi, Bluetooth, ZigBee and emerging 5G standards.
In an effort to facilitate the explosive growth of data delivery, creation, movement and storage, our customers are implementing methods to improve performance with carrier aggregation, receive diversity and MIMO functionality. This dynamic involves a step function increase in levels of requisite analog and mixed-signal performance, enhanced power efficiency and high-precision filtering, as well as configurable systems integration capabilities.
Skyworks' broad portfolio and systems-level expertise are well aligned to resolve the intense performance demands facing our customers. And further, 5G will be yet another industry catalyst and significant content driver for Skyworks. This technology will drive band proliferation in higher frequencies and play squarely into our ability to address complexity with fully integrated systems. 
The breadth of our portfolio and our unique market reach continues to fuel a robust and diverse design win pipeline. To illustrate, during the most recent quarter, we leveraged our leadership SkyOne architecture across scores of 4G LTE platforms, with customers like Huawei across their Honor 8 premium lineup. We are also powering the first Google-branded LTE Pixel smartphone. And we are capturing design wins across broader markets in the Internet of Things. In particular, we continue gaining traction with customers like Amazon, supporting their Echo and Tap digital assistance. We are also enabling NETGEAR's Orbi home router system and providing an integrated solution to Trilliant for use in their smart grid platforms.
In addition, we are deploying small-cell solutions for several leading infrastructure providers in China. And in automotive, we are delivering 4G LTE solutions for use in both Land Rover and Jaguar modules -- models. These wins and others demonstrate our expanding customer and end market reach across both mobile platforms and the IoT.
At this point, I will turn the call over to Kris for his financial review.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Liam. Revenue for the fourth fiscal quarter was $835.4 million, up 11% sequentially and exceeding our guidance and consensus. Gross profit was $425.9 million or 51% of revenue, in line with our guidance and up 100 basis points from the fourth quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Liam. Revenue for the fourth fiscal quarter was $835.4 million, up 11% sequentially and exceeding our guidance and consensus. Gross profit was $425.9 million or 51% of revenue, in line with our guidance and up 100 basis points from the fourth quarter last year. Operating expenses were $107.5 million, consistent with our guidance for flat sequential spending. We generated $318.4 million of operating income, translating into 38.1% operating margin. Our cash tax rate was 12.6%, driving net income of $277.6 million or $1.47 of diluted earnings per share, exceeding our guidance by $0.04.
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow. Cash flow from operations was a record $455 million, driven by higher profitability and significant improvements in working capital on a sequential basis. In particular, DSOs declined from 69 to 45 days. And days of inventory declined from 108 to 94 days, and we expect further reduction of inventory dollars and inventory days in Q1. Capital expenditures were $16 million versus $57 million in Q3, reflecting the lower investment level now required for our TC SAW filter production. 
Further, in Q4, we repurchased 3 million shares at an average price of roughly $66 a share. And for fiscal '16, we have repurchased 8 million shares at an average price of just under $66 per share, helping us to reduce our share count from 195 million shares entering the fiscal year to 189 million shares exiting Q4. We also distributed over $200 million in dividends over the course of fiscal 2016, up 63% year-over-year. 
In summary, Skyworks returned 81% of our free cash flow or $727 million to our shareholders over the fiscal year, up from the 64% distributed in fiscal 2015.
Now moving on to our outlook. For the first fiscal quarter of 2017, we anticipate our revenue to be up 7% to 9% sequentially. At the midpoint of $902 million, we expect gross margin in the low 51% range. We expect operating expenses to be $112 million, further reducing our overall OpEx ratio to 12.4% of revenue.
Below the line, we anticipate around $1 million in interest and other expenses, and a cash tax rate of approximately 15%. We expect our share count to be roughly 187 million shares. With our revenue growth and continued operating leverage, we plan to generate non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $1.58 in the first fiscal quarter.
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Liam.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kris. So to quickly summarize, we delivered above-guidance results in the fourth fiscal quarter, closing out another record year, driven by increasing global demand for high-speed connectivity, coupled with strong operational execution. Skyworks'
componenttext:
Thanks, Kris. So to quickly summarize, we delivered above-guidance results in the fourth fiscal quarter, closing out another record year, driven by increasing global demand for high-speed connectivity, coupled with strong operational execution. Skyworks' systems-level expertise and scale advantages are positioning us to capitalize on the rapidly expanding mobile and IoT ecosystems, particularly with 5G on the horizon. Our profitability and strong cash generation capabilities allow us to fund growth and deliver increasingly higher returns to our shareholders. 
Clearly, we remain well positioned to realize our vision of connecting everyone and everything all the time.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, let's open the lines for questions.

componenttext: Liam, for my first one, your December sales outlook is above Street expectations. When I look at it though, it's still somewhat down year-on-year. When do you think you will get back to what has been a historical sort of high single-digit, double-digit growth rate from a top line perspective? And as part of that, how's the visibility into content gains of -- and the flagship phones for next year?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thank you, Vivek. Well, as you outlined, the guidance here for the current quarter is up strong, 7% to 9%, coming off an 11% sequential here in Q4. So we certainly see the momentum coming back into our business. With respect to year-over-year comps,
componenttext: Sure. Thank you, Vivek. Well, as you outlined, the guidance here for the current quarter is up strong, 7% to 9%, coming off an 11% sequential here in Q4. So we certainly see the momentum coming back into our business. With respect to year-over-year comps, we're confident that we will be up on a year-over-year basis in Q2, fiscal Q2. We continue to see great momentum with the flagship players, not just the leading U.S. player but globally. We're starting to see strength there, and that's being represented in our numbers.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And as my follow-up, maybe one for Kris. On gross margins, if you could address the impact on gross margins from both fab utilization and just the market pricing, because I think you had mentioned you will take down inventory over the next 1 or 2
componenttext: Got it. And as my follow-up, maybe one for Kris. On gross margins, if you could address the impact on gross margins from both fab utilization and just the market pricing, because I think you had mentioned you will take down inventory over the next 1 or 2 quarters. What is the impact on utilization and gross margins? And sort of part b of that is, your competitor just reported very weak gross margins. And I'm wondering if that's a company-specific issue for them, or are you seeing any pricing issues from a market perspective?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I can't speak to what happens to our competitor. And we haven't seen any major changes to the pricing environment. That has been very consistent over the last couple of quarters. And looking forward, we don't see any major changes there. Let me just,
componenttext: Yes. I can't speak to what happens to our competitor. And we haven't seen any major changes to the pricing environment. That has been very consistent over the last couple of quarters. And looking forward, we don't see any major changes there. Let me just, on the gross margin, highlight that in fiscal '16, we improved the gross margins with 280 basis points exiting the year at 51%, which clearly demonstrates a strong operational execution in terms of margin improvements. And we definitely want to continue to further drive operational efficiencies. And we believe that we can improve the gross margins with another 100 basis points exiting the fiscal year of 2017.

componenttext: Sure, Blayne. Yes, I mean, in our 902, we don't have the full complement of what will be the legacy products with one of our customers. So some of that had been invoiced early in the year as we articulated. So it's -- but I will tell you that by the time this quarter is exited, we're clean. We're back on track. So again, we're pleased with the ability to bring up a 7% to 9% top line off of an 11%. We feel really good about our content position with the leading platforms, but there is a slight -- an abating headwind but a bit of a touch of that in the 902 versus the prior year.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just a bigger picture question. As you look at next year, you mentioned several drivers. Just curious, when you look at carrier aggregation, obviously you're combining bands. And some of those bands may historically be a BAW band. So just c
componenttext: And then maybe just a bigger picture question. As you look at next year, you mentioned several drivers. Just curious, when you look at carrier aggregation, obviously you're combining bands. And some of those bands may historically be a BAW band. So just curious of your view in terms of whether SAW and TC SAW can address a lot of the transmit in terms of the carrier aggregation. And then when you look at next year, where do you see your biggest gains? You were able to get and receive the same content in the larger phones. Where else do you see picking up these in content next year?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now that's a great question. So as you articulated, there's a couple of dynamics. We have been known for leadership in the transmit chain, with power amplifier and power amplifier plus duplexers, SkyOne-like systems. That continues to be beneficial for us
componenttext: Now that's a great question. So as you articulated, there's a couple of dynamics. We have been known for leadership in the transmit chain, with power amplifier and power amplifier plus duplexers, SkyOne-like systems. That continues to be beneficial for us. We're probably 30% to 40% of the way of penetrating the market now. New names like Huawei are adopting the technology. Players like OPPO and Vivo in China, and certainly the larger Tier 1s have been with us for a while. So on the transmit chain, we continue to move up in frequency. So we've done a great job in low band. We're starting to win mid-band. We can address high band with foundry partners for BAWs. So that part of the food chain looks really good. When you look at the receive side, we have a very unique strategy, a leadership strategy. We've been able to implement high-content, high-performance solutions with the leading players in the market. That again now is starting to round out into China and some other spaces where that value is quite unique, and the performance requirements on the downlink side are met so we can handle that. As you move further along though, you start to look at 5G, et cetera, we think that the way that transmission will occur with TDD as well as FDD, we have time division duplexing, our ability to leverage TC SAW looks very good there. So we can encroach frequencies that had been a domain of bulk acoustic wave with our TC SAW, with performance advantage and also taking advantage of the unique protocols that we see in 5G.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Harsh Kumar with Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Harsh Kumar with Stephens.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard in for Harsh. Just wanted to start off and look at -- a little bit deeper into the December quarter guidance of 7% to 9%. What are some of the base assumptions for broad-based growth versus growth in mobile? What are you seeing at your lar
componenttext: This is Richard in for Harsh. Just wanted to start off and look at -- a little bit deeper into the December quarter guidance of 7% to 9%. What are some of the base assumptions for broad-based growth versus growth in mobile? What are you seeing at your largest customer? And then also within China, some of the buy siders that we talked to have talked about double ordering taking place over there. Are you seeing anything like that?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start with Q1, and then we can touch on China. So we are seeing Q1 seasonally being strong in mobile across all of our major accounts in mobile looking good, and with a great enrichment in content really steering the ship there. So we see tha
componenttext: Well, let me start with Q1, and then we can touch on China. So we are seeing Q1 seasonally being strong in mobile across all of our major accounts in mobile looking good, and with a great enrichment in content really steering the ship there. So we see that the IoT in broad markets business continues to look good. We're up substantially on a year-over-year basis. IoT was up into the high teens on overall broad markets. For the full fiscal year, we're up about 12%. So we continue to see opportunities there. And then if we think about China, we have -- yes, fortunately, China has changed a bit in the last couple of years. It's moved away from this 10 to 12 white box players, where there's a great deal of distribution and just kind of hoping for the best in terms of upgrade cycles and ensuring that you pick the right horses. What's happening now is it's starting to coalesce around 3 or 4, or maybe 5 players with names like Huawei, leading Oppo, Vivo, Xiaomi, and then you get into a long tail of others. So we play that directly with the top 4 or 5 with direct engineer-to-engineer engagements. We also play the entire China theater with our baseband partners. So close collaboration with MediaTek, Spreadtrum, HiSilicon, even Qualcomm provides a buffer of diversification. So right now, China has been a solid market. We handicap it quite well. We analyze the data from the distributors. We look at the poll rates and the upgrade data that we get from China mobile and others. And we feel we have a very balanced outlook. I don't expect any volatility through any double ordering or anything like that. I don't see that, but we'll maintain a cautious view as we look out.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's extremely helpful. And then kind of wanted to get your sense on what you look for, what are your criteria for M&A and what's the appetite for M&A right now?
componenttext: That's extremely helpful. And then kind of wanted to get your sense on what you look for, what are your criteria for M&A and what's the appetite for M&A right now?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. Well, I mean, the good news for us is that we're very bullish on the opportunities in front of us today at Skyworks. There's a great deal for us to do in our core markets in mobile and IoT and expanding our broad portfolio. We like what we see
componenttext: Sure, sure. Well, I mean, the good news for us is that we're very bullish on the opportunities in front of us today at Skyworks. There's a great deal for us to do in our core markets in mobile and IoT and expanding our broad portfolio. We like what we see there. There's a tremendous need to support great customers looking forward. So M&A isn't something that is mission-critical for Skyworks. But having said that, we continue to look at opportunities if they come about. Our track record, as you know, reflects that we are highly disciplined when it comes to M&A. A deal needs to meet all of our stringent criteria. You can see that we've done a few deals in the last few years. The Panasonic JV has closed, bringing great TC technology -- TC SAW technology in-house. We got a 5G deal a few years ago for WiFi technology. That's played out beautifully. And even a power management deal with Advance Analogic. And all of those elements play very well into our long-term strategy. So we will keep our lens open for opportunities as they come about, but again, very stringent financial criteria here.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Craig Ellis with B. Riley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Craig Ellis with B. Riley.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to start with a longer-term question on the growth of the business. So one of the supply chain players, early in the reporting season, noted they think that smartphones will grow about 5% through 2020. So I'm not asking you to endorse that. But i
componenttext: I wanted to start with a longer-term question on the growth of the business. So one of the supply chain players, early in the reporting season, noted they think that smartphones will grow about 5% through 2020. So I'm not asking you to endorse that. But if that were the industry's growth rate, what growth rate would you be satisfied with organically? And do you feel like you've got enough leverage in the portfolio to drive sufficient organic growth? Or do you need to have a blended organic and inorganic strategy?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think organically, Craig, if you look at the unit growth, which is approximately, as you indicated, about 5% on smartphones. It's the content lever that we're most excited about. And if you listened in the prepared remarks, one of the reasons why
componenttext: Well, I think organically, Craig, if you look at the unit growth, which is approximately, as you indicated, about 5% on smartphones. It's the content lever that we're most excited about. And if you listened in the prepared remarks, one of the reasons why we talked about this mobile ecosystem in some of these great companies that are monetizing it is that they really are driving change. They're driving change with our customers, and our customers are driving that change to us. And often, it's a give-and-take. And in many cases, we're at the drawing board in crafting these incredible systems that move data. So we see content being really the key focus. So we see unit growth could be 3% to 5%, maybe as high as 7% in top line units. But it's the content lever that is unique. And I think that is where -- I know that is where Skyworks outperforms. The higher the content in terms of the complexity and the performance needs, that's when we do our best work. So with that said, we would expect to be at or around double digits across the board, could be higher in some cases depending on the market and the mix.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then one for Kris. Kris, you mentioned that you'd expect gross margins to be up 100 basis points this year. That's solid, but it is just 40% of what the business had done in the just-completed year. So as we look at the performance of
componenttext: That's helpful. And then one for Kris. Kris, you mentioned that you'd expect gross margins to be up 100 basis points this year. That's solid, but it is just 40% of what the business had done in the just-completed year. So as we look at the performance of the business, should we expect that as the expanded manufacturing facility, both the Panasonic and in packaging, as that really ramps and hits its operational stride that longer term we can get back to years where gross margins can improve on a multi-hundred basis point basis? Or is this the new run rate for the business?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, there are definitely multiple levers to improve gross margins. As Liam just explained, we see some above-market revenue growth. And of course, incremental revenue and volume growth help to absorb our fixed cost structure. Secondly, we are insourc
componenttext: Yes. No, there are definitely multiple levers to improve gross margins. As Liam just explained, we see some above-market revenue growth. And of course, incremental revenue and volume growth help to absorb our fixed cost structure. Secondly, we are insourcing the filters in our own filter fab, and that is driving further margin expansion. And then of course, there is the normal tackle and blocking and operational efficiency improvements, including cycle time reduction, yield improvements and internal and external cost reductions. And maybe last but not least as well, we do see a further mix improvement in some other areas outside of mobile that have slightly above-average gross margin. And when you put that all together, we are comfortable that we can further improve our gross margins.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Atif Malik with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll go next to Atif Malik with Citigroup.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Liam, the first question, you talked about the criteria for M&A, and I think in the past, Skyworks has talked about maybe acquiring something in the $2 billion to $3 billion range kind of size of the company. Can you just remind us what else in the criter
componenttext: Liam, the first question, you talked about the criteria for M&A, and I think in the past, Skyworks has talked about maybe acquiring something in the $2 billion to $3 billion range kind of size of the company. Can you just remind us what else in the criteria you're looking at? And is this still the right size of the deal you're looking at?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't really want to put any boundaries on deal size. I think it's more about the merit of the opportunity and how it plays within the Skyworks franchise so to speak. So we definitely look for opportunities that -- and we talk -- everyone talks
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't really want to put any boundaries on deal size. I think it's more about the merit of the opportunity and how it plays within the Skyworks franchise so to speak. So we definitely look for opportunities that -- and we talk -- everyone talks about synergies in terms of accretion and financials, but I also want to see entities that really do better with the Skyworks brand than they would separately. We talked about some success stories, SiGe, Panasonic, even AATI are examples of that. So we would like to have the kind of acquisitions that really raise the overall franchise that bring us into new technology opportunities that perhaps augment our strength already and the positions in the market that we enjoy today. So it's -- really, it's a complex answer. There isn't one simple thing that we're looking for. It's a number of things. We do have a very, very high bar. We've looked at a lot of franchise and a lot of assets. And for us, the bars are quite high, and I like that. I think we've worked really hard to generate the cash that now has been phenomenal for us. And I think we're in a great track record to continue to do that. We have the powder to do the right deals when they come along, but we'll continue to be very, very vigilant.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then as a follow-up, you guys had pretty good design wins in the latest iPhone diversity switch module. And Murata was quoted in a Nikkei article in Japan that they could take pricing down by like 1/3 in order to get the sockets back. And can yo
componenttext: Sure. And then as a follow-up, you guys had pretty good design wins in the latest iPhone diversity switch module. And Murata was quoted in a Nikkei article in Japan that they could take pricing down by like 1/3 in order to get the sockets back. And can you just talk about the stickiness of these wins? And how should we think about you guys sustaining this content going into next year?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes. I mean, all of these complex solutions that you alluded to, whether they're with a lead customer or the top 3 or 4, are highly customized. I know what we offer. It's highly customized. It is very sticky. These are engineer-to-engineer developed
componenttext: Sure. Yes. I mean, all of these complex solutions that you alluded to, whether they're with a lead customer or the top 3 or 4, are highly customized. I know what we offer. It's highly customized. It is very sticky. These are engineer-to-engineer developed solutions, highly calibrated within the customer's ecosystem. There's little risk that there'll be -- anyone will be unseated or there'll be any kind of pricing action post design win. And then it's the incumbency, the ability to execute, the ability to manage your capacities and execute to supply and all those other things that keep you in at the long term. So we feel really good about our position with the leading accounts and our ability to grow at highly complex solutions that better -- in -- and every new cycle, upgraded, altered, changed to meet customers' needs.

componenttext: There will be some seasonal fluctuations as you go through the normal seasonality. But on average, that's what we target.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: We have a question from Ambrish Srivastava with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Kulin Patel, calling in for Ambrish. For the year-on-year revenue headwind, you mentioned headwind at your largest customer. Is all the headwind due to legacy units? Or was there any share loss?
componenttext: This is Kulin Patel, calling in for Ambrish. For the year-on-year revenue headwind, you mentioned headwind at your largest customer. Is all the headwind due to legacy units? Or was there any share loss?

With that behind us, the run rate CapEx that Kris mentioned is sustainable. It's enough for us. We can do a great job with that capital and monetize our assets and filters as well.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, diversification is an element. It's something that we look for, but it's really -- it isn't the only criteria. It's not the underlying criteria. I think we're looking for opportunities that really drive the entirety of the business. And as w
componenttext: Well, I mean, diversification is an element. It's something that we look for, but it's really -- it isn't the only criteria. It's not the underlying criteria. I think we're looking for opportunities that really drive the entirety of the business. And as we said, we feel really good about what mobile is bringing. It's a lot more than what the market expected 3 or 4 years ago or 5 years ago. And what we're seeing from our customers is just a daunting and relentless portion of performance. And what was also enjoying, our product developments and revenue streams that weren't on the radar screen 5 years ago. Diversity received, we talked about. WiFi has been taking off. Our GPS location systems are taking off. We're seeing more and more reach into our filter franchise. So just -- there's just a lot to do. So we wouldn't look at a deal on the merit of diversification as a primary motive. It would be nice in some cases, but we would also entertain opportunities that really help us advance our core business.

componenttextpreview: Got it. And as you look at the BAWs -- BAW road map, I know you guys said you are getting BAWs from some of your foundry partners. Can you update us how your road map looks there? Are you expecting any BAW products launching here? Or still expect TC SAW t
componenttext: Got it. And as you look at the BAWs -- BAW road map, I know you guys said you are getting BAWs from some of your foundry partners. Can you update us how your road map looks there? Are you expecting any BAW products launching here? Or still expect TC SAW to be kind of -- take that part of the bands, too?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I mean, there are significant growth opportunities in the areas that we are strong today across TC SAW. We continue to push the frequency range in TC SAW quite nicely. We're winning a lot of products there, not only on transmit but also on div
componenttext: Sure. Well, I mean, there are significant growth opportunities in the areas that we are strong today across TC SAW. We continue to push the frequency range in TC SAW quite nicely. We're winning a lot of products there, not only on transmit but also on diversity receive. So BAW technology is not critical. It's not mission-critical. We understand where it is in road maps and where it isn't in road maps. We are making great progress again in raising the market opportunity for our TC solutions. And also when you look at things like 5G, what we're seeing is that there's more and more TDD capability in 5G than FDD. So when you go to TDD, time division duplexing, you don't require a BAW filter or a BAW duplexer. You can do it with TC and may use frequencies. So that's another expanding opportunity for us. Now having said all that, we have access to BAW. We're using it today with some of our flagship products with foundry partners. We always take a look at make versus buy. Is it an opportunity for us to invest in-house? We'll continue to weigh that balance, but be sure that we're going to be able to address the market as we need to. We'll be able to address the filter opportunities and the systems engines that we've been delivering for years. So there's no stop on that.

componenttextpreview: Great question. I'm glad you brought that up. So SkyBlue is a method that Skyworks uses really as a -- another way to provide efficiency in the amplification and transmission food chain. And so we do that with a very unique proprietary architecture we cal
componenttext: Great question. I'm glad you brought that up. So SkyBlue is a method that Skyworks uses really as a -- another way to provide efficiency in the amplification and transmission food chain. And so we do that with a very unique proprietary architecture we call SkyBlue. It is embedded in some of our system solutions. If you looked at some of the leading platforms that we've announced, and you can see they were teardowns, both devices are apparent there, they made up with our SkyOne solutions to provide higher levels of efficiency, incredible levels, higher than ET, in many cases. It's a device that is baseband agnostic. We're working with all the key chipset providers as well. And it is very early for us right now. We have a long way to go with this solution. We're continuing to provide new and additional revs with upgraded performance, but it is in production with 4 or 5 key brands today.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Liam, if the iPhone 6s inventories all consumed by the time you exit December, as you indicated, why should we expect to see orders for those parts to you from Apple if they keep selling that phone in 2018? Is that an erroneous assumption? But if the phon
componenttext: Liam, if the iPhone 6s inventories all consumed by the time you exit December, as you indicated, why should we expect to see orders for those parts to you from Apple if they keep selling that phone in 2018? Is that an erroneous assumption? But if the phone's still being built after they consume all of their raw material from you, then I would expect you'd see some sort of revenue for that product. And then on MediaTek Phase 2, Phase 3, China has been very strong for you and for your competitors. And I know that Phase 2, Phase 3 only use modules with switches and amplifiers. But it sounds like MediaTek may be moving to pads earlier than expected. You currently do not sell discrete filters into that market. But if they go to pads and you're 1 of the 2 big suppliers of those parts already, why should we expect that your filter demand should step up significantly, because MediaTek would obviously be buying those filters from whoever's supplying the modules and that's going to be you and maybe Qorvo?

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great insights, Ed. So on the first one, certainly, if there were additional demand requirements for the legacy products with our lead customer, we'd be well positioned to deliver, and that could be incremental revenue for us. So that's one. And then
componenttext: Yes, great insights, Ed. So on the first one, certainly, if there were additional demand requirements for the legacy products with our lead customer, we'd be well positioned to deliver, and that could be incremental revenue for us. So that's one. And then with respect to MediaTek, you got it right. I mean, so right now we have a very strong partnership with MediaTek. And one of the products that has done really well in that ecosystem is our SkyLiTE product. And so the SkyLiTE product, and I know you'll get this, but for everyone, it is really a SkyOne solution absent the filters. So we lay out all the required amplification, transmit receipts, switching. And we do everything but the filters, and we allow the MediaTek ecosystem, the customers that use the MediaTek chipset, to pick and choose filters. That's been the way of the land here for a while. Next rev, we are looking at integrating -- leveraging our TC SAW capability to bring in a complete PAD or SkyOne-like product to these MediaTek customers. So it's a great opportunity. We're working on it right. Hopefully, we'll have more to report to you here in the next quarter.

At this time, I will turn the call over to Mitch Haws, Investor Relations for Skyworks. Mr. Haws, please go ahead.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks' Fourth Fiscal Quarter and Year-end 2016 Conference Call. On the call today are Liam Griffin, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Kris Sennesael, our Chief Financial Officer
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Skyworks' Fourth Fiscal Quarter and Year-end 2016 Conference Call. On the call today are Liam Griffin, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Kris Sennesael, our Chief Financial Officer. 
Before we begin, I would like to remind everyone that our discussion will include statements relating to future results and expectations that are or may be considered forward-looking. Please refer to our earnings press release and recent SEC filings, including our annual report on Form 10-K, for information on certain risks that could cause actual outcomes to differ materially and adversely from any forward-looking statements made today. 
Additionally, the results and guidance we will discuss today are from our non-GAAP financials, consistent with the format we have used in the past. Please refer to our press release within the Investor Relations section of our company website for a complete reconciliation to GAAP.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Liam.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mitch, and welcome, everyone. The Skyworks team delivered solid Q4 and fiscal 2016 results, demonstrating the resiliency and power of our business model. To put a few metrics in perspective, we achieved record revenue of $3.3 billion; expanded gro
componenttext:
Thanks, Mitch, and welcome, everyone. The Skyworks team delivered solid Q4 and fiscal 2016 results, demonstrating the resiliency and power of our business model. To put a few metrics in perspective, we achieved record revenue of $3.3 billion; expanded gross margin by 280 basis points; delivered 37.8% operating margin; generated record operating cash flow of $1.1 billion, allowing us to return $727 million in cash to our shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases, more than double the amount from last year. And despite headwinds with one of our leading customers, we are pleased with our ability to deliver record results in fiscal year 2016.
Now at a high level, we see strengthening dynamics in the core markets we serve. Specifically, we are in the midst of a massive sea change in the mobile usage case, given the utility and value that connected devices are bringing to the world. We are supporting and in many ways, enabling a mobile ecosystem that is cannibalizing traditional brick-and-mortar industries, transforming the way we live, work and play. Wireless platforms have become virtual hubs for e-commerce, enterprise to cloud, social media, gaming and entertainment portals. Ultimately, these devices are a conduit for a new multi-trillion dollar connected economy across a wealth of innovative technology players.
Consider that the top 5 S&P 500 companies: namely Apple, Google Alphabet, Microsoft, Facebook and Amazon are all monetizing these themes with mobile-centric business models. At the same time, smartphone architectures are evolving to accommodate this rapid increase in mobile data across a densely crowded spectrum. The usage case is a catalyst for higher speed, lower latency, secure and always-on connectivity, which is challenging the capabilities of existing hardware in the supporting cellular infrastructure.
Our mission at Skyworks is resolving this daunting complexity with customized custom-level solutions, unburdening our customers while improving the user experience, with higher levels of efficiency, enhanced streaming capabilities and expanded network coverage. All of this translates into an expanding opportunity for Skyworks. Recall that our focus is on the wireless connection, the most critical function linking the user to this incredible ecosystem. 
And in addition to the rise of mobile data, we are actively addressing 2 parallel growth drivers. First, connecting the unconnected. There remain 2 billion people that have yet to benefit from this dynamic ecosystem, and Skyworks will play a leading role in bringing this population online. In addition, we are committed to connecting everything as we address an estimated 20 billion new devices brought to market over the next 5 years. Skyworks is seamlessly enabling these massive opportunities with highly customized system solutions, supporting a broad set of protocols, including cellular LTE to WiFi, Bluetooth, ZigBee and emerging 5G standards.
In an effort to facilitate the explosive growth of data delivery, creation, movement and storage, our customers are implementing methods to improve performance with carrier aggregation, receive diversity and MIMO functionality. This dynamic involves a step function increase in levels of requisite analog and mixed-signal performance, enhanced power efficiency and high-precision filtering, as well as configurable systems integration capabilities.
Skyworks' broad portfolio and systems-level expertise are well aligned to resolve the intense performance demands facing our customers. And further, 5G will be yet another industry catalyst and significant content driver for Skyworks. This technology will drive band proliferation in higher frequencies and play squarely into our ability to address complexity with fully integrated systems. 
The breadth of our portfolio and our unique market reach continues to fuel a robust and diverse design win pipeline. To illustrate, during the most recent quarter, we leveraged our leadership SkyOne architecture across scores of 4G LTE platforms, with customers like Huawei across their Honor 8 premium lineup. We are also powering the first Google-branded LTE Pixel smartphone. And we are capturing design wins across broader markets in the Internet of Things. In particular, we continue gaining traction with customers like Amazon, supporting their Echo and Tap digital assistance. We are also enabling NETGEAR's Orbi home router system and providing an integrated solution to Trilliant for use in their smart grid platforms.
In addition, we are deploying small-cell solutions for several leading infrastructure providers in China. And in automotive, we are delivering 4G LTE solutions for use in both Land Rover and Jaguar modules -- models. These wins and others demonstrate our expanding customer and end market reach across both mobile platforms and the IoT.
At this point, I will turn the call over to Kris for his financial review.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Liam. Revenue for the fourth fiscal quarter was $835.4 million, up 11% sequentially and exceeding our guidance and consensus. Gross profit was $425.9 million or 51% of revenue, in line with our guidance and up 100 basis points from the fourth quar
componenttext:
Thanks, Liam. Revenue for the fourth fiscal quarter was $835.4 million, up 11% sequentially and exceeding our guidance and consensus. Gross profit was $425.9 million or 51% of revenue, in line with our guidance and up 100 basis points from the fourth quarter last year. Operating expenses were $107.5 million, consistent with our guidance for flat sequential spending. We generated $318.4 million of operating income, translating into 38.1% operating margin. Our cash tax rate was 12.6%, driving net income of $277.6 million or $1.47 of diluted earnings per share, exceeding our guidance by $0.04.
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow. Cash flow from operations was a record $455 million, driven by higher profitability and significant improvements in working capital on a sequential basis. In particular, DSOs declined from 69 to 45 days. And days of inventory declined from 108 to 94 days, and we expect further reduction of inventory dollars and inventory days in Q1. Capital expenditures were $16 million versus $57 million in Q3, reflecting the lower investment level now required for our TC SAW filter production. 
Further, in Q4, we repurchased 3 million shares at an average price of roughly $66 a share. And for fiscal '16, we have repurchased 8 million shares at an average price of just under $66 per share, helping us to reduce our share count from 195 million shares entering the fiscal year to 189 million shares exiting Q4. We also distributed over $200 million in dividends over the course of fiscal 2016, up 63% year-over-year. 
In summary, Skyworks returned 81% of our free cash flow or $727 million to our shareholders over the fiscal year, up from the 64% distributed in fiscal 2015.
Now moving on to our outlook. For the first fiscal quarter of 2017, we anticipate our revenue to be up 7% to 9% sequentially. At the midpoint of $902 million, we expect gross margin in the low 51% range. We expect operating expenses to be $112 million, further reducing our overall OpEx ratio to 12.4% of revenue.
Below the line, we anticipate around $1 million in interest and other expenses, and a cash tax rate of approximately 15%. We expect our share count to be roughly 187 million shares. With our revenue growth and continued operating leverage, we plan to generate non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $1.58 in the first fiscal quarter.
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Liam.

headline: Skyworks Solutions Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kris. So to quickly summarize, we delivered above-guidance results in the fourth fiscal quarter, closing out another record year, driven by increasing global demand for high-speed connectivity, coupled with strong operational execution. Skyworks'
componenttext:
Thanks, Kris. So to quickly summarize, we delivered above-guidance results in the fourth fiscal quarter, closing out another record year, driven by increasing global demand for high-speed connectivity, coupled with strong operational execution. Skyworks' systems-level expertise and scale advantages are positioning us to capitalize on the rapidly expanding mobile and IoT ecosystems, particularly with 5G on the horizon. Our profitability and strong cash generation capabilities allow us to fund growth and deliver increasingly higher returns to our shareholders. 
Clearly, we remain well positioned to realize our vision of connecting everyone and everything all the time.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, let's open the lines for questions.
